PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989THERAPEUTIC GOODS BILL 1989THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 December, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989. Last night before the adjournment debate I was putting the Opposition's position on a number of issues in regard to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The National Party and the Liberal Party support the charter and the agreement-the principles-but they wish to reiterate that the charter and the agreement should be brought before Parliament before the legislation is passed by both Houses and enacted. As the legislation stands at the moment, it gives the Minister massive power to bring the agreement and the charter before the House after the legislation has gone through. The agreement cannot even be removed by regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has some reservations also about the community visitor provision, which my contribution will pick up. The amendments that the Opposition has moved also have the support of the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals, another major organisation representing nursing homes in Australia; Geriaction, an organisation representing nurses and the aged Australia-wide; the Association of Self-Help Organisations and Groups, representing all the self-help groups in Australia, including the Association of Blind Citizens, the Epilepsy Association, the Mental Health Coordinating Council, to name but a few; and nursing associations throughout the country.

On behalf of the industry, the aged themselves, their relatives, the nursing profession and proprietors, the Opposition puts forward these amendments which will ensure that the charter and agreement will, when they are formulated, come back to both Houses of Parliament for scrutiny, debate and amendment if necessary, and then approval by both Houses. We also propose that the principles that the Minister is enabled by this legislation to lay down in respect of approved operators of approved nursing homes should be subject to approval by both Houses. That does not happen under this legislation. The Minister virtually has carte blanche to put anything he wishes into a charter without the supervision of the Senate or the House of Representatives.

The Opposition believes that it is the responsibility of the Minister to report back to Parliament and not hide himself behind regulations and the bureaucracy. If there is no hidden agenda in this legislation, this should be the course to be followed. As my colleague Ray Braithwaite, the honourable member for Dawson, said in the other place, we are discussing in this case the quality of the care of our aged. We are talking about the rights of an individual to be absorbed into a higher quality of care, and that is what the Opposition intends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on all the Bills which are being dealt with cognately this morning: the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, dealing with the matter of patients' rights in nursing homes; and the therapeutic goods legislation, which concerns registration, listing and the regulatory processes dealing with both therapeutic agents and physical therapeutic goods.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn first to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which Senator Boswell has just been addressing. This legislation is primarily designed, as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) said in his second reading speech, to enable residents' rights to be implemented in nursing homes and hostels. He lists a number of other things which this Bill does and says that it removes the necessity for a medical certificate for nursing home admission, allows for backdating of domiciliary nursing care benefit in certain circumstances, provides for proprietors of nursing homes to be approved operators, provides for lodgment and processing fees for reviews of budgets or deficits of certain nursing homes and, finally, includes certain minor amendments consequential on the implementation of new respite care arrangements in nursing homes.

The principal measure to which Senator Boswell has addressed his remarks and to which I will be addressing my remarks is the enabling of the establishment of a charter of patients' rights in nursing homes and hostels. The Minister, further on in his second reading speech, identifies that as the principal purpose of the Bill. He says:
The major purpose of the Bill is to produce new provisions which give effect to the rights and responsibilities of residents of Commonwealth funded aged care facilities.

There lies the rub, which has already been identified. The Bill does not give effect to these rights and responsibilities. This Bill is enabling legislation. The rights and responsibilities which are drawn in the Bill are very broadly drawn indeed. If we look at clause 4 of part 2 of the Bill we see that the Minister may, by instrument, formulate a statement of the rights and responsibilities of the residents of approved hostels. Proposed subsection (3) in clause 4 goes on:
Without limiting the generality of subsection (2), the charter may state that the resident has:
(a) a right to be treated as an individual; and
(b) a right to personal independence; and
(c) a right to privacy;
(d) a right to access to all documents relating to the resident; and
(e) a responsibility to respect the rights of others.

Nobody would disagree with the protection of those rights, especially in the area of aged care. But behind each of those simple forms of words lies a potentially incredibly complex quagmire and a difficult area of resolution. The first paragraph concerns the right to be treated as an individual. Certainly there are many aged people who go into this type of care who are still physically reasonably well and who have all their mental faculties about them. Clearly, the right to be treated as an individual is exactly the same right as one would accord to everybody in the community, without exception. But many patients who go into nursing homes suffer from various degrees of dementia and from a loss of mental capacity. The question of what it is to be treated as an individual under those circumstances is not clarified by this Bill, but presumably it will be clarified in the charter.

Similarly, as one goes down the list one finds `the right to personal independence'. What happens to a patient with Alzheimer's disease, who is progressively losing the ability to know exactly where he or she is, and whose geographic sense is progressively being lost? Most of these people go through a stage of wandering, of getting lost. How then does one interpret the right to personal independence? To what degree has one a right to restrain that person for the person's own good, because he or she may wander across roads and be run over and killed?

There is a similar difficulty with the right to privacy. As people with Alzheimer's disease deteriorate, they become incontinent. They have to be nursed, as babies have to be nursed. At what point does nursing care intersect with the stated principle of the right to privacy? Similarly, in dealing with patients in this category there is difficulty in resolving the conflicting rights of one patient vis-a-vis another patient and also with respect to the director of a nursing home and members of the nursing staff. It seems, to me that, while the idea of a charter of patients' rights is absolutely commendable and while one could not find exception to the outline we find in the Bill at a number of places, nonetheless, in the working out of the detail, the implementation of these clauses in terms of the identification of precise rights-bearing in mind that the charter will become a legal document once it is in place-is fraught with enormous difficulty. The implementation of those rights is something that is fraught with enormous difficulty and therefore needs to be approached with a great deal of care and in a completely open and transparent way so that one can get the best description of those rights, the best protection of the rights of patients and the balancing of the rights and responsibilities in that charter. It is for those sorts of reasons that the Australian Democrats are supporting the approach being taken by the Opposition.

I think it is worth pointing out that the process which is implicit in the legislation is one in which the charter will be dealt with in the same manner as regulations. Proposed new section 10DA (4) states:
The Charter is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

This means that if the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 were allowed to pass in its present form if would be quite possible for the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) to bring forward a charter in early January. I am hypothesising here-the Minister in the chamber yesterday Senator Bolkus, criticised me for hypothesising-but the rumour is that we might have an election in late February and we may not sit in this place again until April. The 15 sitting days during which the charter would be disallowable would begin some time in April and the charter could be in operation for at least six months before it was possible to modify it.

I think a lot of people in the community do not realise that one of the defects in the system of disallowable instruments is that we must either allow or disallow in toto. We are not given the option of, amending, changing and improving those disallowable instruments-usually regulations but, in this case, the charter of patients' rights. As I have indicated, it is for that reason that we believe the better process in this case is to support the legislation in its intention but to say to the Government that the better way to proceed with respect to the charter is to bring that charter forward in a way that allows it to be debated, to be amended and then to be implemented in the best possible form.

Yesterday, the Minister, Mr Staples, rang me and tried to convince me otherwise. His argument was along the lines that somehow or other allowing this legislation to pass and allowing him to introduce the charter in the form of a regulation would speed up the process. I did not accept his argument and I pointed out to him, and I point it out to fellow senators, that the process that is allowed for in the Opposition's series of amendments is far more likely to put in place an effective charter of patients, rights before one could go down the road of regulation and then through the process of disallowance with all the difficulties that that entails. If we were to find some objection to one minor but important element in that charter, we would have to disallow it. The Government would than have to go away and come back with a whole new charter. That would then have to be considered, and again it would be an allow or a disallow situation, not one open to amendment.

This is a serious defect in the system. I believe that the Opposition has found a mechanism whereby one can get around this process in important matters, and this is a very important matter, so that the charter can be argued about in detail and amendments made to it. We will be supporting the Opposition's series of amendments. They are a series of amendments because the question of the charter comes up in a number of places in the Bill, the Bill being one which amends a number of other Acts.

To summarise, the Democrats favour the charter. We favour the broad principles which are outlined in the Bill. We are not happy, however, with the process by which this charter is to be introduced. It is for that reason that we support the mechanism whereby the charter can come back before both Houses of Parliament and be debated and, possibly, amended. We believe there are a number of potential difficulties in this area. We are dealing with extremely complex situations and the resolution of that complexity is something that will take a great deal of care.

I wish to turn now to the therapeutic goods legislation. Again, the Democrats welcome the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989. It provides for national controls over therapeutic goods, something we have not had hitherto, and in a sense it follows in the tradition of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill, which we passed in December 1988 when we brought the registration and regulation of those agents largely under Federal control. I think everybody would accept that this is an area where it is far more appropriate for the Federal Government to register and regulate these matters. The Bill does this with respect to drugs and therapeutic agents in that sense, but also with respect to instruments which are used in a medical sense. Instruments which are used in the diagnosis, cure or alleviation of illness-for example, pacemakers, catheters, specula, the whole range of medical instrumentation-will come under this Bill.

Appropriately, the major parts of the Bill cover the determination of standards, with respect to both the manufacturer and the efficacy and operation of the agents or the instruments, the establishment of a register of goods for import, export and supply, and also the licensing of Australian manufacturers. Behind that lies a process of factory inspections, so that, in the case of injectables, standards of sterility, standards of efficacy, toxicity and all the other data that will be required will go into that process. The register of therapeutic goods will consist of two parts-one for registered goods and the other forlisted goods. Goods to be registered will require evaluation as to quality, safety and effectiveness before being approved. Goods to be listed will be those of a less hazardous nature which require assessment for quality and compliance with official standards.

We will be seeking to move several amendments in relation to this legislation because, although the thrust of the legislation is one we totally support, and indeed, appears to be supported by the large number of people who have lobbied for it, there are some clear defects in the legislation which we will be seeking to amend. Firstly, in the matter of labelling, the Bill clearly allows that it would be possible for Australia to export items with lesser standards of labelling than would be applicable in Australia. As a general principle-and I think this has been enunciated with respect to a number of potentially hazardous situations-Australia should not be a country which exports agents or items which would not be acceptable for use in this country. Of course, that general principle should also apply to the labelling of items. Indeed, the World Health Organisation recently stated that all packaging and labelling materials should provide information consistent with that approved by the country's drug regulatory authority. Australia should not be known as a country which allows dumping of products in other countries.

Just harking back for a moment to the agricultural and veterinary chemical area, in times past we have been on the receiving end of some agents from the United States which were not permitted to be used in that country. I know of at least one drug-I had something to do with its testing-which was introduced to Australia before it was put on the American market. I am not suggesting that in that case we were used in any sense as a dumping ground. Nonetheless, the first registration occurred in this country and, therefore, we needed very adequate labelling and information on that agent. There was a need to make appropriate registration and regulatory decisions.

Another matter which is of concern to the Democrats is the role of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) in the assessment of therapeutic agents, particularly drugs. Some of those agents fall into two categories-medicines and vitamin treatments, which are espoused by many people but are somewhat outside the realm of orthodox medicine. The National Health and Medical Research Council is not a statutory body. For many years the processes by which the NHMRC committees consider these matters have not been open to close scrutiny. Moreover, the members of these committees are usually part time people who are drawn from research institutes and universities. They are busy people and very often there are long delays between the submission of a substance for testing and judgment in respect of efficacy, quality, pharmacology and so on. For all those reasons, the NHMRC system has not really worked very well.

It is not possible for us to amend this Bill to change the NHMRC system. But at the committee stage I will certainly be seeking from the Minister some assurance in relation to placing this committee system on a more full time basis so that decisions can be made more quickly and we can establish a more transparent system of review. I want to outline the sorts of concerns that have been expressed to me. Some companies which are making megavitamin or multivitamin tablets and putting those products on the market fear that the NHMRC committee system, composed of more conventional medical-type people, is likely to take an antagonistic view in regard to the registration of some of their products. Coming from a conventional medical background, I might share the NHMRC's judgment about those items. But that is not the point I want to make.

The point I want to make is that the NHMRC system of consideration of data should firstly be open to free import of information from bodies that are seeking the registration of these agents. Secondly, the processes of review of those agents should be open to scrutiny so that the NHMRC committee can be seen to have considered the data. Its judgments and the reasons behind them should be clear and open to scrutiny and if there is an element of prejudice which is not soundly scientifically based there should be some appeal mechanism. Again, one points to the fact that there is no appeal mechanism in the NHMRC system. That is an area on which this legislation will rely quite heavily. In the past it has not been very satisfactory and needs to be improved but it cannot be improved through this legislation.

Concern has also been expressed that the Victorian legislation in relation to therapeutic agents will continue for a time. Many companies have expressed the concern that they will still have to face a double system-a system of national legislation and also a system of Victorian legislation and standards. I am informed that the Victorian Premier and the Victorian Minister for Health have given assurance that when this legislation is proclaimed the Victorian system will be repealed. At the appropriate time, I will be seeking an assurance from the relevant Minister in this place that that is the intention of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be at exactly the same time. That is what we have got to ask for.
—As Senator Baume has said, it should be certainly simultaneous or as close as technically feasible so that one simply supervenes the other.

SPEECH.PARA: The other major area of concern relates to both the therapeutic industry which manufactures a large range of small volume products and a number of small starter companies which manufacture medical instrumentation. Concern has been expressed that in both those instances the scale of fees foreshadowed in this legislation is such as to discourage or kill off companies that are making a large number of small volume products. Those who have expressed concern about this matter are principally in the herbal remedy area. If they have to face a very large fee, some of their products would not be profitable and would disappear from the market.

The imposition of large fees on some of the smaller manufacturers which may eventually have quite high volume sales but which in the start-up years have very small volume sales with very large development costs, may well simply prevent them from getting under way. In their lobbying these companies have pointed out that an important philosophical principle is involved in this. They point to the fact that in the United States this type of process is considered as a service to the public-it protects the public-and therefore the public pays for it. The scheme is run at public expense through taxation and no fee at all is charged to the individual company for the inspection processes, registration of goods and so on.

This contrasts with the alternative view that this system is run as a service to industry. In that case, clearly industry pays. One could argue that the advantages to industry would be that it gets the imprimatur of the Government in terms of quality, overseas sales and so on. If there is reciprocity of quality acceptance, these manufacturers can go into interstate markets without further complication. Evidently the Government has taken a totally arbitrary position, saying, `Okay, we'll charge half of what we reckon it costs to run this process', and the fees are designed to cover 50 per cent of the cost. Recognising that that is a completely arbitrary decision and satisfies neither philosophical position, I suggest to the Government-later on we will do so by way of amendment-that in certain areas the fee which is charged should be waivable. Indeed, there is a provision in the Bill for that to occur, but the wording is extremely weak and we believe it could be strengthened. Those who have lobbied in this area have drawn attention to the large number of small, export oriented, profitable companies which operate in the States and contrasted that with the situation in the United Kingdom, where the fees, albeit small, are nonetheless levied against the industry.

In summary, we support the thrust of the legislation. The idea of bringing this whole matter under Federal control rather than leaving it with the States is supported by the Democrats. Indeed, it is supported by most people in the industry. However, care needs to be taken that the processes of assessment are open to proper scrutiny. The fees which are charged need to be based on a scale which does not inhibit the ability of companies to begin and develop export business. We would argue strongly that nothing in this legislation or in any other legislation should permit Australia to export anything which would not be permitted to be used in this country or, indeed, to allow it to be labelled in a way which was less specific and therefore to be used in a potentially hazardous way in a foreign country that was not allowed in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a package of three Bills-the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Therapeutic Goods Bill and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill. Although the Bills are being debated cognately, they are not related measures in terms of therapeutic goods and community services and health. As a result, I find myself in some difficulty, as the Opposition's spokesman on health matters in this chamber, in trying to address both sets of Bills within the time available.

SPEECH.PARA: The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) proposes a series of changes to the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953. The amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 are contained in part 5 of the legislation. There are nine changes proposed. The first restricts the eligibility for Medicare benefits to the head, the staff and the families of the diplomatic missions of countries which have an agreement with Australia specifically providing for their representatives to be treated as if they were Australian residents. This amendment is intended to rectify the current situation whereby diplomatic representatives in this country may be granted eligibility for Medicare benefits even if their own country confers no such privileges on Australian representatives serving there.

The second amendment removes the requirement that dental practitioners perform oral surgery in a hospital in order for those services to attract Medicare benefits. The third defines `officer' of the Health Insurance Commission to mean a member of the staff of the Commission and removes any possibility that `officer' could be interpreted as the General Manager, member or commissioner of the Health Insurance Commission. The fourth amendment is to the definition of the term `proprietor' of a pathology laboratory so that Medicare benefits for pathology services will be payable only when those laboratories have at least one proprietor who has effective control over the staffing, equipment and premises of the laboratory and can ensure the maintenance of certain standards.

The explanatory memorandum to the Bill argues that the corporate structure of some pathology laboratories currently makes it difficult to identify who is the operator of the services. This amendment is intended to overcome the problem. However, in spite of this statement it is not clear what the amendment can be expected to achieve. In cases where a laboratory is operated by a corporation or a number of equal partners, it is difficult to see how any one person could be made more responsible than some other person for the operation of that laboratory. As I understand it, there has been no consultation between the Government and the Australian Association of Pathology Practices on this issue. Therefore, I will ask the Minister who replies to the second reading debate to explain precisely what it is intended the amendment shall achieve and how that question can be addressed when there are equal partners or when the operator is a corporate entity.

The fifth amendment removes the previous provisions in relation to the vocational register of general practitioners when the Minister for Community Services and Health had the power to make determinations with regard to the role of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) in the conduct of the vocational register of general practitioners. Changes affecting the RACGP will now have to be made by way of regulation and not determination, as recommended by the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance.

The sixth amendment extends to the recipients of the formal training allowance the same health care card and pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) concessional benefits as are currently available to those in receipt of unemployment benefit. The seventh amendment provides for the Health Insurance Commission to play a role in the pro- cessing of claims for health program grants, which until now have had to be lodged with the Department of Community Services and Health. The eighth amendment provides that, where an officer of the Health Insurance Commission is involved in counselling practitioners on the admissibility of evidence, in addition to being an officer of the Commission the counsellor must have relevant qualifications as a medical practitioner, dental practitioner or optometrist. Finally, the ninth amendment provides for what is euphemistically described as the free flow of information between officers of the Department of Community Services and Health and the Health Insurance Commission as a result of the recent transfer of administrative responsibility for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to the Commission.

I say, once again, that the Opposition is conscious of and draws the attention of the Senate to the appalling record of the Health Insurance Commission in preserving the confidentiality of medical and personal records which it has under its control. The Commission has a disgraceful record, which its officers and senior managers should be ashamed of, in terms of the leaking of information, the deliberate political misuse of information within the hands of the Commission, and the deliberate policy of the Commission in making available details about individual medical practitioners for grubby and sleazy political purposes. The Health Insurance Commission has an appalling record in this regard. Although we will not oppose the Government's amendment in this regard to allow the exchange of information between the Department and the Commission, it is an area that we shall watch with considerable interest because it is about time that somebody in the Commission was effectively prosecuted and dealt with in the court system to prevent this sort of nonsense from occurring.

Part 6 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) makes amendments to the National Health Act 1953. Two amendments are proposed. The first relates to the arrangements for patients to pay an additional amount for a pharmaceutical item in cases where the manufacture disputes the price determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority. This amendment provides a formula for the calculation of a pro rata special patient contribution based on any prescribed quantity of such drugs rather than tying the payment to a fixed quantity.

Finally, there is an amendment providing for the Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health (DCSH) to be able to grant a retrospective entitlement to a concession on a PBS item in situations where eligibility for such a concession was, for some unavoidable reason, not provided at the time that the drugs were dispensed, resulting in payment at an inappropriate higher level. The Opposition welcomes that amendment. It is therefore not our intention to oppose the sections of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 as they relate to amendments within the health portfolio.

In the House of Representatives an amendment was moved by the Opposition regarding the determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal of 28 August 1989. It was proposed that we should move that amendment again within this legislation. But on the basis that the Senate yesterday insisted on insisting upon its amendment to the National Health Amendment Bill and has therefore sent back down to the House of Representatives a clear indication that the Senate requires that determination to be formally overturned by the Parliament, I have come to the view that we should not press that amendment in this particular piece of legislation.

I turn to the two Bills dealing with the regulation of therapeutic goods, the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989. I indicate at this stage that, to get it on record, I would formally move the amendment which has been prepared on behalf of the Opposition for the Bill to be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I would now like to have circulated the amendment in my name to the motion for the second reading. I now formally move:

At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate, while supporting the principle of uniform federal regulation of the manufacture of therapeutic goods in Australia, considers that the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989 are deficient in a number of respects and consequently resolves that the Bills be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for inquiry and report, by the first sitting day in March 1990, on:
(a) the impact of the proposals in the Bills on the therapeutic goods industry, with particular reference to the export sector of that industry and product innovation;

(b) the levels of service to be provided by the Department of Community Services and Health under the therapeutic goods program, the actual cost of listing and registering a product, and the means of measuring the performance of the therapeutic goods program;
(c) the evaluation procedures to be adopted and the scope for utilising evaluations performed in other competent countries;
(d) whether the intensification of controls is warranted;
(e) whether the provisions of the Bills should commence before the States and Territories enact complementary legislation;

(f) whether the National Health and Medical Research Council is an appropriate body for determining the Poisons Standard and what industry input should be provided for in the poisons scheduling process;
(g) the protection of the confidentiality of information and the industry's involvement in ensuring that confidentiality provisions are observed;
(h) the principle of a public authority charging product sponsors for performing services associated with its statutory public safety functions;
(i) whether public safety may be jeopardised as a result of the Department of Community Services and Health trying to expedite approvals of new products in order to maintain revenues;
(j) whether there are sufficient guarantees that all fees collected will be transferred from Consolidated Revenue to the Therapeutic Goods Administration Trust Account;
(k) whether it would be more appropriate to charge fees only for examining imported products;
(l) the extent to which the implementation of the provisions of these Bills could undermine the efforts of other government programs to promote R&D and export activity.''.

The purpose of the Therapeutic Goods Bill is to create a national system of control over the manufacture, evaluation and marketing of therapeutic goods and devices for both export and domestic consumption. The accompanying piece of legislation, the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill, relates to the application of a range of fees and charges for the registration and evaluation of therapeutic goods and devices and for the licensing of manufacturers and inspections under codes of good manufacturing practice.

For the purpose of this package of legislation the definition of therapeutic goods is a very wide one. It includes prescription and non-prescription medications, vitamin, mineral and dietary supplements, herbal and homeopathic preparations, as well as medical devices. The major parts of the Therapeutic Goods Bills relate to the determination of standards for therapeutic goods; the establishment of an Australian register of therapeutic goods approved for import, export or supply, and the licensing of Australian manufacturers of therapeutic goods. The proposed date of commencement of the legislation is 1 March 1990, with fees and charges to be collected from 1 July 1990.

In principle, both the Opposition and the therapeutic goods industry support the broad objectives of the Therapeutic Goods Bill. Indeed, I have just been reading an article by R. C. Hall in the Medical Journal of Australia, the 18 September 1989 issue, entitled `Drug Regulation in Australia'. In it Hall makes the point that there is a need for national legislation in this particular area. His article argues for the creation of a statutory authority to do that, and he derives some comfort in that view from an examination of the situation in both the United Kingdom and Sweden as far as these matters are concerned. Therefore I do not believe that there is any argument about the principle that there ought to be effective national regulation in this area.

Indeed, there are a number of obvious advantages to the community and the therapeutic goods industry in having a unified system of controls over therapeutic products and their advertising. As my colleague Senator Peter Baume said by way of interjection during Senator Coulter's speech, the important challenge will be to ensure that there is not an overlap or a continuation of regulation between existing State regulation-particularly in Victoria-and Commonwealth regulation should such a scheme come into effect.

There is no argument about the value of ensuring the quality, safety and efficiency of therapeutic goods and the need to protect the public interest in this regard. All of us in the Parliament are old enough to know something of the havoc wrought by thalidomide, for example. On the other hand, the Opposition shares a range of concerns expressed by the industry in relation to the Bills and the regulations which will underpin them. These matters include: doubts as to whether a national system of controls is achievable in this particular way; whether the Government's proposals contain adequate checks and balances and avenues of appeal; whether the codes of goods manufacturing practice are excessive and unreasonable on a benefit to risk basis; the damage which may be done to the manufacturing and export industries by the proposed fees and charges; and the fact that the whole structure is to be underpinned by regulations which have not been finalised or made available to the Parliament.

I come back to that last point. It is akin to the debate we had about a vocational register of general practitioners and have had ad nauseam, as we had indeed, from what Senator Coulter was saying, in relation to parts of the community services legislation: The suck-it-and-see approach of this Government, the `Let us pass the Bill and trust us to get it all right in the regulations at some later stage' approach, is not acceptable. Senator Ray, who is the Minister on duty in the chamber, has had particular experience, in terms of immigration, in establishing a proper mechanism whereby the Parliament is actually involved in making decisions about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We still get criticised for it as not going far enough.

—That is inevitable, but at least Senator Ray has taken the first step in developing a system which, hopefully, will grow into a model of the way in which regulation should be made in complicated areas rather than simply leaving them permanently on the basis of saying, `Let the Parliament simply pass the enabling legislation, and let the Department, or the bureaucracy or the Commission or the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) or whoever it happens to be, put down a set of regulations'-knowing full well that regulations in this place can only be taken or left in globo. We cannot amend particular parts of regulations. We have to strike them all down and start again or accept them all. That is simply not a satisfactory way for a parliament to proceed in determining regulations in a very difficult area. It is primarily for reasons such as these that the Opposition has decided that it will oppose the legislation, despite the fact that the Bills themselves are ones to which we do not object in principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to a more detailed discussion of why we have come to that conclusion. As I said, in principle, the package of legislation has been supported by the relevant industry groups, which see some advantage to the general public and the manufacturing industry in relation to the uniformity of scheduling and regulatory controls for manufactures. However, unless all of the States and Territories cooperate with the Commonwealth, the proposed system for the national registration of therapeutic goods will be unworkable. At this stage it appears that no Australian State or Territory government has drawn up complementary legislation. Apparently the Victorian Government has indicated that it is willing to look at repealing its own system of registration, but it will not do so until the spring 1990 parliamentary session. This means that if the national system comes into effect in March 1990 there will be dual registration in Victoria for some time.

These are matters with grave consequences for the industry, which wants a guarantee that the system will be implemented on a truly national basis. Therefore, there are grounds for arguing that Victoria should repeal or amend its legislation so that its system will not continue beyond the commencement of the national one and that all States and Territories should have complementary legislation in place when this Bill comes into effect.
On page (iv) of its information paper No. 13 of March 1989, entitled `Therapeutic Goods Regulation', the Business Regulation and Review Unit (BRRU) stated:

The paper considers that there are many areas where regulation generates unnecessarily high costs. It also considers that the intensifications of controls proposed by DCSH are not, in the main, warranted and that the charging proposals both for these intensifications and for the on-going program are excessive. These conclusions apply with particular force with regard to products having well known features and risks.

This proposition is totally consistent with the coalition parties' policy enunciated on page 16 of our Economic Action Plan, where recognition is given to the fact that accumulative regulation has become oppressive and a major obstacle to new investment and the improved productivity and competitiveness of Australian industry. The Business Regulation Review Unit also referred to an issue raised by the Therapeutic goods industry, namely, that a number of longstanding difficulties with the therapeutic goods program remain, and the increased regulation proposed-particularly the surveillance of a wider range of goods-may exacerbate rather than resolve these problems by reversing recent moves towards more risk related approaches. The DCSH proposes linking cost recovery through fees to an increase in the performance of the assessment and inspection sections of the therapeutics division. It envisages setting itself targets for clearance of drugs and an increased frequency of inspection of premises, although failure to meet those targets does not carry any specified penalty.

The BRRU states that in line with independent reviews conducted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the Public Service Board, the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and the Inquiry into the Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Industry-the so-called Ralph report-economies could be achieved if assessments were undertaken by competent overseas authorities and were to be accepted in Australia. Not only would such a move achieve savings, but it would also reduce delays in the availability of new products.

I now turn to the material that we have on this subject. There is a very detailed report from the IAC of April 1986, entitled Pharmaceutical Products; another detailed report, No. 295, from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in 1988 entitled Therapeutic Goods; and the Ralph report of August 1979, the pharmaceutical manufacturing industry inquiry. Many issues are raised in those reports and, indeed, in yet another report of the Public Service Board to which I have referred, which are not adequately addressed within this legislation.

The IAC estimated that drug approvals in Australia were slower by between 1.9 and 22.8 months than those of a group of developed countries. It also estimated that for the period 1970 to 1983 the average lag of 42.3 months, between first approval by another country and approval in Australia, was somewhat in excess of that of other countries. There is a scope within the Bill for goods manufactured overseas to be accepted on the basis of adequate evidence on the standard of manufacture from a relevant overseas authority. Whether an applicant has agreed to pay the costs of Australian inspectors visiting overseas manufacturing premises, and whether the manufacturer has agreed to such an inspection, are matters which may be considered in evaluating the registration of goods manufactured overseas.

Considerable industry opposition has been raised in relation to the scale of fees to be imposed. These fees are viewed as representing a hidden form of additional taxation designed to hide Public Service expenditure, although clause 59 (2) of the Bill states:
Fees prescribed under this Act must not be such as to amount to taxation.

I shall return to the comments made by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on that matter in due course. However, the Government has made it clear that it intends to raise one half of the costs of operating the therapeutic goods program from the industry, and departmental officers have told the industry that the Department regards the fees and charges as revenue and expects the costs to be passed on to the public. Industry argues that the fees represent double-dipping, as its companies are paying taxes for the provision of government services, and that individual taxpayers pay income tax for the same purpose.

The payment of additional fees and charges for government services is seen as being unreasonable and inequitable, and the level of charges does not relate to the level of services offered. Just how much service will be delivered in return for the payment, year after year, of a registration or listing fee for an unchanged item is hard to determine. In addition, the charges will have an inflationary impact and it can be expected that they will be lifted by the Government, maybe to the point where it carries out its own original intention to recover 100 per cent of the therapeutic goods program, and that will inevitably flow on to consumers.

The 1988 report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts No. 295 entitled Therapeutic Goods, subtitled A Review of the Therapeutic Goods Evaluation and Testing Program; in paragraphs 7.20 to 7.23, refers to charges being performance-related, not merely income generating; that fees should be fair; that under no circumstances should there be cross-subsidisation by one category of goods in respect of another; and that fees for the inclusion of goods already on the market should not be substantial. The major burden of the fees as proposed-which are considerably higher than those in other countries, such as the United Kingdom-will fall most heavily on the Australian manufacturing industry. For example, the Australian Medical Devices and Diagnostics Association cites United Kingdom manufacturers' licences which amount to one thousand pounds sterling initially, with renewals half of that amount, compared with the Australian proposal to charge up to $8,300 each year for similar licensing and $13,000 for full evaluation of a therapeutic device.

The imposition of a high level of fees can be expected to decrease international competitiveness at the very time when national interest demands all possible support for Australian manufacturing industry and its export potential. The proposed fees could, therefore, negate existing government sponsored initiatives to encourage the therapeutic goods industry to expand its research and development and export activities. For example, Austrade is currently heavily involved in the promotion of the medical devices industry, but the small new companies being supported in this way could be driven out of business by the fees set under this legislation.

If fees are to be charged, an incentive to export could be achieved by granting exemption from the manufacturing licence and annual registration fees to manufacturers exporting a significant prescribed quantity of their annual output, for example, more than 20 per cent. There is also a view within the industry that there should be a range of differential fees based on the degree of evaluation required for particular goods and the size or quality of particular types of inspections. For example, the United Kingdom system of fees based on whether an inspection is minor, standard or major. The industry believes that the frequency of inspection should be clearly stated and that the United Kingdom scheme-where no charge is applied for inspectors' informal visits to discuss plans or follow up suspected defective products-should be adopted.

A further concern relates to the role of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and its standards for the uniform scheduling of drugs and poisons. The NHMRC is an unofficial organisation which exists pursuant to an Order in Council. Over the years the NHMRC, through its subcommittees, has made a number of recommendations which have had major impacts on the therapeutic goods industry, yet it is not accountable and is unrepresentative of the industry's interests. While the NHMRC is not mentioned in the legislation itself, the explanatory memorandum to the Therapeutic Goods Bill does refer to it, and the adoption of its standard for the uniform scheduling of drugs and poisons. Also, the regulations to the legislation define the `poison standard' as the `current edition of the standards for the uniform scheduling of poisons and drugs'.

The industry argues that giving the NHMRC the power to determine the poisons standard has serious implications in view of its track record in relation to matters affecting the therapeutic goods industry. For such reason the industry believes that responsibility for the standard should be passed to a new committee which is both accountable within the framework of the Bill, and representative of the therapeutic goods industry. Furthermore, in view of the technical nature of matters arising from a request for a review of a decision on a product, the industry does not believe that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is the appropriate body to hear such appeals and would prefer to have such issues resolved by a body consisting of industry representatives.

While, in principle, the legislation offers some advantage in relation to uniformity of scheduling and regulatory controls, nevertheless, there are significant areas of concern about the way in which the Hawke Government is seeking to achieve these objectives. As I have already said, there are widespread concerns about the negative impact these Bills will have on the therapeutic goods industry, particularly in relation to the expansion of export activity and the innovation of new products. The Business Regulation Review Unit found that there are many areas where regulation generates unnecessarily high costs. This view supports our own, which is reflected in our intention to reduce the burden of business regulation generally.

There appears to be insufficient evidence that the proposed intensification of controls is warranted, and a widely held view that the charging proposals are excessive. There are no guarantees that the Government or the Department will not see the fees as a handy source of extra revenue to step up charges on a regular basis, conduct more inspections to generate additional funds or impose fees for initially free services such as the provision to sponsors of information on their register entry. There is also no evidence that the implementation of these charges will produce significant improvements in the operation of the therapeutic goods program. It is for these reasons that the Opposition is proposing the amendment to the second reading of this Bill-which I have already moved-to refer this Bill to a Senate select committee. That second reading amendment states, in part, as follows:

. . . the Senate, while supporting the principle of uniform federal regulation of the manufacture of therapeutic goods in Australia, considers that the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989 are deficient in a number of respects and consequently resolves that the Bills be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for inquiry and report, by the first sitting day in March 1990 . . .

A range of matters is then set out in the motion. I have to take a few more minutes to detail one or two of the other criticisms of the Bill. I understand that at the expiry of my time I will be allowed to finish those matters. I will make a very brief comment in appreciation of the courtesy extended by the Senate on its account which arises from my having to discuss two quite separate Bills cognately.

The areas which have been drawn to our attention and to which I wish to draw the Senate's attention include the following: representations from the Australian Association of Professional Homeopaths draw attention to the fact that lack of regulations for examination means that the Government's intentions are not available for widespread scrutiny. The representations received from organisations such as the Victorian Herbalists Association Inc. make the same point and make the point which Senator Coulter made in his remarks that the NHMRC and the more established bodies within the profession may not have the same sort of attitude towards non-mainstream remedies as is the case with more traditional therapeutic goods. The representation from the Nutritional Foods Association of Australia makes precisely the same point that a view is likely to be taken which does not comprehend the sort of important service which it is providing. The Australian Dental Industry Association Inc. makes the point that within the guidelines being operated upon at the moment entitled `The Instructions for Therapeutic Goods Regulation' there is a proposal for dental instruments, devices and materials to be brought within the provisions of this legislation. This point is similarly made by the Australian Dental Association which draws attention to the fact that the Industries Assistance Commission Report No. 402 of April 1987 entitled `Medical and Scientific Equipment: Measuring, professional and scientific equipment. Appliances and parts, and medical, dental, and veterinary equipment' suggests at page 52 that such items should not be included and the Government is moving in the contrary direction as far as that area is concerned. Representations from The Australian Medical Devices and Diagnostic Association Inc. point out that in the United Kingdom, the Medicines Control Agency plays a role which is a far more acceptable one to the industry than the regime proposed for Australia. (Extension of time granted) That Association makes the point that this matter should be referred to a committee and should be evaluated to take account, in particular, of the way in which this system operates in the United Kingdom. Furthermore it says such an inquiry should take account of the export potential in this area. In a letter to the shadow Minister for health, Mr Shack, Mr Sutherland, on behalf of the Australian Medical Devices and Diagnostic Association Inc., said:
Further, I point out the burden which would fall upon the small, high technology companies which form the backbone of the medical devices and diagnostic industry . . .

Here, he is making a valid comment about the potential charges which might be levied on the industry. The 1988-89 annual report of Australiatrade on page 41, under the heading `Medical and scientific equipment', stated:

The Medical and Scientific Equipment Strategy, launched by Senator Button in October 1988, established an export target of $735 million in 1991-92, almost doubling the 1987-88 exports of $398 million. Exports in 1988-89 are estimated at $460 million.
Australia is well placed to take advantage of the 15 per cent annual growth in the world market.

That is absolutely true and the target is likely to be set at some considerable peril by the way in which the Government has proceeded in this matter. I also draw attention to the fact that groups such as the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association have expressed concerns about the additional cost which will be imposed. A news release put out by that Association on 15 August stated:

The announcement of new initiatives to accelerate new drug approvals and improve oversight of pharmaceuticals has failed to demonstrate how the Department of Community Services and Health will achieve these desirable goals . . .

That Association is very critical of the way in which the Government has proceeded in this matter. In a letter to me dated 17 November, John Pentecost, the Chief Executive Officer of the Proprietary Association of Australia Incorporated, stated:

While we recognise that the Bill itself embodies basic and rational principles which Industry supports, we point out that the implementation mechanisms will be provided and controlled through the accompanying Regulations, yet to be presented to the House. The Bill itself cannot therefore be meaningfully considered without the accompanying Regulations.
I endorse entirely those points.

In my concluding comments I draw attention to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its eighteenth report of 22 November 1989 in which it found the Bill deficient in respect to the matter of prescribed codes of goods manufacturing process. It argues that the Minister should not be allowed simply to publish orders in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette; rather, that should be done by regulation. On page 5 of the report the Committee stated:

The Committee . . . is of the opinion that to have the codes of goods manufacturing practice incorporated in regulations would not affect the flexibility of the system or the ability of the Orders to be altered in a timely fashion.

The Committee suggests that that is the proper way in which this legislation should proceed rather than the way which is currently proposed by the Labor Government. In relation to the Therapeutic Goods Charges Bill the Committee stated:

The Committee notes the matters raised by the Minister concerning the level of industry input to the determination of charges. The Committee does not regard it as appropriate that the amount of an annual charge can be fixed by regulation with no upper limit to the charge specified in the bill. The most appropriate means to ensure that the upper limit of a charge is not set by the regulations is to amend the bill to set a maximum level for the relevant charges.

If the Government is genuine about cost recovery up to 50 per cent but not up to 100 per cent, it could easily have put that in the legislation. The Government has not put the matter in the legislation. This leads the Opposition to believe that the Government, having had the matter drawn to its attention by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and having deliberately not proceeded in the recommended fashion, proposes to use this process as an open-ended tax arrangement. It is not the responsibility of the Opposition to draw that amendment. However, it is our responsibility to draw attention to the potential for misuse. It is for that additional reason that the reference to the Senate Committee has been proposed and is so necessary. This is yet another of those matters which need to be subject to detailed and close examination. We believe that the only way to do that effectively is by reference to the Senate Committee. We have therefore embarked on that course of action. If we are unsuccessful I indicate that the Opposition will be voting against this package of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a group of Bills-the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989. The first Bill has little relation to the other two Bills, which deal with therapeutic goods. My colleague Senator Boswell discussed the question of a residents' Bill of Rights. I will not address that matter. I will address my remarks particularly to the proposal for a national system of registration of therapeutic goods in Australia. I want to make just two points. First, the concept of a national register of therapeutic goods was promoted in 1981 by the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare in its report to the Senate entitled `Another side to the drug debate . . . a medicated society?'. I note that very few members of that Senate Committee remain in the Senate. Nevertheless, it was a report to the Senate under the chairmanship of Senator Shirley Walters.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I want to make is that there are sufficient grounds for uncertainty to support the Opposition's view that the proposal should go to a Senate standing committee for examination and report. I turn first to the 1981 report of the Senate Standing Committee: one finds in that report at page 61 the recommendation most relevant to this Bill. That recommendation reads:
. . . the Committee recommends that the national registration scheme be instituted as soon as practicable.

That was the recommendation made by the Committee to the Senate in 1981-that a national registration scheme for drugs be instituted as soon as practicable. The Committee reached that conclusion by a series of quite logical steps. It was aware that there was and still is no national system of registering therapeutic goods and no system of ensuring that they comply with minimum standards of purity and safety. I interpolate that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) mechanism, admirable as it is, picks up only some therapeutic goods. There is no system at present for ensuring that the manufacture of all therapeutic goods requires adherence to certain minimum acceptable standards.

What existed at the time the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare was doing its work was a system in Victoria which was really only a system for drugs that escaped the ADEC net. That system is described at page 57 of the Senate Committee report under the heading, `The Victorian registration system'. Under that system, which was introduced in 1948, proprietary medicines had to be registered in Victoria before they could be advertised or sold in that State. In the absence of any other registration scheme, the Victorian system has been important in Australia, especially considering the small size of our national market and, therefore, the natural desire of manufacturers to be able to include Victoria within their marketing. Although a system has been operating in only one State, it has, in effect, been one that has been followed by manufacturers.

The one reason that the Victorian scheme was so important was that it enabled the scrutiny of drugs manufactured locally from local raw materials. Had they not been manufactured locally or had the raw materials not been local, then the substances would have been picked up under the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee mechanism. This meant that any drugs or therapeutic goods which were manufactured locally from local materials which were not sold in Victoria, which were not intended to be sold in Victoria, and which, therefore, were not required for sale in Victoria could escape any scrutiny at all. I should declare an interest here. I was at one time a member of the National Therapeutic Goods Advisory Committee, so I have an interest in what was proposed then and in what has transpired since.

My concerns about drugs include safety, predictable manufacturing quality, predictable biological effect and so on. It is the consumers of drugs whose rights are put at risk if there exists no system of registration or no system to require or enforce proper standards of manufacture and performance. I do not believe that we have adequate standards up to this time. We have had a couple of quite unsavoury episodes in this country in the last five years, if not on this precise point then on a point close enough to bring home to us the dangers to consumers of a system which is not adequate.

The Victorian system was clearly unable to meet even its own objectives when the Senate Committee examined it earlier this decade. I was a member of that Senate Committee until I became a Minister, at which stage Senator Shirley Walters became the Chair of the Committee. We discovered from the Victorians that there were staff shortages; that there were no inspectorial staff; that information storage and retrieval was done manually; that there were inadequate evaluation resources; and that information was not shared adequately between different levels of government.

Because of concerns like those, consideration was given, as long ago as 1970, to the establishment of a national registration scheme and of a national register. But it appears that even if we had taken the scheme that existed, the Victorian scheme, and the ADEC and said, `What can we do to improve those?', it was the view of the Senate Committee in 1981 that even reform of improvement of the existing scheme would not have overcome its shortcomings.

Secondly, I remember that in 1970 the National Therapeutic Goods Advisory Committee put forward a suggestion to the Australian Health Ministers Conference for a national registration scheme. That was back as far as 1970. Thirdly, I remind the Senate that in 1986 at the Australian Health Ministers Conference it was agreed that a national registration scheme and its concomitant products register should be established. The Federal government of the day rejected that proposal later following objections from all sections of industry. The government of the day rejected the proposal even though all the State government authorities strongly supported implementation of the system. Nevertheless, in spite of the view of the Federal Government, the Senate Committee, supported by State governments, recommended unanimously in 1981 that a national registration scheme be instituted as soon as possible.

It is proposed that new products particularly should be made subject to the provisions of the scheme. But industry is still concerned, not unreasonably, about the equity of the charges. My colleague Senator Puplick has referred to these and I will not go over the points he made. Industry is concerned particularly about continuing charges where there may be no continuing service given. There is a point to be considered. Industry argues, I think reasonably, that the Victorian scheme should cease to operate on the day that the national scheme begins, so that there is at each stage a single set of regulations to which people must work. There is nothing in this Bill or in the statements that have been made by the Minister that gives us any reason to expect that the Victorian scheme will cease to operate at that point; and it should. It is all very well for those of us who receive our salaries as parliamentarians or who work in salaried positions. It is quite a different matter if one is manufacturing a product and trying to understand the codes to which one is working, to understand the regulations by which one is bound, and to realise that one is in a transitional period. We expect and demand that the Victorian scheme shall cease on the very day the national scheme begins, but we have no guarantee yet that that will happen.

In spite of the self-interest which drives many industry representations-and I am not saying that that is improper; self-interest is quite helpful here, self-interest which, however, may overwhelm public interest on some occasions-there may be considerable substance to some of the concerns which industry has put to us. Further, there have been other inputs of significance as well. My colleague Senator Puplick has referred to some of these. The Business Regulation Review Unit has had some input. Senator Puplick has pointed out the statements made by that unit in its information paper No. 13 of March 1989 on therapeutic goods regulation in which it expressed some quite serious concerns about the course the Government proposes to take and about the regulation which is involved.

Again, Senator Puplick has drawn attention to significant input, that is, input from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which had some input into this area in 1988. Its report No. 295, entitled Therapeutic Goods: A Review of the Therapeutic Goods Evaluation and Testing Program, made some quite significant criticisms and laid down some standards by which we should be operating. Although they have been referred to by Senator Puplick, I will mention them again. The Public Accounts Committee said that charges should be performance related, not merely income generating. We have no guarantee from the Government that that is what is proposed. The Public Accounts Committee determined and reported that fees should be fair. Industry does not believe that they are fair; the Government must justify them. The Public Accounts Committee recommended that under no circumstances should there be cross-subsidisation by one category of goods in respect of another. We have no guarantee that that is the current situation. Finally, the Public Accounts Committee reported that fees for inclusion of goods already on the market should not be substantial. These are significant criticisms by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. We do not prejudge this matter, but we do want to get it right. I have indicated already that the Committee on which I serve is a strong supporter of the establishment of a national register; but we do not want a bad register, we want one that is right.

The Senate has already discussed the principle of referring Bills to committees for examination and report. We have already passed certain motions in the Senate so that from the beginning of 1990 that will be happening more and more. The Senate has accepted the principle of the reference of Bills to committees and, as I say, has now gone some way towards giving effect to measures to have reference of Bills to committees for detailed examination become more frequent. The Senate has referred Bills to committees often in the past, generally with benefit to the Bills, benefit to the Senate and benefit to the country.

It is important that we do not lose sight of the time frame within which we must work. On the one hand, Senator Coulter has mentioned to us that he thinks the time frame is urgent because he believes that there may be an election coming. Senator Coulter may be right on this matter. On the other hand, however, the scheme which we are considering for a national register has been germinating for a long time. It is actually worth getting it right before we put it in place. It is worth ironing out the wrinkles now, not asking us to pass something and hope that we can get it right later. A committee reference is an appropriate way to go about doing this. I serve on the committee to which reference is proposed. That committee actually has fixed up two matters for the Government in the past year, and we can fix this one up as well.

I remind the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), first, that there was the question of the allocation of licences for fishing for southern bluefin tuna. Honourable senators may say that that is a small matter; it was not a small matter for the southern bluefin tuna fisherman. My cousin, Senator Michael Baume, is in the chamber. He will remember that on the south coast of New South Wales it was a major problem, but the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology was able to get an answer which was acceptable to government and the industry and that matter was fixed; it was a negotiated solution. Second, there was an inquiry concerned with the Government proposal to deregulate the sugar industry. I remind the Minister that that is a matter of some importance to her State. It was proposed that we should deregulate the sugar industry and allow the importation of sugar, ending a 70-year-old embargo-a matter of great political sensitivity and a matter which caused a lot of fear in the industry. After consulting across the industry the Senate Committee was able to make suggestions to government which were adopted, so far with success, so far without any pain to the industry. Again, change had been implemented without any of the detriment to the industry which we had been led to expect might occur.

The Senate Committee has a record of taking references like this, in completing them, and making a success of them. I think that the Senate Committee could make a good job of examining this proposal for a register of therapeutic goods. The Committee could work expeditiously, and we could have the task done by the reporting time set out in Senator Puplick's motion. It would involve a bit of hurry up, but that is all right; it would be well worth the effort. If the Senate is serious about submitting legislation to Senate committees for examination, then this is one appropriate piece of legislation for such examination.

It will be apparent from the history of the matter that I and my Party are not ipso facto opposed to the proposal that the Government has brought forward. Members of the Liberal Party were on the committee which supported the principle back in 1981. The history of that earlier Senate committee work makes it crystal clear that we are not opposed ipso facto, but we do want to get it right. We do want to discover and correct any wrinkles or faults. We want to respond to the concerns of industry which have come in now, as my colleague Senator Puplick has said, from a number of organisations, most of whose members have spoken to me as well. I do not want to accept or reject their concerns, I do not want to accept or reject the bland assertions of government at this stage. I want to hear from those who will have to live with the legislation. I want to hear from those whose lives, livelihoods and businesses it will affect. I want to hear from those members of the public who think they have an interest. As it has done before, the Senate Committee can then fix the matter up. This is what such references are all about. This is why we can do it in this case. It is to be hoped that the Senate will agree to the reference. It follows that I am speaking to support very strongly the amendment which has been moved by my colleague Senator Puplick to the motion for the second reading and to indicate that I will support also the course of action which he has proposed for this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on only one aspect of two of the Bills before us-that is, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Therapeutic Goods Bills-as they have affected directly constituents of mine in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn, first of all, to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Clause 31 of this Bill inserts a new section which will empower the Minister to formulate a statement of the rights and responsibilities to be enjoyed and met by residents of approved nursing homes. Such a charter for residents of nursing homes is indeed needed. We had access to a draft charter in a report recently tabled in the Senate entitled A Guide to Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels. The charter here had 20 components, all of which are admirable.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the first two of these clauses-first, that residents in nursing homes should have the right to be treated and accepted as an individual by those in the same facility and, secondly, that they should have the right to maintain personal independence, personal choice and personal responsibility for all actions, including a recognition that some actions may involve an element of risk which the resident accepts, and which should not be used to prevent or restrict those actions. In short, the charter in this particular report lays down the rights of residents in nursing homes to dignity, proper care and attention.

Recently in Western Australia some nursing homes have been under investigation because of the complaints that have been made. It has been shown that these nursing homes did not have the best interests of their residents at heart in some of their activities. I will not detail the complaints here in the Senate; they have been detailed widely in the press in Western Australia. In short, the main complaints were of over-sedation , patients not being involved correctly with decision making on their behalf, and not being given dignity or being treated with the kindness and care that they deserved. In addition, there have been some atrocious cases of the most appalling neglect.

The point I would particularly like to raise in the Senate today is that when staff in those nursing homes made complaints they were dismissed in some cases and then placed on a black list; that is, they were unable to obtain employment in the nursing home industry afterwards. I drew this matter to the attention of the Senate recently in an adjournment speech. Through that speech, I also drew the matter to the attention of the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett. I commend Dr Blewett for addressing that issue. In a response, he stated:

The Government believes the majority of nursing home owners, care managers and staff provide the best possible qualify of life for residents. However, the Government wishes to ensure that all elderly people enjoy the best possible quality of life and has embarked on a vigorous campaign of dealing with these homes which persistently and seriously undermine the qualify of life for their residents.
He went on to say:

I am most concerned at Senator Jenkins' report of the blacklisting of the staff member who chose to speak out about the abuse and neglect occurring in nursing homes. The Department of Community Services and Health and, I am sure, State government bodies offer confidential investigation of complaints to avoid the unfortunate scapegoating of those who speak out.
