I call on the nursing home associations in Western Australia to come clean on the allegations that this staff member has been passed over for employment because she blew the whistle on what has been proven to be a scandalous situation.

That matter is currently being addressed. It is essential that it is properly addressed. If residents in nursing homes are not being treated properly and if a staff member working in one of those homes chooses to speak out, it is essential that that person is not blacklisted in this way. What is more likely to happen-and what I believe has happened on a number of occasions-is that a person, especially a breadwinner, will be afraid to speak out. So the charter is needed.

The Australian Democrats question whether it is adequate for the charter to be drawn up by the Minister alone. We would certainly prefer the charter to be debated in the Parliament and, if necessary, adjusted by the Parliament. There needs to be a full public debate, including an input by our electors, by residents in nursing homes, their relatives, friends and trusted advocates and by people in the nursing home industry. This is too important a matter to be subject to a list of regulations which would no doubt be drawn up by bureaucrats in the Minister's Department-well-meaning bureaucrats, I am sure, who could not have access to the responses that we in the Parliament can have access to.

The problem with having such a charter set into regulations would be that it would come into law immediately the regulations were tabled-that is, before public and open scrutiny had taken place. The regulations, like all regulations, could only be allowed or disallowed, so no adjustment to them is possible. There are obvious problems in disallowing regulations which have already come into law. As I said before, it would not be possible to have a full scrutiny of all the developmental stages of the regulations. In short, the Australian Democrats are in full support of the charter but we believe that it must be set up properly and openly. Therefore, we will be supporting the Opposition's amendments in that regard.

The second aspect of this legislative package which I wish to address is therapeutic goods with particular regard to the registration of therapeutic agents and National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) decisions. It is a well-known fact that drugs have different effects of varying degrees on different people. One man's meat can well be another man's poison in this regard and this has been shown to be so. It is all the more important, therefore, that adverse reactions be tabled and examined. It is also important that this be mandatory. Unfortunately, as I understand it, unless a special case is made, this is definitely not the case at present.

I have raised before in this place the issue of the drug Depo-Medrol, which is the brand name of methylprednisolone acetate sterile aqueous suspension. This drug is administered mostly into the joints of muscles and adverse reactions which some patients have endured have been listed in the pharmacopoeia of information put out by drug companies. The pharmacopoeia shows that Depo-Medrol is normally administered into joints, specifically knees, ankles, shoulders, elbows and wrists, and also into muscles. The appropriate dosage is listed and the publication quite clearly states:
Joints not suitable for injection are those that are automatically inaccessible such as the spinal joints and those like the sacroiliac joints that are devoid of synovial space.

Nonetheless, some doctors, as a last resort-and, unfortunately, not always as a last resort-have used the drug epidurally and, in some cases, the results have been disastrous for the people concerned, who have been left very much worse off than they were before. This matter has concerned me greatly as more than 100 people have contacted my office with regard to this matter. I have spoken face to face with some 30 people who have suffered dramatic adverse effects from the administration of Depo-Medrol epidurally. I have written to the manufacturer, Upjohn Pty Ltd. Upjohn wrote back and said that the information given with the product under the heading `Warnings' states:
Depo-Medrol is not recommended for intrathecal administration.
Under the heading `Adverse Reactions' the following comment is made:
Arachnoiditis has been reported following intrathecal administration.
In the same letter, the Managing Director of Upjohn states:

We do not include epi- or extra-dural administration as a recommended route of administration in our product information . . . We have no plans at this time to apply for registration of epi- or extra-dural administration because to do so would require the design and conduct of expensive clinical trials.

That letter was dated 27 October 1987. As a result of the matters that I brought forward with regard to some of the results of the administration of the drug Depo-Medrol by the epidural route, the Western Australian Minister for Health, Mr Keith Wilson, and the State Commissioner for Health, Dr Bruce Armstrong, have proposed and, in fact, have set out the following actions:

A letter is to be sent by the Health Department to all registered medical practitioners in Western Australia outlining the facts regarding epidural use of Depo-Medrol and drawing attention, specifically, to the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee's decision and the manufacturer's recommendation regarding use.
It will highlight the need for provision of information to enable patients to make an informed decision in regard to the use of epidural Depo-Medrol.

The National Health and Medical Research Council is being requested to sponsor a controlled clinical test of the efficacy of epidural Depo-Medrol. The Federal Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett has also been requested to support the study.
Relevant professional groups are to be asked to develop a protocol for the administration of Depo-Medrol as an interim measure until such time as the issue is fully resolved.
An independent investigation is to be undertaken of cases of reported adverse effects of Depo-Medrol use that have been brought to the Health Department's attention.

As I understand it, the committee investigating the adverse effects is now up and running; it is already taking evidence. I have used this particular case as an example of what I believe should be done in cases where there is any possibility of adverse reactions by patients to the particular use of a particular drug. I certainly commend the Western Australian Minister for Health and the Western Australian Health Commissioner for having taken these steps. Matters such as these are crucially important with regard to the registration of therapeutic agents and to decisions made by the NHMRC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a trilogy of Bills in a cognate debate, the first of which is not related to the second two. The first Bill, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, covers several areas and two portfolios. The other Bills being discussed are the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first read these Bills I was reminded of the story of the young chap who was working in a pram factory in Germany before the Second World War. He met a nice young girl one day and they got on very well. They got married and in due course were going to have a baby. He thought it would be very nice to give his wife a present of a pram so he went to the front of the factory and asked whether he could buy a pram. He was told that there was no way of buying a pram there. He thought about it and at the end of every day's work he took home a part that was manufactured in each section of the factory. When he had all the parts he assembled them in his lounge room. When he put them together he found that he did not have a pram at all; he had a machine gun. That shows that somebody knew what was going on, although he did not.

The Government has presented many of its recent Bills in a way that is quite attractive, with aims, objects and principles with which nobody could really disagree, but when it comes to the machinery by which the Bills are to be administered we are being asked to buy a pig in a poke. There have been many problems in this respect. I cite, for example, the introduction of the vocational register for general practitioners. The regulations for that had to be referred to a committee and brought back to the Senate for approval. The legislation by which the Government is dismantling disability services is creating consternation in the industry, mainly because people do not know what is going on. The same applies to the legislation with respect to therapeutic goods.

Nobody could argue with the principles on which the Government is operating to bring in the therapeutic goods legislation, but we do not know the means by which it is to be administered. That is why there is so much consternation in that industry. The position is similar with respect to nursing homes. We need to examine the machinery by which the Bill is to be administered. Part 5 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) deals with the health aspects of the legislation and there are nine elements in it, most of which are purely machinery matters, but two of which are of particular concern. One is the new definition of a proprietor of a pathology services clinic. The Opposition wants to know what the Government wants to achieve by having one person responsible for the provision of those services, for the staffing and the provision of equipment. We would like that clarified. Perhaps that has been clarified since I first read the Bill; if so, I have not heard of it. The other element concerns the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which has been discussed this morning, and I will not repeat the debate.

In recent years, the administration of health in Australia has been dismantled. Medicare, for example, has been hived off. In order to qualify for Medicare benefits, one must be actually sick. Medicare does not deal with, say, preventive medicine in any way. Preventive care has been hived off to the Better Health Commission, Worksafe Australia and such institutions. Quarantine, which was originally the only responsibility of the Federal Government, is not part of Medicare. Medicare itself has become a much more restricted service and is becoming more restricted as we go on. Nursing care for the aged has also been hived off. Care for the disabled, hostels and domiciliary care have been compartmentalised so that we have a different organisation from that which we had previously.

If a business makes some error in administration, only the people in that business are badly affected, but if a government makes some major administrative blunder the whole community is affected. For example, in past years the flow of patients was from their own homes into nursing homes, hostels or institutions for the disabled and then to hospitals. That was the way the funding was organised. The care of people in their own homes was recognised as being a low cost operation and the care of people in hospitals as a high cost operation. The Government is now reversing the flow of patients; it is getting people out of hospitals into nursing homes and hostels and then out of those institutions back into their own homes. It has taken the Government quite a while to realise that that is the right way to go. I am rather pleased that it has at last found out that it is the right way to go.

When I was a young doctor there were not the big nursing home institutions that we have today. Nursing homes were places where two or three nursing sisters got together, bought an old, rambling house, and looked after upwards of a dozen people in it. It was a most congenial arrangement because the residents were near relatives and friends, visiting was easy and parking was easy. Their children could visit and grandchildren could call in after school. They could be taken for drives if they were well enough. They could be taken to church and taken shopping. There was a good relationship between those little nursing homes and the service clubs in the area, like Lions and Rotary, and it did not even seem to matter much what was wrong with the patients. Most older people suffer from arthritis, strokes or cancer, and they just have to be looked after. They are very happy if they are looked after, nursed properly and fed properly.

The Government then came along and said, `We are here to help you'. That structure was dismantled. The first thing the Government did was declare such nursing homes to be fire traps. To my knowledge, there has never been a fire in one of those little homes in Australia. I do not think there has been a fire in a private nursing home in Australia. It is only in the government-funded nursing homes that there have been fires. Nevertheless, all the little nursing homes were closed down and the bigger institutions came into being and were subsidised by government. All kinds of specialists appeared. Specialist therapists, including speech therapists, physiotherapists and nursing aids appeared. A whole industry grew up simply because of the way in which the Government was funding nursing care. People felt as if they were neglecting their patients if they did not put them in these institutions where they could have so-called proper treatment and expert care.

The Government has now realised the error of its ways and is using financial coercion to reverse the flow of people simply because the policies followed by successive governments, not just the Labor Government, resulted in many inappropriate admissions to nursing homes. Many of the people who qualified for care in nursing homes should not have been in nursing homes, but the hospitals were anxious to get rid of their extended stay patients by putting them in nursing homes. The nursing homes wanted to increase their turnover and they had to get people into hostels and back into their own homes. So although the Government is now following the right program, it did not properly consult the industry. Here are all these people who thought that they were doing the right thing. The nursing homes had been inspected, licensed and audited and had every other kind of infiltration, I suppose one would call it, by the Government into their business and the patients' business, and now they are being virtually dismantled, the patients are being put back into their own homes and the Government is going to concentrate on providing adequate care at home. That is the right track, but what I complain about is the lack of consultation with the industry.

The Government is not prepared simply to let go of the whole thing. It is introducing agreements, charters and contracts which have been virtually kept secret from the people who are going to have to operate the businesses. Presumably, the content of the agreements, charters and contracts is to be left in the hands of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). The Opposition wants these instruments laid before both Houses of the Parliament so that they can be amended if necessary. It may not be necessary to amend them, but it is only right that the Parliament and the people should have access to instruments that are going to be the nuts and bolts of the administration of the nursing homes themselves.

Also contained in the legislation is the provision of inspectors and bovver boys who will be going around the nursing homes with access to all the staff and patients, be able to command the production of document and look at all the equipment. Nobody argues that somebody has to do this, but the Government has not defined in any precise way at all what all these different inspectors and monitors are going to be doing. For example, I always thought that community visitors were the friend of the friendless in nursing homes. A community visitor could be allocated to go and see people who required a friend and perhaps get them out of their problem. But it now appears that a community visitor will have equal authority with all the other monitors and inspectors who will be introduced for the administration of nursing homes. The Opposition wishes to have some clarification of just what is involved in that.

I think that one of the major problems with bringing in legislation of this nature is that the Government starts off by having some sort of an inquiry, however inadequate, and usually only with one portion of the industry-in this case the patients-and then brings in legislation that is directed towards rectifying problems in that area but does not pay any attention to the proprietors, operators and staff of nursing homes, who all have rights too.

If patients' rights are brought in-this was dealt with very adequately today by Senator Coulter-patients' rights will vary depending on their testimentary capacity which, in turn, will depend on the illness they have got. That is a lot more complicated area than people think. It is not only patients who have rights, and I think that the neglect to consult with proprietors, operators and staff has led to a lot of the consternation that exists in the industry at the moment. These Government monitoring teams are already in the field inspecting various nursing homes, and grave inconsistencies have been found in their reports. This will be another area which will cause more than a few problems. In addition, the agreements, charters and rights have already been found to interfere with the professional duty of the doctors and nurses who look after patients.

When a situation like that exists where the Government is bringing down an edict to say, `Here are the patients' rights, and this is what has got to happen', one finds that this is an infringement on the professional duty of the profession and there is then a major problem. I think the Government is faced with this problem now and should pay a lot of attention to that. So we are insisting that these charters, agreements and contracts be tabled in both Houses and debated.

I turn to the Therapeutic Goods Bill. I have already mentioned that our objection to that Bill is that, although it is a Bill which nobody can argue with and which everybody supports, it contains no regulations under which people in the industry can operate with some certainty. That was adequately dealt with by Senator Peter Baume. I do not want to repeat all of his arguments. I think it is a simple case where the Government ought to agree that this matter, like all the ones I mentioned, also be sent off for proper examination by a Senate committee. I understand the worry that perhaps there is going to be an election that will interfere with the process but, nevertheless, the Senate has an on going job. The composition of the Senate does not alter until 30 June next year. Whether there is an election or not, a matter of importance such as this where we are wanting to have some degree of certainty about our therahpeutic goods, the quality of the goods, the quality of the advertising, and the coordination of the role of the States and the Federal Government in the administration of those matters should be attended to by the Senate. It is for those reasons that I support the position that has been put today by honourable senators from the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly today on just one of the package of three Bills that we are debating cognately, namely, the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989, and I speak in strong support of the second reading amendment moved by my colleague Senator Puplick, on behalf of the Opposition, which essentially requires that the Senate refer the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in March 1990 on a wide range of the technical issues which, although technical issues, have very important implications in relation to the Government's proposals. I make the basic purpose of the legislation clear at the outset, as other speakers on the Opposition side have done, including the shadow Minister for Health, Mr Peter Shack, in the House of Representatives when this Bill was debated on 26 October, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: In principle, both the Opposition and the therapeutic goods industry support the broad objectives of the Therapeutic Goods Bill. There are a number of obvious advantages to the community and the therapeutic goods industry in having a unified system of controls over therapeutic products and their advertising. There is no argument about the value of ensuring the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods and the need to protect the public interest in this regard.

Of course, the basic purpose of this legislation is to establish and maintain a national system of controls relating to the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods for export and for consumption within Australia. There are a number of reasons why we believe that this Bill, whilst we are supportive of it in principle, should be referred for detailed examination to an appropriate committee, and in this case we recommend the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. We share a range of concerns expressed by the industry in relation to the Bills-the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989-and, very importantly, in relation to the regulations which underpin the Therapeutic Goods Bill. The content of the Bill is very much a motherhood type of statement. It is a very general Bill. The real essence of the substance of the Bill is to be contained in the regulations. As I understand it, some draft regulations have been prepared but at the same time many proposed changes have been foreshadowed to those draft regulations following consultation with industry-but, I stress, inadequate consultation in the eyes of the industry.

It is a very wide-ranging industry. The Bill covers a huge variety of goods. One estimate is that up to 40,000 products are covered by this Bill, and that is probably a conservative estimate. The Australian Dental Association, for example, in representations to me-because it is concerned that all dental products will be encompassed by the Bill-made the point that in that industry alone there are about 30,000 separate products. So the range of products that is to be caught by the Bill as a whole, when one considers the full definition of therapeutic goods, is enormous.

It is understandable in some ways, therefore, that the consultations with the therapeutic goods industries and manufacturers of the products that have been caught by the Bill have been less than adequate, certainly in the eyes of the industry. From the representations that I and, I know, many of my colleagues have received, I would certainly support the view that those consultations have been inadequate. It is a basic problem, if this Parliament is to debate legislation which has a great impact throughout the community, not just on the consumers but also on the manufacturers of therapeutic goods, and particularly when we see this industry as having considerable potential for export, that the regulations, rather than the substance of the Bill that we are now debating, will determine the success or otherwise of the proposals.

At least one of the major advantages of having these matters referred for consideration to a parliamentary committee is that-certainly I would have thought it would have to be a requirement-the regulations would be available for debate and consideration by that committee.

So I want to make it clear that we are not opposed to the Bill per se. We support the proposition in principle, but we believe that it is such an important Bill that if we take the extra time to get it right-and the time that has not yet been granted-the advantages in the long term will make up for any temporary delay in implementing the Bill. The Opposition amendment puts a time limit on the committee of the first sitting day in March 1990 to report on it.

Whilst there are agreements from many quarters about the desirability of having a national system for therapeutic goods controls, it is not universal. As I understand it, in my own State of Victoria, the Victorian Government has indicated its intention to retain its own registration system, at least until well into 1990. That in itself raises very important questions about the prospect of duplication, overlapping and outright confusion arising from a situation where one may have two systems, State and Federal, operating for the same industry at the one time. I hope that the Minister, in summing up this debate, and when we get to the committee stage of the debate, will be able to tell us about the Victorian situation and its implications in terms of the timing and the application of the Federal Bill when it is enacted.

Various other issues are of concern. For example, the role of the National Health and Medical Research Council will be very important. But it should be borne in mind that the NHMRC exists pursuant to order-in-Council and, as such, it lacks the accountability that applies to many other organisations, certainly the accountability to Parliament. It is not required to justify its decisions in the same way as are many other government or public bodies. There are few, if any, workable avenues of appeal against its recommendations, yet the recommendations and advisings of the National Health and Medical Research Council will be a very important input into the actual operation of the new proposed controls. So that is another matter that requires considerable investigation and careful consideration by the Parliament.

The whole question of the extent to which the detail of regulation and control proposed in the Bills is necessary also requires consideration. We should never forget the fact that, whilst controls may be desirable for certain reasons, they always have a cost. The regulatory burden imposed on business in Australia-not just through this Bill but through the whole gamut of regulation that we have progressively applied to industry, business and commercial activity in Australia over many years-is one of the major reasons, I believe, why business is struggling in Australia to be competitive and productive in the way that we all want it to be.

The Industries Assistance Commission inquiry in 1987 into medical and scientific equipment raised considerable questions about the desirability of the proposals that are now in this Bill so far as the principle is concerned. It pointed very much to the question of the costs involved in a national system of regulation and control along the lines of that now being envisaged, as did the Business Regulation Review Unit earlier this year. So important government bodies have expressed concern about the cost elements involved in proposals of the nature now envisaged in the Therapeutic Goods Bill. I hope that an investigation by an appropriate parliamentary committee into the Bill and its details will take that into account as well.

I do not think we ought to be taking it for granted that all the regulations and regulatory measures proposed in the Bill, and presumably in the regulations as will be drafted and promulgated, should be taken as necessary without careful consideration by the Parliament. It is about time that we started looking at reducing the amount of regulation and control over industry and productive activity in Australia and not increasing it, unless there are very good reasons for doing so.

The range of representations that I and, I know, many of my colleagues have had on this Bill has been very wide indeed-much wider than one normally gets on legislation of this nature. I have had representations from the Australian Dental Association, the Association of Professional Homeopaths, from the Herbalists Association, certainly of Victoria and, I think, of other States as well and from individual companies engaged in these parts of the therapeutic goods industries or wider-all of which boil down to saying that the Bill is very detailed. To some extent it snuck up on the industry without it being able to encompass the magnitude of the implications, despite the fact that discussions on the matter have been proceeding on and off for a lengthy period-running into years. Because it is so detailed and so broad there are many associations and individual companies, most of which are small businesses, who have found it impossible to catch up with what is proposed. They have had difficulties, despite the fact that they are part of the industry, as also, and I believe understandably, have many members of parliament. It is for these reasons, along with the others I have mentioned, that I believe it is very important indeed that this Bill be referred, as the Opposition is proposing, to a Senate committee for investigation and early report.

The best course of action, I think, is to wait until all of the implications and unanswered objections to this legislation are resolved. That is not going to lead to the creation of any new vacuum. There is an existing system in place and we should not forget that. There are important gaps in it and that is of course why the legislation is being proposed, but it is a system which, whilst not perfect, has persisted for a long time now without any major problems arising. Another few months is not going to hurt at all in that context. On the contrary, it will give the Government more time to get things right, and that is something we would all welcome. Over the last few years we have seen far too much of governments rushing in with hastily and sloppily prepared legislation, without adequate consultation with those people who will be affected by it, whether they be consumers, producers or what have you.

It is one of the major indictments I would have of the activities of the Hawke Government over recent years. The quality of its legislative proposals, when it comes to their drafting and the subsequent necessity to change them in this Parliament because it has got it wrong the first time, has been one of the hallmarks of this Government. Let us give the Government a chance to get it right this time on its own behalf and, more importantly, on behalf of the people who will be affected by the legislation. The extra time spent in doing that will in the long run save time as well as prevent unnecessary upheaval and cost to both the industry and the users of the therapeutic goods.

I very strongly support the amendment proposed by the Opposition that the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989, whilst being supported in principle, be referred for detailed consideration of its underpinning and that we have another look at it early next year, by which stage the Senate standing committee to which it would be referred would have reported back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the general intent of the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 in that its objective is to ensure the quality, safety and effectiveness of therapeutic goods on the Australian market from the point of supply by means of standard national uniform legislation. This Bill is something of a motherhood Bill and I doubt that any responsible person could criticise its broad concept. I am, however, concerned about aspects of its application and implementation. It will apply to the manufacture and supply of a great range of products, including pharmaceutical drugs, dietary supplements, health foods, herbal and homeopathic products and a variety of others.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the Senate can assess the legislation, there are two other necessary components that require examination. Firstly, there are the regulations that are an important component of the Bill's implementation. I understand that in the development of the regulations there have been consultations between departmental officers and representatives of a number of groups to be affected by the Therapeutic Goods Bill, for example, the National Nutritional Foods Association Inc. and the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. I do not know whether the regulations have been completed or whether any member of the Senate has seen them. If they are not completed or available for consideration, I would like to know when they will be available because I believe they are very important. While I have some concern that this legislative proposal should come before us without the supplementary detail of the regulations, I do not perceive that as being the major impediment to the implementation of this legislation.

If a national uniform standard is to apply, there should be no conflicting or additional standards applying at the State or Territory level. I am aware that all departments of health have supported the introduction of a national uniform system, but where are the complementary legislative packages from the States and Territories? It is essential that all States and Territories have complementary legislation ready to be implemented at the same time as a national system is to commence, otherwise there will be an extension of the present problem of having to comply with a range of differing requirements in various States. There could even be the ridiculous situation of having to comply in one State with differing State and national requirements for manufacturing and packaging.

Some States can be sluggish in surrendering aspects of what they deem expressions of States rights; some could be unwilling to discard their own regulations in favour of those of another State. In regard to the latter, I doubt whether anyone here could guarantee that New South Wales would discard its own regulations and guidelines in order to comply with those under which Victoria operates. Operating with a dual system of standards can only increase costs, not once but twice or more, as State changes could be introduced piecemeal. These costs will not be absorbed by the manufacturer or supplier but will be passed on to the consumer. A national uniform system should not be implemented until such time as States and Territories can demonstrate more than goodwill and good intentions. As I stated before, there must be complementary legislation ready to be implemented at the same time as any national system is to commence.

I have only one comment to make on the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989. If there are to be fees and charges, it should be possible to demonstrate some return for these proposed charges. As there are already extended and unacceptable delays in evaluation and approval times for pharmaceutical products, how can the imposition of fees and charges guarantee a reduction in these delays? Part of the current problem is the lack of staff to carry out the evaluation. If the number of applications for evaluation and listing is to be increased greatly, which must be the case when this Bill is applied to the great number of additional products that will come under the definition of `therapeutic', will there be sufficient staff available for appointment even to keep pace with the applications, let alone reduce the processing time?

I question that there will be a demonstrable reduction in evaluation and approval times, but that questioning is minor compared to my prime concern in regard to the possible introduction of a national uniform standard without complementary State and Territory legislation ready to be implemented at the same time. To pass these two items of legislation before the regulations have been drawn up and before there is complementary legislation at the State level can lead only to confusion. It would be disappointing if, for want of a little more time and deliberation, the very sound proposal to introduce national uniform standards for therapeutic goods were to become cumbersome, unsatisfactory and unworkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I support the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989 although at the moment I am not as fully briefed as I might be to deal with the various matters that have been raised in the course of this very interesting second reading debate. As far as the Therapeutic Goods Bill is concerned, in general the Government is trying to achieve a situation where there is in place a clear national strategy, a system of controls relating to the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods that are supplied in Australia, wherever they are produced, or are to be exported from Australia. I believe that this attempt to get such common standards in place has the support of all senators in this chamber, of industry, and particularly of the consumers or users of therapeutic goods. These therapeutic goods are absolutely essential in the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of diseases. Nevertheless, we do not know precisely the range of products available within the Australian community because many products can enter our marketplace without prior recording or scrutiny. We know that they play a major beneficial role in modifying the impacts and outcomes of illnesses and contribute greatly to the quality of life which individuals now enjoy.

SPEECH.PARA: In this situation it has been thought useful to bring this legislation before the chamber after many months of arduous discussion with industry and consumer groups. The reason I am a little hesitant about dealing fully and comprehensively with this Bill is that I learned from Senator Coulter only a short while ago that he wishes to place some amendments before the chamber for its consideration. No doubt that matter could come to the Committee if the Bill passes the second reading stage. That is the prior question. I have undertaken to examine over the lunch break the amendments to be moved by Senator Coulter on behalf of the Australian Democrats in order to ascertain their scope and purpose and whether they are sufficiently compatible with the purpose of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just goes to the question of the reference to the Senate committee.

—Indeed, my instructions are that the Government does not wish this matter to go to a Senate committee. The Government believes that the matter has been the subject of very exhaustive discussions between government, industry and other groups. When one looks at the history of this matter, the very close discussions between the Government and industry as to the regulations which are to be promulgated under this legislation have led to their being nearly finalised, and they have been well known to the industry for some time. In the light of discussions that have already taken place I think letting the matter go to a committee to elucidate any further matters that can be properly put in debate in this chamber is unnecessary.
—Because you and the industry have agreed that the Parliament has no role.

—It is not merely a question of the Government or the industry. These negotiations and discussions, no doubt involving the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, have been taking place over a long period. Now it has all come to the point where this chamber is called upon to make a decision. However, I understand that Senator Coulter wants some indication of the Government's stance in relation to the amendments which he has circulated before he finally makes up his mind whether further discussions are required within a committee of the Senate. That is what will occur over the lunch break.

SPEECH.PARA: It is certainly no disrespect to the Senate to say that this matter has been sufficiently canvassed over many months-virtually years-to allow this chamber to come to a decision. There is certainly no attempt to short-circuit or undermine the usual deliberations and lengthy considerations of these matters which properly constitute the review task of the Senate; but the discussions have taken place, as I say, over a long period and, in our view, this package of therapeutic goods Bills could and should be supported by the chamber. However, I ask that the Therapeutic Goods Bill be put to one side if I complete my further remarks before 12.45 p.m. The other Bill before us is the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. I believe some matters have been raised in the second reading debate which I could deal with now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind you that a Minister has the option of moving that the debate be adjourned until a later hour, in which case the Senate could lift a little early. It is up to the Minister.
—There is always the second reading.
—We are not ready for a division on the second reading of the Therapeutic Goods Bill until we have had some discussions over the lunch break.
—Move that the debate be adjourned.
—I think that would be the best course of action.
—It would save you making a fool of yourself, perhaps.
—Never. I do not think I am on the verge of that. Mr Acting Deputy President, I take your hint from the Chair and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That debate be adjourned and that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 12.38 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) and Westpac Banking Corporation survey of industrial trends for the December quarter 1989. In particular, I draw the attention of the Minister to the findings of the survey: firstly, business expectations have fallen sharply and a slowdown in manufacturing is under way; secondly, not one manufacturer surveyed predicts an improvement in the general business climate; thirdly, manufacturers predict a marked decline in production in the March quarter 1990; fourthly, manufacturing investment is slowing down and investment plans have been revised down markedly; fifthly, employment is expected to decline dramatically over the next three months; and, sixthly, export deliveries will stabilise at low levels. Does the Minister agree that these results presage a serious downturn in the manufacturing sector? Is the anticipated production slump part of this Government's economic strategy? Can he explain how a downturn in manufacturing investment and production, and no anticipated increase in exports, even from low levels, will provide a basis for sustainable recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the CAI-Westpac survey. That survey and others are predicting a slowdown in activity. In so far as the investment part of Senator Chaney's question is concerned, all information available to the Government suggests that investment anticipations are still higher than the Budget projections which, as I recall them, were for a 6 per cent real increase in investment. The figures have come down from a very abnormal high to something in the order of 9 or 10 per cent real anticipated increase in investment.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the slowing of the economy is concerned, the Government does not see that there is any evidence available which suggests strongly that the economy is heading for a crash landing-if I can put it in those terms-as distinct from a softer landing. The September quarter national accounts show that the economy slowed in that quarter broadly in line with Budget anticipations. As I have said, the anticipations in respect of investment are still quite buoyant compared with what they have been historically. The latest labour force statistics show continued strength in employment but, as I said to the Senate the other day, that figure has always lagged behind other aspects of business activity and I do not think too high a reliance can be placed on that. The Government's strategy has been designed to reduce demand from unsustainable levels and various arms of policy have been tightened for that purpose. In so far as export anticipations are concerned, the Government believes that export activity will improve as domestic demand slackens. While the CAI survey might suggest a degree of gloom about that, the Government believes that that will nonetheless happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note the Minister's fairly optimistic response to the rather gloomy report put out by the CAI and Westpac and his reliance in the earlier part of his answer on the investment figures. Is the Minister concerned that the same report suggests that capital expenditure during 1989 was to replace existing capacity-61 per cent of respondents said that the capital investment about which the Minister is so pleased, as I am, was merely to replace existing capacity-and that this trend would continue in the next 12 months? Is the Minister concerned that this means that there is not as much new capacity being brought on stream as the raw figures might have indicated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even before the survey referred to in Senator Chaney's question, the issue of whether investment is being directed to new capacity or replacement capacity has been a difficult one to gauge. There have been many different views about that. In the CAI-Westpac survey, 38 per cent of firms said that their investment plans would be aimed principally at adding new capacity. As I recall it, 62 per cent of firms said that their investment would be to replace current capacity. Even though the effect of that is not nearly as significant as investment for new capacity, it does have an effect on the overall efficiency of the economy and of firms.
—Not necessarily on the balance of payments.

—No, but a current machine replaced by a new, higher technology machine will have an influence on the capacity of that firm, although it may not be described as `new capacity'-it is changed technology and so on. Looking at the figures, the evidence is uncertain in respect of an answer to this question. I have had the Bureau of Industry Economics working on the issue. Its conclusions-and I hesitate to use the word-are generally comforting in the sense that it comes down with the view, based on surveys of some 200 firms, as I recall it, that a lot of investment is going into new capacity. There is an enormous amount of anecdotal evidence-starting with firms such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or ICI Australia Ltd, which are big firms, and moving down to smaller firms-about increasing capacity by new investment. I cannot give a categorical answer to the question. On the balance of information which I have, I would err on the side of saying that the investment is, by and large, leading to an increase in capacity and that is certainly supported by my observations of industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney in his earlier question asked me about investment intentions. Some firms have announced investments. For example, one major firm which announced a $350m investment has reduced that in the current circumstances to a $200m investment this year. A bit of that is happening in terms of retracting prior announcements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of claims made by people attempting to get assistance from agents when lodging immigration applications that they are being charged exorbitant fees? Is he also aware of agents making claims of being able to influence decisions on their cases? Can the Minister inform the Senate what he intends to do to protect the victims of these unscrupulous people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of claims being made by a variety of people who have been conned by these so-called agents into paying large fees for a very minimal service. I stress at the outset that my Department treats all applications in the same way. No special privileges are given to applications that are lodged by agents. The fact is that applications are assessed on the merits of their individual case, not on the relative aesthetics of the way in which their applications are presented or any so-called special influence that agents may claim to have. I will give some examples of the cases brought to my attention recently. I will not mention the individual names of the agents at this stage, but let this be a clear warning to others that the next time I hear of such cases I may not hesitate to name the individuals in this chamber. In one instance a solicitor charged $2,000 simply to lodge an application for a further entry permit. The normal departmental fee for this type of application is $50.
—You should report him to the Law Society.

—I will take that excellent suggestion on board. In another case an agent charged $6,000 for services to a client. Those services included lodgment of an application for resident status and a further application for temporary entry residence after the initial one failed. The fact that the applications were compiled into a glossy, spiral-bound folder and submitted by the agent had no effect on the result. The applications were rejected in both instances. Finally, an agent who claimed to have a friend in the Department asked for payment of $5,000 up-front to take the case of a sponsor of an applicant whose original application had been refused. He had been considered by the Immigration Review Panel and finally had been subject to a personal appeal to me. The application, which was rejected, had the support of a member of parliament in all these processes. To my knowledge, the applicant has fortunately not taken up the offer by the agent. These types of people prey on the vulnerability of potential residents by using unsubstantiated claims about their ability to influence a decision, and they are making a fortune in the process.

ANSWER.PARA: I should also stress, however, that there is a number of reputable agents and firms who provide genuine assistance in the form of advice to clients. The impending changes to the migration legislation, which come into effect on 19 December this year, appear to have provoked a concerted effort on the part of some of the unscrupulous types to make the most of any uncertainty that people have. In recognition of this problem, the new migration legislation contains a provision under which agents can be prosecuted for claiming they have special influence. In any event, they must provide an itemised statement of their accounts. At this stage the principal advice that I would offer to any people contemplating the use of a migration agent would be to go to the nearest office of my Department and check out the reality of the situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In reference to the proposed relocation of the Royal Australian Navy to Jervis Bay, yesterday the Prime Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . I can inform you that the Government is no longer disposed to move the Sydney naval fleet to Jervis Bay.
Yet, on the same day, a spokesman for the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, stated:
. . . an eventual move to Jervis Bay could not be ruled out.
Can the Minister advise the Senate which is the definitive statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I had noticed a newspaper report this morning alleging that a spokesman for Mr Beazley had said that an eventual move to Jervis Bay by the Navy could not be ruled out. Because I noticed that this morning, I made some inquiries of Mr Beazley's office.
—In what terms?

—In very friendly terms. It was suggested to me that one officer of Mr Beazley's staff did in fact talk to the journalist concerned. However, that person claims to have been misquoted. In fact, he had referred to not ruling out the possibility of the armaments depot in the long term, depending on what the environmental impact statement (EIS) process might reveal. No-one in Mr Beazley's office contradicted the Prime Minister. However, one of his staff was misquoted and so this unfortunate situation arose.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response. I am not quite sure from his answer whether he is suggesting that the EIS is continuing. I ask him to explain that to the Senate. Also, what status did the senior Government source have who said that Mr Hawke's carefully chosen words did not categorically rule out a move to Jervis Bay, and that `What it means is that the whole thing is on the back burner.'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know who that Government source is. If I did, whoever it is would not have as much status as he or she had before saying it. The reality is that the Prime Minister has indicated the attitude of the Government. In fact, what he said was hardly new. I have indicated here a number of times, as has the Prime Minister, that inadequacies were revealed in the production of the original EIS, which is why it has been held up for so long.
—Are you going on with your EIS?

—Senator Newman probably does not understand the system. That is all right; I understand that. We have to prepare an EIS, which then goes to my Department, which is consulted before the EIS is put out to public review. My Department found a number of problems with the EIS. In any event, the EIS process will continue in so far as the armaments depot is concerned. That means that there will have to be some reworking of it. Already, however, the EIS has proved useful in providing us with some information on marine life at Jervis Bay which we did not have before. In any event if we are to look at the armaments depot it must continue.
—What about the rest of the EIS?

—I think that the Prime Minister has said that the fleet will not go to Jervis Bay. Therefore we will not continue with an EIS process that says the fleet ought to go there, but we will continue to look at whether the armaments depot goes there. I intend to talk to Mr Beazley, the people from the Department of Defence, Mr Simmons and some people from my own Department. We will rework the EIS and see how much of it needs to continue and how much of it does not. When we have some reworked terms for it I am quite happy to make them available to Senator Newman.
—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
—That's right; get into him.

—All right; I will. It concerns the long running farce of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Assembly, which began last week with the Canberra Times headline `Duby Deals Doom to Follett'. It was not `Duby Does Dallas' but close to it. With regard to the ACT Assembly and the sudden change of mind-to put it frankly-experienced by members of the No Self Government Party, who voted out the Labor Government, will the Minister examine a need for another election in the ACT if the manoeuvring of the Assembly members concerned leads to further instability? On behalf of Senator Lewis and while I am on my feet I will ask about my Aunty Ethel, who wants to be in the Assembly too. Can the Minister explain whether she should run as an independent or as a member of the `No Fluoride in Tomato Party'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the great majority of Canberra residents, I share the view that Rosemary Follett had done an excellent job in leading the ACT, even if it was from the position of leader of a minority government. She had worked hard, as had her Ministers, in the interests of the ACT. That is in stark contrast to the alliance which has now taken over, which could not even find a proper excuse for a no-confidence motion. I am asked whether the Government would examine the need for a new election. To do that, we need first to look at what power we would have to do it; and, secondly, to look at whether a situation which calls for the exercise of that power exists.

ANSWER.PARA: Section 16 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act refers to a procedure whereby the Governor-General may dissolve the Assembly. He can do so if either of two things are occurring: one, if the Assembly is incapable of effectively performing its functions; or, secondly, if the Assembly is conducting its affairs in a grossly improper manner. If the Assembly were to be dissolved in that way, a commissioner would be appointed with powers in the Executive and an election would have to be held between 36 and 90 days afterwards. Of course, the Commonwealth Minister responsible would have to table the reasons for the decision in both Houses of Parliament. So we must look at whether the Assembly is incapable of effectively performing its functions or whether it is conducting its affairs in a grossly improper manner.

If one is searching for stability in the ACT the early indications are not all that promising. The Residents Rally and the Liberals have been at odds with each other on God knows how many issues, fluoridation being just one. Other issues are how to run the health care system and how to run the education system. The Liberal Party was elected on the ultimate pro-development platform-`We will let them build anywhere'. The Residents Rally opposed even the casino and was allegedly opposed to development. My, how principles change when the prospect of office starts to look a real possibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the prospect of losing office for you.

—At least the prospect of Senator Puplick getting there remains remote. If we are looking at how this Assembly can perform, we should note that, during the Budget negotiations, Mr Duby of the No Self Government Party, to whom Senator Aulich earlier referred, called for $90m in additional expenditure while the Liberals called for expenditure cuts. No justification of any substance was given for the no confidence motion. The Australian Financial Review of 6 December said it all. It said of this new alliance that it was:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . a joke masquerading as a government . . . a curious amalgam of political philosophies held together by no more than petty opportunism.
These people have elevated hypocrisy to new heights. The Residents Rally is led by a gentleman called Bernard Collaery. After the last election he said:

The very fact that we are here is because we reject the concept of party-political machines, so we won't form a coalition with Liberal and Labor. They will have to come down to us and find a community base.
The Liberals had no difficulty in coming down. As far as this coalition is concerned with the No Self Government Party, Mr Duby had this to say in his election material:
You can stop self-government. Don't be fooled. You can say no. Life under the new pretend parliament will be very different from the one you have now.

It did not take him long, however, in looking at the pretend parliament, to decide that the office was not all that much of a pretence. It gave access to the extra salary and the car. By the way, the car offered was not good enough for Mr Duby. He was offered a Falcon. He sent that back. He has asked for a Fairlane.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you drive?

—I would love to drive a Falcon if someone would give me one, but no-one will. If the Residents Rally remains true to its aims, obviously this ACT Government cannot possibly last. It will fold, and it will fold immediately. Amazing as it may seem, there are but 10 members of this Liberal coalition Government. Nine of them have ministerial roles. But honourable members should not think that there is a back bench-the tenth member is the Speaker. That is not a bad effort. Even when this lot here on the other side had to find jobs for Senator Brownhill and a few others, they invented a few extra positions; but they did not dare go this far. This is the ultimate in joke government and this ACT Government will be condemned by the residents of the ACT. At the next election-an election about which it is terrified-the result will be obvious. It will be thrown out and Labor and Rosemary Follett will return to their rightful places.

—It is interesting to see how chickens come home to roost. I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel another question in relation to Jervis Bay. I preface my question by noting that a Defence Department review of alternative sites to which naval facilities in Sydney could be located is now under way. Therefore, I ask the Minister: How, and by whom, is the study of alternatives being conducted? Given that there is strong scepticism among environment groups about yet another study of relocation options being done within the Defence Department, will the Minister open up the review to comprehensive public input? What role, if any, did the person directing this alternative sites study have in formulating or executing the plan to relocate naval facilities to Jervis Bay? Will this study include a consideration of alternative schemes to the naval bombardment of Beecroft Peninsula?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —A month or so ago the Minister, Mr Simmons, directed the Department of Defence to look at alternative sites for the relocation of the fleet base. In looking at what sort of a team would do that, I think the Department of Defence has come up with a team which will more than cope with the task. The review team is drawn from the headquarters of the Australian Defence Force and the Facilities and Property Division of the Department. It is being oversighted by a major-general equivalent level steering group. The review team will conduct its study both by making use of the previous reports and information and by the commissioning of any further studies and data collection as it considers necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: In initiating the review in the first place, Mr Simmons stressed that he wanted to avoid any bias that could be suggested by anybody in trying to come up with a predetermined outcome. To reinforce that view it is intended that interested groups will have an opportunity to make submissions to the review team. The officers and officials who were involved in the review were not responsible for the naval studies which concluded that Jervis Bay was the most suitable site. So they do not have any previous pride of authorship to protect. The officials from the Department of Defence Facilities and Property Division have, naturally enough, been involved in developing planned relocation in accordance with those guidelines, but they were not responsible for any of the original decision making.

As far as the fourth part of Senator Coulter's question is concerned, I think he misunderstands the nature of the environmental impact statement (EIS) and of the previous decision made to look at the possibility of sending the fleet to Jervis Bay. It was never the case that the future of the bombing range at Beecroft Peninsula should be determined on the basis of whether the fleet went there. The continued use of Beecroft Peninsula has never been conditional on the outcome of the EIS, and that position remains.

I have discussed the matter of Beecroft Peninsula in this chamber a number of times. The Government is of the view that it can, and should, remain as a bombing range. It has been well managed by the Navy and we do not believe that there needs to be any change to that arrangement. So there will not be any examination of that question in any proposed review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the Minister's reply that even though the team may, to some extent, have some independence, the selection of the review team is still very much an in-house matter within the Department of Defence. Therefore, if I am correct in how I read the Minister's reply, he has not answered the part of my question dealing with the opening up of the review to comprehensive public input. If that process is still essentially in-house, through the selection of the team within the Defence Department, can he tell me how or whether the review will be opened up to comprehensive public input?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the objections my Department raised with Navy in looking at the direction of the EIS was that it lacked information in the study of alternative sites. As I indicated earlier in Question Time in answer to Senator Newman, I have to discuss with Mr Beazley and Mr Simmons how we might adjust the EIS process and still achieve the result of testing the armaments depot question. As part of that process it may be the case that we continue with a consideration of alternatives there, and obviously, if we did, that would be opened up to full public scrutiny.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no possibility that at the end of the day the public can be kept away from the process of looking at where a fleet base would be relocated. One would imagine that there are not too many places on the coastline of Australia-particularly on the east coast-where there would not be some objections from somebody about its relocation. So there are two possibilities for public involvement in the review: in the way that I have indicated, or in the EIS, depending upon how we wish to keep it going. I give Senator Coulter my commitment, however, that I will ensure that there is maximum public participation in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the annual report of the Australian Customs Service, which reveals that during the last financial year there was a 46 per cent increase in the number of successful drug interceptions at air and sea ports. In view of this significant achievement, are any measures anticipated to even further improve detection methods in a bid to further reduce the evil trade and deal an even greater blow to the international drug cartels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A major objective of the Customs Service is to upgrade the effectiveness of narcotics interception. There are all sorts of views about whether that can best be done by better intelligence or by massive manpower increases. Senator Jones is quite correct; Customs has reported a significant increase of 46 per cent in successful drug interceptions in 1988-89. This increase has been across all drug categories except heroin. However, I should point out that the amount of heroin seized has increased by 161 per cent over the previous year.

ANSWER.PARA: The focus for Customs narcotics interception is the use of contraband enforcement teams and their application of risk management principles. These teams concentrate on drug enforcement activities through the identification and control of high risk areas at the Customs barrier. There is a greater reliance by Customs on activities such as the gathering of intelligence on persons involved in illicit drug activities, and closer cooperative links with other law enforcement organisations and non-government organisations involved in international trade. These methods have helped improve the success rate to which I referred and it is expected that these improvements will continue. I add that the training of Customs staff in a wide range of drug enforcement disciplines will continue to be a major priority for the Service.

In the absence of any national estimates of the totality of drug trends, Customs and other enforcement agencies are not in a position to estimate their effectiveness in terms of drug availability or abuse. All the Customs Service can say is that there has been this increasing performance in the detection of drug offences and drug interception. It is very difficult to quantify what the success rate is compared with the total drug market. I believe that the figures I have quoted provide encouraging support for the strategies and risk assessment systems employed by the Australian Customs Service which have been referred to on numerous occasions in the Senate in relation to questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It concerns the financial problems of the State Bank of Victoria and the adequacy of its capital. I refer to yesterday's revelations that the State Bank of Victoria is planning what one might call a creative all-in-the-family financing arrangement with a government agency such as the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria to cover its $1 billion losses.
—How much?

—It is just $1 billion down the drain-give or take $100m, perhaps. Bearing in mind the concern of the Reserve Bank of Australia that the State Bank of Victoria should comply with its capital adequacy guidelines, will the Minister tell the Senate whether the proposed cover-up by the Cain Government will do so?

—I gather from the comments that were made by some other honourable senators on the Liberal Party side of the chamber that the $1 billion is a very rounded figure. I do not know what the more accurate figure might be. I am subject to correction on this, but I do not believe that the Reserve Bank Act gives the Reserve Bank any control over a State bank. Therefore, I am not sure whether the prudential requirements which the Reserve Bank would impose on a normal trading bank are applicable, but I will check that out and get a response from the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I draw attention to an article in the Australian Financial Review of today's date which relates to the steel plan. Now that the plan has been finished for a year and we have the time for sober reflection on its results, will the Minister explain whether he is satisfied that the plan has achieved its aims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the first aims of the steel plan was to keep Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) in the steel business.
—How does our productivity compare with that of other countries?

—I will provide an answer to that. The goal of the Government and of BHP for improving the company's international competitiveness through improved efficiency and greater productivity has been achieved with dramatic effect, according to the Australian Financial Review article. That is right. The honourable senator asked whether we had been able to compare the position of this country's steel industry with that existing before the plan. I am able to confirm that there have been significant improvements in both the current situation and our expectations for the future.
—The rest of the world has been standing still, has it?

—No, the rest of the world has not been standing still, but Senator Stone and his National Party colleagues in Queensland have stood still, if anybody has, and I will come back to that in a minute. At the time of the severe downturn in 1982-83 the steel plan was introduced to encourage rationalisation and modernisation in the industry. It certainly helped to create a favourable environment for industry development and delivered only limited financial assistance to the industry through a system of bounties on the production of certain iron and steel goods. The total bounties payable under the plan amounted to approximately $150m. There has been a significant decline in industrial disputation at BHP steel plants. A much better environment has been created which is now reflected in industrial agreements providing for productivity improvements, job security, training programs and job and award restructuring. The capital expenditure of BHP for the period March 1983 to December 1988 was $1.8 billion, That figure has now been lifted by the announcement by BHP that, by the end of the year 1990-91, there will be a further $850m, approximately, expended on the steel industry.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of another very important issue which Senator Stone asked me about by way of interjection, I simply say that the productivity of BHP has increased from below 200 tonnes per employee when this Government came into office and introduced the steel plan, to where it is now approaching 400 tonnes per employee, and BHP anticipates that by the end of the calendar year 1990 that figure will have reached 500 tonnes of raw steel per employee in a year. There are only two areas in the world at the present time where that productivity level is exceeded, and they are Japan and some areas of the steel industry in the United States of America. BHP now claims to be producing the cheapest steel of its kind in the world, and the current investment commitments will make for a large performance in respect of exports by BHP. It is already of the order of 20 per cent and increasing, and as each year passes and these new investments are commissioned, that export capacity will increase.

I was at Whyalla the other day, opening a new steel making facility at Port Kembla. That, and other plants which are coming on stream, will increase the steel making capacity to 7.85 million tonnes per annum. The honourable senator who asked the question-Senator Childs-is from New South Wales, and will know that many of the projects which I have referred to are in New South Wales. They will have an obvious economic flow-on effect for the people of that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of the concern being expressed by members of the medical profession that efforts to reduce the toll of osteoporosis among at risk patients are being hindered by the fact that the Medicare rebate is not available for this procedure? What efforts has the Minister made, or what efforts, if any, does she plan to make, to consult with the Minister for Community Services and Health and the relevant section of the medical profession to address this issue?

—Senator Patterson raises an important issue, and one that has been addressed in consultation with women in developing the national women's health policy. The specific question that she has asked is not one that I am in a position to answer here today, but I can certainly get a detailed briefing for her. Obviously, there are a great many health issues affecting Australian women that are being addressed under the national women's health policy. This is one question raised during the consultations, and I will seek to get further details for Senator Patterson.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister what effort she has made or what effort does she intend to make-I would not have thought that she would need a briefing on that but maybe she does-to do something to address this issue.

—I am continually working in a range of fields affecting Australian women, and I will continue to do so. This is one that Dr Blewett has prime responsibility for but I have worked very closely with him in the development of the national women's health policy. I keep in constant contact with Dr Blewett about a range of new initiatives that are coming out in relation to that policy. As I said before in answer to Senator Patterson's earlier question, I will get a detailed briefing for her.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The question relates to the taxation of lump sums paid out by employers for unused long service leave. I ask: Where a taxpayer who is still working dies and that person's employer pays out a lump sum on account of unused long service leave, is that lump sum then liable to income tax? Is the income tax then payable much earlier than it would have been had the person lived longer? If so, does this mean that the Australian personal income tax is a form of death duty? Finally, has the Minister received representations complaining about this aspect of the Australian income tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question contains four parts. I will answer them in sequence. The first one is: is a lump sum payable subject to income tax? The answer is yes. Under section 26ad of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was introduced in 1978 when Mr Howard was Treasurer and Senator Stone, incidentally, was the Deputy Secretary to the Treasury, the post-August 1978 element of any lump sum is typically taxed more heavily than the pre-August 1978 element. The main point in this context is that the taxation of such a lump sum has long been a feature of the Australian tax system.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question is: is the tax payment brought forward by the death of a person? The answer to that is yes because had the person lived, the tax liability on accruing long service leave could have been deferred for a very long period, possibly right up to retirement. Because of section 26ad the accrued long service leave entitlement is taxed as soon as possible after the death of the individual. The third part of the question is: Does this mean that the personal income tax is a form of death duty? I think the answer to that has to be unequivocally no because we are talking about a tax on income. The tax is levied on a receipts basis rather than as the income is accrued. Exactly the same principle is, of course, applied to capital gains tax. Yesterday Senator Stone tried to argue that this meant that capital gains tax was `incontrovertibly' a form of death duty. Senator Stone said:
This is a fact that the Government continues to deny but it is incontrovertibly true-it is a form of death duty.

Senator Stone was referring to the capital gains tax. That is a completely false definition for a number of reasons, one of which is that death duties are applied to an estate whether or not there has been a capital gain in the estate. A capital gains tax is applicable only if there has been a real capital gain. I have already given another reason why the capital gains tax is not a death duty.

Moreover, I suggest that, if one accepts Senator Stone's specious assertions-his arguments about the capital gains tax being a form of death duty-the speculative gains tax, in circumstances where an estate or a piece of property is sold because the three or four people who may inherit it cannot agree on any continuing arrangement and it therefore has to be sold, is also a form of death duty. I do not accept Senator Stone's argument, nor does the Government. I believe that, had anybody put to Senator Stone, when he was Deputy Secretary to the Treasury, when he was a rigorous Treasury officer instead of a politician in the National Party of Australia, the type of argument that he put in the Senate yesterday, it would have been dismissed as sophistry, casuistry, or even the rantings of a mere meretricious player.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware that under the National Agenda for Women grants program applicant organisations or individuals, to be eligible for a grant, must support the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women?
