Why must an Australian women's organisation, which is applying directly to the Federal Government for funding, be subject to an international convention? If an organisation under its own constitution supports the concept of equality of opportunity for women but believes many of the articles of the convention to be ambiguously worded and unattainable, why are those applicants denied funding through this grants system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator McGauran cannot be very familiar with the National Agenda for Women grants program. As far as I am aware it is unheard of for women's organisations not to support the National Agenda for Women. Australian women's organisations are very pleased that the Government has implemented the National Agenda for Women and they welcome the opportunity to apply for grants under this program. As to Senator McGauran's specific question as to what would happen if an organisation came forward and said it did not agree with the National Agenda for Women grants program but it was seeking funding under that program, obviously the Office of the Status of Women would have to deal with that particular problem when it arose. I am not aware of any such organisation. If Senator McGauran knows of an organisation that is in the strange position of applying for money when it does not even uphold the philosophy and principles of the program under which it is applying, I would be interested to have a look at the specific example.

ANSWER.PARA: The underlying point of the National Agenda for Women grants program is that it gives women's organisations the opportunity to read the agenda and to look at how they can make the agenda relevant in their particular sphere of interest and concern. It may be in relation to employment, health, education, domestic violence, portrayal of women in the media, child-care, housing-the full range of issues included in the National Agenda for Women. I am sorry if I do not sound particularly helpful in relation to the question asked by Senator McGauran but it seems to me that it would be quite contradictory for an organisation that does not uphold the need for recognition of the National Agenda for Women to apply for a grant. If Senator McGauran has a specific case to refer to me I would be happy to look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It refers to the November Australian Bureau of Statistics unemployment rates which showed about a 9 per cent rate for Tasmania compared with 6 per cent nationally. Do these figures indicate that Tasmania's geographical, economic and/or political circumstances are now less conducive to employment than those of other States or do the figures show that the Federal Government's fiscal policies, including high interest rates, have a more dramatic influence on smaller businesses in smaller States? If it is the former, could the Minister detail to the Senate the factors which have contributed to Tasmania's significantly higher unemployment rate and indicate whether one of these factors has been the effect on tourism of the airlines dispute?

—As long as I can remember, unemployment in Tasmania has had more stability-if I can put it in those terms-at a higher level than in most areas of the mainland. I conceded in the Senate on a number of occasions a few weeks ago that the airline dispute had had a very detrimental effect on Tasmania, as it has on other remote parts of the Commonwealth, compared with the major cities on the mainland; that is certainly true. I certainly would not concede that fiscal policies and, indeed, monetary policies had had a differential impact on Tasmania from anywhere else in the Commonwealth. In so far as Senator Harradine refers to fiscal policies, I must say that there have always been demands from Tasmanian governments to this Government and the previous Government, the Fraser Government, for Commonwealth appropriations to support industry activities in Tasmania.
—The Fraser Government cared for Tasmania.

—All the caring under the sun does not do much good if nothing is done. If Senator Newman wants to lead me to this point, I guess that I must say that the main problem of Tasmania is that until quite recently there was a pretty dopey government down there that did nothing about developing Tasmanian industry.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to reports that wool prices have fallen by nearly 30 per cent this year and that this industry, which last year contributed $5.9 billion to Australia's balance of payments, may have sales cut by $2 billion this year. Is the Minister also aware that the Australian Wheat Board had to slash nearly one million tonnes from its projected estimate for this year's wheat crop, a crop which was worth $2.5 billion to this country last year? What effect will the downturn in both of these very important industries have on Australia's balance of payments and blow-out of the trade deficit?
—This wouldn't have happened if Joh was still Premier in Queensland.

—Senator Button says that this would not have happened if Joh was still Premier and if the white-shoe brigade, in coalition with the brown paper bag brigade, was still running Queensland. I would have thought that the answer to the question would be self-evident. If there is a major decline in either production or price of any significant export-and wheat and wool are both significant exports-Australia's export receipts will be lower than they would otherwise have been and the current account deficit will be commensurately larger.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware that the British Child Migrant Trust has records of some 4,500 former child migrants who are seeking their identity and personal history prior to coming to Australia, that the majority of these people are aged in their late forties and fifties, and that time is running out for them to find their parents and other relatives who are still alive? Did the Minister view, or otherwise have reported to him, the contents of the recent Peter Couchman telecast of 22 November which described the work being done by Margaret Humphreys, a Friendship Trust social worker funded by a United Kingdom local government authority, who is searching for the United Kingdom relatives of the former child migrants now resident in Australia? Has the Minister taken any steps so that the Australian Government can assist by providing full time social workers who will assist in finding any remaining relatives and provide professional counselling before, during and after re-uniting meetings? If yes, what steps have been taken by the Federal Government and State governments? If no, what steps will the Minister take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins would be aware that this issue was raised in the Senate on 1 June 1989. At that time I expressed my concern for the situation of former British child migrants and the unfortunate experiences of some of these children. I assured Senator Jenkins that the Federal and State governments would assist these people to trace their origins. My Department in Western Australia has already provided significant assistance to British child migrants in that State. I am aware of the program that was on television on 22 November. I have instructed my Department to assist any former British child migrants who may approach it as a result of the program. I should also add that my Department has already been assisting some of these people during the course of the year.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of the funding of social workers has been addressed by the Standing Committee of Social Welfare Administrators. This body represents Commonwealth and State officials concerned with child welfare issues. As such, the matter is not one for me to comment on any further. My Department will provide former British child migrants, at no cost, with a certificate of evidence of resident status which provides details of their arrival in Australia. My Department will also provide any personal documentation held by it that will assist these people in tracing their origins.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. With regard to the search for records, is the Minister urging the Government to provide or is the Government already actually providing assistance for record searches in the United Kingdom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that that was more a matter for the domestic politics of Britain, where most of the problems originally arose. Is the honourable senator referring to records we may hold in our immigration sections overseas? I was not really clear what Senator Jenkins's supplementary question was getting towards. Those records held overseas 30 or 40 years ago would have been returned to Australia, I guess, and placed in the archives. I would not have thought that they would be stored in the United Kingdom.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JOURNALIST: DISCLOSURE OF SOURCES OF INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the Minister to the gaoling in Perth of Sunday Times journalist Tony Barrass for refusing to reveal the source of Australian Taxation Office documents on which he based a story in his newspaper. While understanding the independence of the prosecution process, does the Minister have a view as to the appropriateness of pursuing journalists to this point, given the widespread knowledge of the Australian Journalists Association's code of ethics, which prevents the disclosure of sources? Does the Minister agree with the comments by Mr Barrass's lawyer that, knowing about the code of ethics, if the Commonwealth Crown had other evidence to support the charge it should not have put the journalist in the position it did, and if it did not have other evidence it should have dropped the charge? Will the Attorney-General call for a report on the handling of the case in view of its widespread ramifications for the media in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not well versed in the particular case which Senator Chaney refers to, though I did see a press clipping which passed over my desk some time during the course of the morning. The journalist concerned was sent to prison for contempt of court-I tried to grasp what the report said-for a seven-day period. It seemed to be a statutory period rather than a period set simply by the court. I am not quite clear whether the Parliament has also set a particular term rather than an indefinite term until the contempt is purged. It seemed to be a definite seven-day term after which, when it expires, the journalist will be free to leave. I do not have the full details, but obviously very grave questions are raised which are very difficult to judge as to the balance between the legitimate interest of the community and pursuing those who have committed crimes.

ANSWER.PARA: I would have thought it was of grave concern to the Senate, which has taken a particular interest in privacy matters, that those who have committed the crime of releasing information on citizens from Commonwealth departments should not be able to be prosecuted because evidence which would otherwise be forthcoming is said to be in some way immune from being called in a particular prosecution. If those in this chamber are really interested in the pursuit of those who have committed crimes which involve a breach of privacy, I would have thought they would have leant to the side of those who say that any evidence which is available and which could be called ought to be made available for the jury, the judge or the magistrate to make a judgment as to whether the crime is proved beyond reasonable doubt.

Nevertheless there are very complex issues involved, and I am sure that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, which would be the appropriate forum, may wish to take this matter up because quite clearly it is not a matter simply, or even mainly, of interest to the Commonwealth, but would be a matter of concern to all jurisdictions. I will seek to find out whether the Federal Attorney-General thinks it appropriate that he or some other Attorney from around Australia might put it on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time on 11 December, Senator Short asked me a question relating to the industrial dispute at the Altona oil refinery. I have been provided with an answer by the Minister for Industrial Relations. It is as follows: the Government is aware that Petroleum Refineries (Australia) Pty Ltd maintenance workers did remain on strike following the return to work of the contractor's employees. At least 50 or 60 employees remained on strike. However, I am advised that these maintenance workers voted this morning, 12 December, to return to work and have done so. While production was affected during the dispute, the plant was not closed down.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of the legal actions initiated by the employer against unions in this instance, it is for the company to consider its position in this matter. The Government has not been requested by either side to take a position in relation to the legal actions, but I can say that we would wish to see the dispute resolved using the proper processes available to the parties within the wage fixing system.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MARITIME SAFETY OPERATIONS BRANCH: DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 December, Senator Reid asked me a question about the transfer of the Maritime Safety Operations Branch to Newcastle. I now have the additional information: there will be 209 positions in the Australian Maritime Safety Operations Branch in Newcastle. Approximately five existing divisional staff will not be offered transfers to the authority due to organisational changes. All efforts will be made to redeploy these staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Calvert asked me a question about the treatment of cancer in Australian hospitals and the resources for such treatments. I do have an answer to it. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

These statements are not correct. The report referred to was not a Federal Government report but was prepared by a working party of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council (AHMAC). The report is an internal AHMAC document which remains confidential until AHMAC has made a formal decision to release it.
The report was considered by AHMAC on 20 October 1989. Public release of the report was not considered.

Claims of this nature have been made in the past and rest largely on comparisons with overseas countries and the relatively low proportion of cancer patients in Australia who receive radiation therapy (35% in Australia compared with 45-55% in comparable countries overseas).
In considering the working party's report however AHMAC was not prepared to endorse any particular referral rate.

AHMAC's decision recognises that there is no evidence to suggest that Australian referral rates should be the same as other countries and in particular that there is no evidence that survival rates of cancer patients in Australia are worse than elsewhere.

The AHMAC working party report also makes it clear that any apparent shortage of equipment is only one of many factors influencing the availability of, and demand for, radiotherapy. Geographical factors, shortage of radiation oncologists and therapeutic radiographers and limited knowledge of the usage of radiotherapy by referring doctors are all important factors.

Claims that there are Australians who would benefit from radiotherapy but who do not have access because of lack of facilities are not supported by information presented to AHMAC by the working party:
a survey conducted by the working party in December 1988 found there were no significant waiting lists for radiotherapy services;
this would indicate that those cancer patients not receiving radiotherapy services are being treated by other modalities and are not being disadvantaged in any way.
The majority of radiotherapy services are provided in the public sector and the provision of radiotherapy services is essentially a matter for the states.

In responding to the AHMAC Report most states indicated that they have addressed the needs for radiotherapy services to 1995 and have developed, or are currently developing, strategic plans for staff and equipment levels which are generally in line with the recommendations of the working party.

The Commonwealth has also made $50m available under the Hospital Enhancement Program to be matched by states to provide $75m in both 1989-90 and 1990-91 to enable states to improve the capital equipment in public hospitals. This follows a similar program, the Teaching Hospitals Capital Equipment Program, between 1985-86 and 1987-88 under which the Commonwealth provided $150m to assist states with capital acquisition. States determine their own priorities for capital expenditure.

Funding for radiotherapy treatment has been available for many years through medial benefits for services to private patients. In February 1988 the Commonwealth extended its financial support to cover computerised radiotherapy planning services for private patients.
In 1988-89 total Federal Government expenditure for radiotherapy services for private patients amounted to some $11m.

Discussions are currently under way between the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health and the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists (RACR) over the expansion of private sector radiation oncology. Subject to the state authorities confirming that the private proposals are consistent with overall state plans, the Government is likely to support such expansion if States agree.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 November, Senator Haines asked a question regarding the wife's pension. I also have an answer to that. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Wife's Pension was introduced in 1942 to provide income support for women not qualified for a pension in their own right who were married to age pensioners. It was introduced in recognition of the difficulties faced by families who were trying to survive on one single rate pension generally because the woman was slightly too young to qualify for pension herself. Because women usually marry men older than they are, this situation was, and still is, very common.
Wife's Pension is also paid to women married to invalid pensioners who are not qualified for pension in their own right. This issue is not raised by Senator Haines.

At the time when wife's pension was introduced, most married women were outside the work force. Although this is no longer the case, current wife's pensioners who are married to age pensioners are generally in their late fifties and belong to a generation of women who often did not return to work after raising their children. Many of these women have had little or no recent work force experience. Because of this and because of their age, it could be seen as harsh and unreasonable to expect these women to support themselves through employment.

Men who are married to age pensioners but who are not entitled to pension in their own right cannot receive a pension as a dependent spouse. However, if they are providing personal care or constant supervision to a severely disabled age or invalid pensioner, they must be entitled to carers pension, which is paid at the same rate and with the same entitlements to concessions as other social security pensions. Many husbands who are caring for disabled age pensioner wives are currently receiving carers pension. In fact, about two-thirds of current carers pensioners are men.

The Government has given some consideration to the issue of the different entitlements of men and women married to pensioners and believes that it would be inappropriate to extend pension to men solely on the basis of their marital status. Wife's pension is paid in recognition of the special difficulties historically faced by women-particularly this generation of older women-in supporting themselves in the work force. Historically, men have faced no such difficulties, while the special situation of men and women with responsibility for the care of a severely disabled relative or other pensioner has been recognised by carers pension.

This Government also recognises that the best route for people to escape from poverty is generally through employment. It does not wish to encourage premature departure from the work force by those in employment. Extending wife's pension to a spouses pension would therefore create a new anomaly rather than resolve an existing one, especially in view of the availability of age pension to women at age sixty.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that an amount of $12.5m in this allocation is made up of moneys available for new services for which no specific appropriation has been made in the Budget. The $12.5m is for the Department of Transport and Communications as payments to cover charges waived by the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation because of the pilots strike, dispute, or whatever one wants to call it. The fact is that at a time when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said `there is no dispute'-that is, for the month of November-$12.5m of taxpayers' funds went to make up the airline charges waived by the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation. So much for the lack of a dispute.

The fact is that this is the cutting edge of where this dispute is directly costing taxpayers in an identifiable way. But on top of the $12.5m, which follows just a couple of million the month before and a million or so the month before that, there are the hidden costs to the taxpayers of Australia-apart from the clear losses and disasters facing so many small businesses and other industries dependent on travel-such as the hidden subsidy of something like $60m that the defence forces have been providing to the airlines by supplying aircraft during this time of non-dispute. That is apart from the amount of money they are getting back. It is a monumentally understated amount of money as against the costs of operating the services that the airlines have been required to pay the defence forces.

There has also been the massive cost to both the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation in terms of lost revenue as a result of the enormous diminution in travelling numbers. I understand that that loss overall makes up about $19m a month. The extraordinary thing about the $12.5m that is now being paid out of taxpayers' funds is that it will keep on being paid so long as the airlines keep suffering losses by not standing down employees under the terms of the deal done with the Government.

Although the airlines keep claiming that their services have been massively restored, that one can get flights and so on, I have seen no indication from this Government or from the airlines about when this subsidy, involving the waiving of payments to the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation, is expected to stop. If the airlines have got themselves so much in order and have their schedules back so effectively that they can do without Royal Australia Air Force support-and I am told that will be the case from the fifteenth of this month-why are they still facing this problem of paying people who would otherwise have been stood down? How long will this subsidy keep on being paid? Will it keep up at the $12.5m a month level? I believe that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who has authorised these payments, has an obligation to tell the Senate just how long this steady drain of taxpayers' money will continue, particularly as we are assured by the Prime Minister that there is no dispute.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
The annual report of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (HLIC) reveals, amongst other things, the impact on ordinary Australians of huge housing interest rates. Page 7 of the report states:
The average loan insured by the HLIC over all States increased in size from $53,754 in 1987-88 to $64,308 in 1988-89.

If we apply the new 17 per cent interest rate on that, it means that for the average insured loan throughout Australia, a homeseeker would have to be in a position to pay an interest Bill of $11,032 a year-that is, $212 a week in interest alone-before he starts repaying the principal of the loan at all. To do that under the rules of almost every lending institution, one would need a salary of something like $850 a week or $42,500 a year as a minimum. That is way above-something like 50 per cent above-the average weekly earnings. In other words, these figures reinforce the view that the average Australian has been priced out of owning his or her own home because of these enormous interest rates that this Government has used as its only effective economic weapon. As I have said here before, the Government by using interest rates as a way of dampening down the economy is doing no more than pouring cold water over the proper aspirations of Australians to own their own homes. The report of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation also notes that 1988-89 was a boom year. It paid $5.8m in claims, which is a very small amount compared with $32.2m paid in claims over the previous two years.

The HLIC now faces a problem that will face and is facing many home owners now-that is, the massive fall in the value of their homes because of this Government's reliance on high interest rates. What is happening now-and it will be reflected in the accounts of the HLIC next year-is that people are being forced out of their homes. People will owe more and more on a home that is worth less and less. This Government has put the squeeze on the home owners of Australia by its single-minded, pig-headed approach to high interest rates which it is using instead of any of the great range of fiscal measures that it should use but refuses to do so despite continual recommendations by the opposition.

This report simply outlines and indicates the sorts of problems that Australian home seekers are now facing. Quite frankly, a person cannot afford to buy an average house now unless, as I said, he is earning something like $42,500 a year. The situation is even worse in New South Wales and Victoria. The report reveals that three-quarters of all loans in New South Wales and Victoria total above $50,000. In fact, something like 95 per cent of all loans in the Australian Capital Territory total more than $50,000. So the figure I have given really understates the real impact of the Government's high interest rate policies on New South Wales and Victoria. I trust that those people who are having to meet those high mortgage payments will let the Government know at the coming election just how responsible they hold the Government for this deliberate and disastrous policy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of Australian Airlines Ltd is very revealing. It quite properly details the very successful efforts that the company has made in returning a group operating profit before tax of $108.49m, an increase of 63 per cent over the preceding year. But the rest of the Chairman's report is little more than a plaintive cry for help. It is quite clear from the anguished tones in which Mr Ted Harris expresses himself that this airline will find itself in very serious difficulties in the not too distant future unless the Government is finally prepared to bite the bullet and allow it to have access to alternative forms of capital fund raising. Mr Harris is a longstanding mate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and maybe that is one of the reasons Mr Hawke was prepared tentatively to put his head above the barricades some months ago. Even that archconservative in every respect, Mr Willis, was prepared to put his hand up for a short while. I think he even went on the Sunday program saying that perhaps there was some sort of mickey mouse way-no doubt strongly disapproved of by Senator Walsh-in which shares could be issued that would be an indirect method of fund raising that could not be strictly construed as privatisation and therefore might buy off the left. But no, the fact is it would not even wear that. As a result, Australian Airlines is being allowed to bleed to death.
Look at the sort of big bucket that Mr Harris tips over the Government. On page 10 of the annual report Mr Harris states:
In our 1987-88 Report I affirmed that the Board unanimously supported the principal recommendations of the Advisory Group.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can't win, can he? If he is the Prime Minister's mate he is condemned for that, and if he tips a bucket over the Government he gets condemned for that.

—Being a mate of the Prime Minister, per se, is not a criminal offence. I readily concede that. We are concerned about what level of influence he might have and the extent to which the Prime Minister is in any way interested in accommodating the crying needs of this airline. Mr Harris says:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some progress in meeting the requirements set out in that Report but there are some major questions which are unresolved, particularly those of future capital injections and the removal of constraints.

Resolutions of these issues are critical to the future progress of the Airline. The Government, as owner of the Airline, must either support it as a commercial operation, able to compete on level ground-
that is, instead of a level playing field, I suppose-
with its private enterprise competitors, or it should sell the business to private operators . . .

That is in pretty stark terms. Mr Harris is saying no more or less than we all know-than blind Freddy knows, than Senator Walsh knows or than Senator Gareth Evans knew when he put out his government business enterprise discussion papers-namely, that these government business enterprises could not continue to operate successfully unless they had the same access to capital as their private sector competitors. We are now almost two years on since those sorts of high ringing statements were made. This is yet another example of the Government's total failure to grasp the realities of micro-economic reform, of it pandering to those in the trade union movement and the left wing of Caucus who simply will not allow any rational approach to the subject. As a result, once this pilots dispute is over we will see a very crippled airline that will be taken to the cleaners by the Prime Minister's even bigger and better mate, Sir Peter. There is no doubt at all that this airline will come a very bad second. Mr Harris rightly says:
To do nothing-
which is precisely the policy that has operated to date-
or to introduce ad hoc measures that do not properly address the capital injection and constraints issues, may put at risk a valuable public asset.

He could not have put it in starker terms, but I am sure that he will be ignored in the same way as Jim Leslie was ignored for several years as Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd when he was prepared to say publicly that he thought privatisation was the only way to go. No doubt Mr Strong had privately made the same sorts of recommendations before he gave the game away some months back. He had achieved a fantastic performance in turning the airline around to the point where it was the No. 1 leader in the field, but it is now going backwards fast. The principal reason for that is set out in the Chairman's report in very plain and unequivocal language. Once again, we will see absolutely nothing done because the Government is driven by pre-election imperatives to do nothing to alienate any of those who might in normal circumstances be overridden. But, because we are in the run-up to the election, their views will prevail. So much for micro-economic reform. So much for a good government-owned airline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Alston has said. In particular, I want to draw attention to some of the warning signs given in the annual report of Australian Airlines Ltd about its future. On page 10 of the report, the Chairman notes:

SPEECH.PARA: In the period 1 January to 30 June, 1989-
in other words, before the non-existent strike took place; at least non-existent in the mind of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-

there was a marked slowdown, particularly in the leisure market. In that period we carried 600,000 less passengers than in the first half of the financial year. It was a clear reflection of some of the problems facing the tourism industry.

It is worth noting that Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia are facing deregulation next year in the context not only of the disruption caused by this strike but also of the clear problems facing the tourism industry in Australia. The impact of the dispute is clearly indicated in the report as being very serious. In referring to the impact the dispute has had on the financial results in the first few months of the new financial year, the Chairman said:
The losses are substantial and the dispute has had a number of repercussive effects.
In the Chief Executive's report, Mr Strong says:
It is a matter of great regret that following this period of growth and success the Airline has been plunged into the worst industrial upheaval in its history with the tragic pilots' dispute.
This is the real problem:
Although the effects will remain for many years, the challenge for the Airline will be to rebuild the spirit and commitment on which market leadership was achieved.

The problem of the effects of the dispute lasting for many years in the context of a massive re-equipment program undertaken by Australian Airlines should cause us a great deal of concern. That re-equipment program is outlined on page 17 of the report. This is the context in which we are facing deregulation in October 1990. It is no wonder that Australian Airlines is looking forward to that situation with some trepidation. On page 19, it says:
Deregulation has been the subject of protracted public debate in the ten years since the United States took similar action over its domestic aviation industry.
The Australian community has high expectations of the benefits it sees flowing from a free market.

The coalition in particular has high expectations, particularly in terms of increased and improved services to the users of airline facilities, apart from the prospect of cheaper fares. The report continues:
Cheaper fares without over-restrictive conditions, better schedules with no parallel departure times and a wider choice of airlines are among the commonly held perceptions of the future.
Time will tell whether these expectations are realised.
Obviously, Australian Airlines is pouring a little cold water over those expectations because it is going to be in the firing line. The report goes on:
But what is certain is that the experience of the U.S. will not be duplicated in Australia.
The U.S. was the first and largest country to embrace deregulation; lessons learned there will not be ignored in this country.

Poorly-conceived airline operations are unlikely to find speculative financial support. Investors will be better advised, with the experience of the U.S. to draw on, and will assess far more carefully any new airline's prospects for an adequate return on those investments. So, although there will be increased competition, a plethora of new airlines is unlikely.
Deregulation poses some considerable challenges for Australian Airlines.
There is no doubt about that. The report continues:
These will be faced with a determination to prove that our customer-orientated, market-driven approach will bring long-term success and profitability.

What is evident from the report is not simply that Australian Airlines faces a problem only as a result of a strike, only as a result of deregulation or only as a result of falling tourist dollars; it faces a problem on almost every front against a background of massive re-equipment. As I said, the airline industry throughout Australia is in for a lively time next year, judging from this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had urged them to go to court.

—He had previously urged them to go to court and had said the Government would give its full approval-whatever that means from a government that has claimed it has no authority. When the judgment was made and the machinations started to take place and the convulsions started to forment within the parliamentary party and the unions, the Prime Minister said that it was not his cup of tea and that he would deal with it; he would speak to the airlines. SPEECH.PARA: In the minute or so left to me, I say that while it goes without saying that I do not approve under any circumstances of the conduct of the pilots in this dispute, it is a matter of some regret that I again have to record what I consider to be the dishonest and immoral conduct of the airlines. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

In doing so, I declare my interest as a fully paid-up member of Friends of the ABC, an organisation which needs all the friends it can get. When looking at this report, we should begin with that section which refers to the services provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). We can see that the Corporation has a broad responsibility to the people of Australia through its television services, Radio Australia, its symphony orchestras and its marketing arm, in particular, the ABC shops.

The Australian Democrats believe that the national broadcaster ought to be able to set a standard by which all other radio and television in this country is judged. Unfortunately, our ABC is caught in a time warp of inefficiency, underfunding, expensive duplication and poorly utilised resources and is therefore unable to live up to that ideal. When one sees the breadth of resources that it has to provide, that is certainly a problem. As regards that funding, on page 5 of the report reference is made to the fact that, although there was the 1988 guarantee under Minister Gareth Evans, that guarantee appears to have some shaky base. I reiterate that the Democrats believe that the stability of guaranteed funding is critical to the ABC's ability to provide its services fully and efficiently, because if it has to undertake that annual scrabble its really is not possible for it to get on with the job that it needs to do. The job of the ABC has seen some changes this year-they are outlined in the annual report-and I point particularly to the increased services in country and regional areas which have been put under a cloud by the possible instability in the funding promised by the Government in 1988.

The separation of the parliamentary broadcasts, for which the Australian Democrats have been calling for some time, is an advance. It is also a bit of an embarrassment when a constituent rings up and says, `Where do I find the Parliament on the radio?' when we ourselves have difficulty in finding it. However, we believe that the regular programming of the ABC was detrimentally affected by parliamentary broadcasts, but it is important that regular programming continues.

Some aspects of programs with Australian content provide us with concern-77.8 per cent of documentaries are imported productions; 82.6 per cent of serials are imported; 92.8 per cent of feature films are imported; and 98.7 per cent of situation comedies are imported. On the other side of the ledger, very high Australian content is coming to us through the ABC-and here I am referring to television-by way of documentaries, children's programs, news and current affairs. But as I say, there is a concern in those areas-particularly as the domestic production industry involves writers, directors, make-up artists, cameramen, actors, lighting technicians, sound technicians and so on-that we would be better served by a much higher level of Australian content. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allowed for consideration of Government papers has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: report No. 24 of 1989-90-Department of Employment, Education and Training-administration of the Austudy program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Austudy has been very laxly administered by this Government, and the Auditor-General's report No. 24 dramatises once again the enormous scope for yet further improvement after two years of making Austudy `less worse', if I can use that expression. This report indicates that something like $40m potential overpayments a year are made to tertiary students alone which could be resolved. I draw heavily on bits of this report to outline the sorts of problems that have existed in Austudy. The report says that the early administration of the Austudy program was unsatisfactory in many respects, especially in relation to the control of fraud and overpayments and in the management of staff and computing resources. The report outlines that these shortcomings, which are largely acknowledged by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, have been addressed by concerted action taken over the last two years, and it is acknowledged that this action will no doubt result in a substantial reduction in the risk of fraud and overpayment and the more efficient use of staff and computing resources. But the point is that the Department, according to the Auditor-General, also acknowledges that there is considerable scope for further improving the administration of the Austudy program particularly by reducing workload peaks, improving the functionality of the ESAS computer system and the improved program planning and performance monitoring. The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) also identified several areas where urgent management attention was required to rectify continuing shortcomings, in particular, in verifying the continuing eligibility of students receiving assistance and in recovering outstanding overpayments. The report states:

Recoveries administration was the single most neglected area of the Austudy scheme having been virtually completely ignored in the overhaul of procedures for application processing and pre-payment verification checks.
The report goes on:

Additional verification checking and compliance surveys, particularly the sample survey which indicated potential overpayments of at least $40m p.a. to Tertiary students alone, has identified large numbers of overpayments and increased the urgency of the need for management attention.

The Department has agreed with the ANAO's findings and recommendations and has advised of a range of measures that it plans to introduce in 1990 and later years to further improve the administration of the program. That is all very well. We are grateful that the Auditor-General has pointed out how this program has involved ludicrous opportunities for fraud and loss to the taxpayer and that something has been done about it, but the big problem that emerges is one of general principle, and the Auditor-General points out very strongly, quite frankly, that this program, like other programs, was started without any coherent recognition of the need to have proper structures in place to make certain that fraud did not become rampant. I think it is important that this Senate, and the Government in particular, recognise the problems that emerge when a half-baked program is introduced without this kind of protection. The Auditor-General says that the Department did advise the Government that a longer lead-time was required for Austudy implementation. In other words, the Government was warned by the Department that it was not ready to handle this matter in an effective and reasonable way that did not involve the potential for huge losses of public money, of taxpayers' money. The report states:

The implementation timetable approved by the Government was too short to allow adequate system testing and user training and led to some key features not being functional when ESAS commenced operations . . . the imbalance concerned the lack of effective controls to minimise the risk of overpayments which had continued under Austudy from the previous student assistance schemes.
The report went on:

This imbalance was most marked in 1987 when almost total emphasis was placed on getting applicants on pay as quickly as possible in the face of severe system failures and existing verification checking was severely curtailed.

All students will no doubt have been overjoyed that the major concentration was on trying to pay new applicants, but the taxpayers of Australia may not share that view. The multimillions of dollars that appear to have been lost in fraud are a matter of major concern. The long term principle that the Auditor-General pointed out is this:

The need to assess fully the administrative implications of major new policy proposals and to act effectively to implement them cannot be understated. But instances where this has not happened come to notice in other organisations. For example, similar inadequacies in the management of new systems and programs were found and acknowledged in the early administration of the taxation concessions and grants for industry research and development schemes (efficiency audit report tabled in May 1989). Departments need to evaluate new systems and programs to ensure that management controls and accountability issues are fully addressed before they are implemented. The lack of effective management controls itself generates counter behaviour among beneficiaries by encouraging active fraud or passive non-compliance with the conditions of assistance.

Some indication of the effect of applicants' perceptions of the effectiveness, or lack of effectiveness of controls may possibly be drawn from the significant drop in the growth of tertiary Austudy applications experienced in 1989, when much stricter prepayment verification checks were introduced, compared with the previous year. Enrolments in full time tertiary courses at 31 March 1989 were about 8 per cent above corresponding enrolments at 30 April 1988 but applications for tertiary Austudy received by the beginning of April 1989 were only just over one per cent higher than they were in 1988. The Auditor-General concluded:

Departmental program objectives and performance standards need to reflect a balance between ensuring prompt delivery of the benefits and minimising the risks of mis-payment. An appropriate balance is not struck if applicants receive benefits before they have provided reasonable proof of eligibility or if benefits are unduly delayed by an over-emphasis on control.

This is the sort of Auditor-General's report one tends to expect when this Government is administering-I use the word `administering' fairly loosely-programs which involve the handling and the handing out of public money. This Government is so busy buying votes that it does not see as being high on its priorities the requirements the Auditor-General has pointed out of making certain that the taxpayers' money is protected and that these grants do not go to people who are not entitled to them. As Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, I saw this Government deliberately handing out money far and wide, on ludicrous pretexts in many instances, to try to buy votes from interested groups. I commend the Auditor-General for drawing the attention of the Parliament and the Government to the fact that this Government, not in this single instance but as a general rule-in many instances, the Auditor-General says-has not been sufficiently concerned with the protection of the public purse when it has been handing out the taxpayers' money.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989THERAPEUTIC GOODS BILL 1989THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch we were discussing the possible response by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology to the Therapeutic Goods Bill. At that stage some amendments had been circulated by Senator Coulter on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The Government has had the opportunity to consider those amendments and, in consultation with Senator Coulter, has agreed to several of them, not agreed to one or two others, and has modified the wording of one or two others. This has enabled the Bill to be improved in a way acceptable both to the Government and to the Democrats. I believe that it has led Senator Coulter to conclude that he can support the passage of the Therapeutic Goods Bill at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)-particular interest has focused on the residential aged care provisions-honourable senators will be well aware that the main section of the legislation relates to the rights of residents in homes for the aged. It is pleasing that the Opposition agrees with the principle of residents' rights, particularly where the Commonwealth is a funder to the residents in their homes. I understand that the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, Mr Braithwaite, has indicated that he does not disagree with the principle that there should be charters and contracts. He is on record as supporting these measures within the aged care industry. But I believe that it is important that the Parliament move further than an expression of support for the general principles and start the process of the statutory enabling and empowering of those charters and the arrangements that flow under the charter of rights and responsibilities.

As I understood it, during the second reading debate Senator Coulter and Senator Jenkins both expressed the view that the charter would come into effect in April 1990, March or whenever and therefore would have a life of its own before the Senate or, perhaps, the other place-but more likely the Senate-had an opportunity to disallow the charter if it found that it was unacceptable in the main or even in one small part. I would like to make two points. The first is that I do not think that the chambers, particularly the Senate, would underestimate the very great power that this actually reposes in the Senate chamber. The fact is that it can destroy, undermine or completely sabotage the whole project of writing a charter because, if one part is not acceptable to the Opposition and the Democrats, the whole scheme, the whole project, collapses. Therefore, it is a very real incentive for the Government to get it right and to make sure that the charter fulfils the expectations of the residents of aged persons homes, those who provide this service in the community, the Government, the Opposition and the Democrats-and the Independents, for that matter. It is a very powerful incentive for the Government to get the charter right. I believe that this tremendous power of the Senate to disallow the whole of the charter by way of disallowing the regulation, which is the way it is proposed to be brought into force under this legislation, is a very important power that should not be underestimated.

Secondly, I believe that Senator Jenkins and Senator Coulter are incorrect in their projection of a situation where the charter could be devised by the Government over the next few weeks or early in the new year, published by way of regulation and then, as Senator Coulter said, because of the exigencies of elections and so on, which we cannot quite foretell, it might be some time before this chamber reconvened and thus a sitting day appropriate for the disallowance. The Bill provides that the commencement of the charter provisions is 1 July 1990. This allows, I believe, sufficient time for the Parliament to scrutinise it prior to the commencement. That factor is an important one. I picked it up on the car radio listening to Senator Coulter this morning. I believe it gives time to consider the elements of the charter in the early part of next year. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am virtually foreshadowing some of the arguments I would put at the committee stage and perhaps you are quite rightly indicating to me that I should get on with a second reading response. These were points brought up by Senator Coulter in the second reading debate and I just wish to rebut that timetable which led to his indicating greater sympathy for the Opposition's approach that the charter should be subject to affirmative resolution by both Houses of the Parliament.
Senator Coulter also made a point that for persons suffering from Alzheimer's disease the issue of rights and responsibilities is less clear. For example, he talked about wandering dementia patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of rights is not less clear. The interpretation of how you apply those rights is very difficult.

—Of course, it is not envisaged that a person suffering from such a disease would enter into an agreement with the proprietor. A person, generally a relative, being either a guardian or person holding power of attorney, could enter into the agreement with the proprietor on behalf of the resident. Where such persons have no guardian or person with power of attorney, they will be protected by an obligation on the proprietor to comply with the notice in writing made by the Minister and consistent with the terms in the agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sheil expressed a concern about the level of ministerial discretion in relation to the charter and the agreement. I understand that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) over many weeks and months has given extensive commitments to consumers, the industry and the staff of nursing homes to consult on the draft charter and agreement. Further consultations will be conducted in the new year as the drafts are developed, based on the first round of consultations. All groups are aware of this staged process of development and have indicated their willingness to contribute to ensuring that the rights of older Australians in residential aged care are protected.

Senator Sheil also commented on the community visitors to nursing homes and hostel residents and their role. He has sought clarification of that role, as I think Senator Boswell has. Community visitors will not be employees of the Commonwealth and they will not be expected to monitor standards of care in any formal sense. Their primary focus will be one of providing friendship and companionship to those elderly people in nursing homes and hostels who might not otherwise have visitors. However, community visitors would be encouraged to refer any major issues coming to their attention to the appropriate channels. In some instances this could be to the management of the home, at other times to advocacy services or perhaps to the complaints service. The Commonwealth has other established appropriate means of monitoring the standards of care gazetted under section 45d of the National Health Act. Other parts of the legislation deal with the operation of a complaints service and standards monitoring teams. This is not meant to be an identity, by any means, of the functions of the two.

Senator Sheil also made a number of nostalgic references to the good old days before there were standards of care and before the Hawke Government's reform strategy for the aged care area. Senator Sheil cited, by way of example of bureaucratic interference, enforcement of fire controls which closed down old dwellings that had been used as nursing homes. Perhaps the chamber should be reminded of several recent tragic events. In nursing homes in southern Sydney and northern Sydney there were a number of deaths in fires. I have not got the dates of those fires but they were within the last three or four years. I think that was an ill-chosen example that Senator Sheil nostalgically referred to in relation to the very necessary fire controls which are appropriate to ensure the safety of persons in these homes for the aged.

I believe that the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 is a very important piece of legislation. I understand that the Privacy Commissioner, in regard to matters which are of importance to residents, has been given a copy of the Bill and has given the following advice. After considering the proposed amendments in the light of further briefing from staff he regards the draft amendments as generally acceptable and has actually recommended several steps which might be taken by the Department in relation to implementation of various aspects of the residents' rights provision, and these will be taken up.

All in all, there has been a lot of consultation with many organisations. I could list them but it would be tedious to do so. There have been consultations with other bodies, such as the Privacy Commissioner. I believe the legislation before the chamber is a complete and adequate response to the very real needs and concerns that have been recognised in a tripartisan way as being very legitimate concerns and needs. There have been differences, of course, as to the particular method by which these matters might be brought into legislative effect and they are the subject of some amendments to be moved by Senator Boswell at the committee stage. I thank those honourable senators who have indicated that they find the Bill, in principle, a very useful addition to the legislative framework within which we as an Australian community provide the very necessary security and good care for those aged persons in residential care.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

These amendments to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 will ensure that the charter of residents' rights and responsibilities and the agreement to be entered into between the resident and the management of a hostel under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 come back to both Houses of Parliament for scrutiny, debate, amendment if necessary and then approval by both Houses.

As the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) stands, the Minister is empowered to formulate, by instrument, a statement of rights and responsibilities. The charter would then be disallowable-that is, it could only be accepted or rejected in full by both Houses of Parliament. We believe that the charter must come back to Parliament for scrutiny, debate, amendment if necessary, and approval-thus protecting and safeguarding the democratic rights of the people to express their opinion through their elected representatives in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. It will also have the effect of forcing the Government to consult meaningfully with all sectors of the industry.

As regards the agreement between proprietor and resident, as the Bill stands, this is subject to ministerial discretion and not even subject to regulation. Again, we believe that it should come back to the Parliament for debate and amendment if necessary, and then approval.

We move these amendments because we have little faith, based on his past record, in the consultation process of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). The Opposition believes that it is the responsibility of the Minister to report back to Parliament and not hide himself behind regulations and the bureaucracy. If there is no hidden agenda in this legislation, this should be the normal course to be followed.

As I said earlier, our amendments have the support of the Australian Nursing Homes Association (ANHA) and the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations (AAVCA). The Government recognises the ANHA and the AAVCA as the peak bodies representing the nursing homes and hostel industry. More importantly, they even have the support of the Australian Democrats. Indeed, they were represented on the steering committee for the report Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels. These are the organisations nominated by the Government to participate on behalf of providers in the detailed discussions and negotiations on the charter and agreement with the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health. The ANHA and the AAVCA believe that the charter and agreement must come back to Parliament for scrutiny, debate, amendment if necessary, and approval-thus protecting and safeguarding the democratic rights of the people to express their opinion through their elected representatives in the Parliament.

The amendments also have the support of numerous other organisations representing the aged and the industry-the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals, Geriaction, the Association of Self-help Organisations, and groups and nursing associations representing nurses throughout the country. We are discussing the quality of the care or our aged. We are talking about the rights of an individual to be absorbed into a higher quality of care. We believe that our amendments will ensure that.

We want it to be perfectly clear that we agree with the principles of the charter and the agreement. We believe that if the Minister is genuine in his concern for the aged and maintaining that quality of care, he should consult as widely as possible if the charter and agreement are to be the vehicles to show that concern and provide the quality. These amendments not only force that consultation process, but also they provide the parliamentary approval. As I said, the Minister should welcome the process of consultation and approval that we have laid down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pick up briefly several remarks which the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) made a few moments ago in summarising the second reading stage of the debate. I accept what he said in relation to the start-up date. I therefore, in a sense, withdraw what I said about the possibility of the charter coming into force before it would be possible for the Parliament to review it. The other point that the Minister made in relation to the charter being allowed or disallowed in toto, and therefore this chamber having a very powerful ability to impose its will, is a politically naive interpretation of that process. As everybody who has spoken in this debate has said, all honourable senators are in favour of the principle of the charter and the protection of patients' rights. None of us would want to be put in the invidious position of having to disallow the charter in toto if there were just one small but perhaps very important part of it which was found to be unsatisfactory. It is for those reasons that the Australian Democrats support the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's point in relation to Alzheimer's disease seemed to indicate that he has a somewhat unsatisfactory understanding of the nature of the disease, which is a slowly progressive mental deterioration. It is not a question of entering into one form of negotiation with a patient or the patient's representative. The form of negotiation will change over time as the condition of the patient deteriorates. The disease is also marked by long periods when the disease appears to be relatively quiescent: the patient's condition may not deteriorate and then, over a relatively short period, the patient's condition can deteriorate quite markedly, descend to a new plateau and maintain itself there. Each of those stages will be marked by a different relationship between the patient and the nursing staff and between such a patient and another patient. Recognising that this is an incredibly complex situation, we think it is appropriate that the actual form of the charter should come back to the Parliament for very close scrutiny so that as well as it can be got right it will be got right and we will not be left in a situation where we must accept or reject the whole charter in toto without the ability to discriminate one part from another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated some of the arguments that the Government would wish to put in relation to this series of amendments advanced by the Opposition and supported by the Australian Democrats. Basically, it is important to distinguish the personality of the Minister from the process in which we are engaged. I think Senator Boswell expressed some scepticism about the propriety of the way in which the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) might engage in the consultations which will be necessary as a prelude to the formulation of the charter and perhaps questioned his sincerity in relation to his concern for the aged.
—No, I didn't question his sincerity; I questioned his ability to negotiate.

—I think Senator Boswell might have been on the edge of that. Nevertheless, it is important that we formulate the legislation in a way which will be equally apt whoever the Minister happens to be from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a genuine difference between the Government and the Opposition as to whether making the charter by way of regulation, and thus subject to disallowance, is the preferable parliamentary way to go rather than trying to bring the charter into both Houses of the Parliament and seeking its affirmation by a positive and affirmative resolution of each House which would allow for amendment of any clause or clauses in it. I think there is a difference as to methodology. Both methods are an attempt to assert what I think Senator Boswell is trying to achieve; namely, that the elected representatives of the people have a real say in the way in which the charter is finally promulgated and, therefore, effective in so far as the agreements, for example, have to be consistent with the charter.

Perhaps Senator Coulter accused me of being naive. However, I have been a member of this chamber for 11 years and I believe that the power of disallowance is a very powerful weapon which, if properly threatened, if you like, by an Opposition and a Democrat coalition on a particular matter, can lead to and will lead to-it must, if the charter is to be achieved-the sort of consultation which will ensure that the concerns about any clause are dealt with prior to the expiry of, I think, 15 sitting days from the promulgation of the charter by way of regulation. So there is simply a difference between us as to the methodology for asserting Parliament's control over this process.

As I have indicated, under this legislation the charter and any subsequent or consequent agreements depend on its terms and consistent with it cannot come into operation until 1 July 1990. This, once again, indicated good faith on the part of the Government in the sense that nothing will be rushed and sought to be put into effect in a way which either does not allow for sufficient consultation or somehow, given election contingencies next year, would prevent this Parliament from asserting its proper role-particularly this chamber, as a chamber of review-for a long period. That would not be the case; there would be sufficient time. For that reason I believe that the present formula used in this legislation-that is, that the charter be a disallowable instrument and that the agreements referred to be consistent with the charter-ought to be agreed to by the chamber. That is an appropriate and adequate way to go. I therefore urge the Committee to reject Senator Boswell's series of amendments numbered 1 to 10.

These amendments apply to approved operators in relation to approved nursing homes. We propose that the principles that the Minister is enabled by this legislation to lay down in respect of approved operators be brought before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the formulation of the principles and that they be subject to approval by both Houses. If the Minister does not proceed to the formulation of principles and allows the bureaucracy to act, we may well find ourselves in a situation similar to what is happening with the implementation of the Disability Services Act, where the bureaucracy formulates the guidelines and can alter them at whim. We believe it is the responsibility of the Minister to report back to the Parliament and not to hide himself behind regulations and the bureaucracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not find the proposal put forward by Senator Boswell in relation to this matter of the principles very compelling. Once again, I think it is a question of proper interpretation of what might be practically required in order for the Parliament to assert its final review function in relation to these principles. For the Opposition to express a concern that the Minister might act in the absence of the principles and indeed neglect to provide principles is rather an extreme view of the possibilities of the situation. The idea that the Minister could even be well or properly advised by officials without principles being available to them in order to formulate advice for him to act on is really beyond the bounds of what is, in anybody's view, likely to happen.
—It is happening.

—I do not know that it is happening. The fact is that the Minister will always act in accordance with properly published criteria, guidelines and principles. I do not believe that he would be willing to act or even in a sense be able to act without principles which could act as criteria to guide the advice given to him by officials. In the absence of principles, there will be no exercise of the power. I understand-and most of the arguments have already been canvassed-that the Opposition wishes to see these principles subject to affirmation by the Parliament. Once again, I believe that that is not required but as I understand it, the Australian Democrats will support the Opposition's proposal. I simply indicate that the Government cannot support it.
