Clause 26 (Approval of nursing home).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Page 10, paragraph 26 (b), proposed paragraph 40aa (6) (bc) (ii), line 9, after ``Responsibilities'', insert ``in Approved Nursing Homes''.
(16) Page 11, paragraph 26 (e), proposed subsection 40aa (6ba), lines 32 to 37, leave out the proposed subsection.

Our amendments would delete the provision whereby a community visitor may inform an officer of the Department or the proprietor of the relevant nursing home of any matter relating to the provision of nursing home care that comes to the notice of the person including matters brought to the person's notice by a patient. The community visitors to be given all reasonable facilities and assistance in order that they may perform the purposes for which they are appointed under the legislation are not designated in this Bill. No-one knows who they will be or whether they will have a capacity of concern and compassion in entering the home and meeting the residents. Under this legislation, they are given the power to judge the quality of care received by people in nursing homes. This provision in the Bill is especially worrying.

It was our understanding that community visitors were to be the people with an interest in aged care, acting in a volunteer capacity, visiting the friendless and those without families in nursing homes and helping them out with small tasks and small worries. The report Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels in proposing such visitors at no time suggested they would report on the quality of care. There is no suggestion in the Bill as to who will be designated and who they will be. Will they be appointed because of their social justice attitudes or their professional and nursing care qualifications? If it is the latter, there are already sufficient teams in place to monitor the quality of care and the rights of residents. The standard monitoring teams do that job. We do not believe that they should be able to check or report on the provision of nursing home care. Our amendments would have the effect of deleting this provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell's concerns and misgivings about the role of community visitors are rather overdrawn. It is intended that community visitors-even as Mr Braithwaite in the other place used the term-be able to be friends of the friendless; be available to those people who unfortunately do not have either family or some network of caring friends to provide the friendship and companionship, which is obviously very important to their psychological well-being, to their sense of human dignity and a sense of being part of the community. That is not always the case in these sorts of nursing homes. One can be surrounded by people but feel lonely and isolated. The idea, obviously, is that a community visitor will be the primary person to provide that friendship and companionship so essential to the well-being, dignity and sheer enjoyment of life for those persons in the situation I have described.

SPEECH.PARA: They are certainly not employees of the Commonwealth and, as I say, their relationship is not to the Commonwealth as an employee; their relationship is very definitely to the aged person or persons with whom they develop this companionship. Their role is certainly not to become a substitute for those formal bodies which monitor the provision of adequate and quality nursing home care or care to the aged, the frail or the infirm. Nevertheless, one can easily envisage situations where a community visitor is informed by a patient in a nursing home that there is some aspect of the provision of care which is causing a problem. It might simply be a draughty condition, a very hard mattress, or a lack of warmth in the room.

I know Senator Boswell is not suggesting that the community visitor could not pass that concern on. In fact, I think he said that the community visitor would be able to deal with the `small worries' of a patient, which as we know in that sort of situation, can become an obsessive concern which can destroy altogether the quality of life of the aged person who is subjected to, not mistreatment necessarily, but an inadequacy or an unintentional indifference to a particular concern which is perhaps peculiar to that person and which does not fall within the general regime of treatment that is provided, in a good way, to the patients as a whole, as a community.

It seems appropriate that it should be made clear in the legislation that the community visitor is empowered to pass on such a concern, and it really is designed to achieve no more than that. The proposed subsection states:

A person who is a community visitor may inform an officer of the Department of the proprietor of the relevant nursing home of any matter relating to the provision of nursing home care in the nursing home that comes to the notice of the person, including matters brought to the person's notice by a patient.

I think it is sheer commonsense that somebody who is a confidante of an elderly person, and who has the confidence and trust of that elderly person, may in fact be very well placed to help-let us put it positively, not negatively-the proprietor of the nursing home to perceive some inadequacy in the provision of care which is causing hardship, concern or distress to an elderly person who is not quite sure of how, whether, or with what consequences, he or she might approach the providers of that care. If they have confidence and trust in a community visitor, perhaps they will express their concern, which can then be passed on further. Nine times out of ten, I am quite sure that the proprietor of the nursing home would be happy to accommodate and deal with that problem if it is brought to his or her attention.

I quite agree with Senator Boswell-I do not have the explanatory memorandum with me, and I am not sure what is said about this in the second reading speech-that it should be made clear that there is no intention to try to provide a substitute for, or a double-up on, the monitoring teams or the complaints teams. We are trying to provide a sympathetic ear for a frail or aged person. Let us hope that the suggestions that come out of that companionship between the community visitor and the old person lead to the provision of better care. I am sure it would suit the proprietors and fulfil their hopes in providing a service that that can be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment 16, in particular, is an amendment which could be read both ways, as the Minister has indicated. In view of the fact that these visitors will have some official status-despite what the Minister says, they will be paid a fee and selected and trained in a certain way-they will have some standing. I accept what the Minister has said in relation to the friendship which such a visitor would have with patients. I also accept that in most instances they would be passing on relatively trivial matters in terms of the overall activity of the nursing home, although they may not be trivial in terms of the comfort of the individual patient.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the community visitors can report in the way indicated by the unamended clause, what is the status, not of the visitor but of the reports which the visitor may make? Is it envisaged that those reports could be used in some way which was not really intended, in order to improve the quality of delivery of care to the individual patient? The visitor is visiting the individual patient. Is it in any way envisaged that these reports could become part of a dossier in relation to the assessment of the nursing home overall? I think that is the sort of thing that is worrying Senator Boswell. These people are in no sense competent to make those sorts of judgments. Perhaps we can resolve this matter now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised-and I think it is consistent with what I have said, that no community visitor can substitute himself or herself for the monitoring or complaints teams-that in fact the sorts of matters that they will pass on will be simply in terms of advice and concerns. They will not form part of the assessment which could determine the renewal, I suppose, of the authority of the proprietors to continue to operate the nursing home concerned. I agree with Senator Boswell: they are not qualified to make a formal assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I could undertake that in the papers which accompany the appointment of a community visitor, that division of function and the non-identification with the complaints and monitoring teams be made very clear, so that there is a very clear statement in the selection and appointment of the community visitor that honourable senators' conerns in that respect are not well founded and that the complaints do not form part of any formal assessment of the operation of the nursing home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate has given us an assurance of what he believes will happen. But with the best will in the world, Senator Tate is unable to give that assurance if the legislation spells out something different. The legislation states very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who is a community visitor referred to in paragraph (6) (cg) may inform an officer of the Department or the proprietor of the relevant nursing home of any matter relating to the provision of nursing home care in the nursing home that comes to the notice of the person, including matters brought to the person's notice by a patient.

We do not want to be dogmatic about that and say that the visitor should not convey some concerns to a proprietor. What we are saying very clearly is that there are already teams doing this job. These teams have the relevant qualifications and are trained to perform these duties. We do not know who these community visitors will be. They may be merely people who have a community concern but who have no qualifications. It is not spelt out in the legislation. We are concerned, and I think Senator Coulter also expressed concern, that these people may not be qualified. They may think they see things that are really not there and report those not only to the proprietor but also to the Department. We believe this could get out of hand. That is why I believe that our amendment is the correct way to go.

There are State and Federal monitoring teams who do the job. The Government is now duplicating their role with a person who may not have any qualifications. That person may be simply a nice woman or man who has a few hours to spare and who feels that she or he wants to perform a community duty. We are concerned about any lack of qualifications by such persons. I am sure that the Minister can see the dangers, as can Senator Coulter. I ask that this amendment be accepted by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be a three-way misunderstanding. I stress again, it is not a question of the status or training of the person. I think we are all agreed that that person in this capacity is not qualified in relation to the judgment of the nursing home as such. The argument really swings on the status of any report which that visitor may make, and whether that report-as I think Senator Tate was beginning to pick up-can be made as part of the judgment of the nursing home as such.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be prepared to accept an undertaking from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that clause 26 remains in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, but that any reports which are made, are made only with respect to the better treatment and management of that individual patient. They do not, and cannot, form-as I think Senator Tate was moving on to say, and this should be spelt out in the agreement with the visitor-part of the assessment of the nursing home. The status of the reports or information that might be passed on to officers of the Department of Community Services and Health, proprietors and so on-but, particularly, the officers of the Department-is, I think, the point that is worrying Senator Boswell. The problem can be overcome by such an undertaking from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Tasmania-Minister for Justice) (4.41)-On behalf of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) I give an undertaking that the documentation surrounding the appointment of a community visitor should be made extremely clear in order to differentiate the role and status of complaints or observations which they forward for action, in order to alleviate the immediate problem or distress of the person with whom they have developed a friendship or companionship. It is more important from Senator Coulter's point of view, and from Senator Boswell's point of view-I think he is putting forward these matters in good faith-that administrative devices be created to ensure that the reports do not attain the sort of status that they would have if they were the reports of a complaints or standards monitoring committee. I am sure that can be accommodated within the structure of the Department and in relation to the activities of these community visitors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly indicate that I accept the Minister's assurance on these two particular amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Boswell's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Committee for the delay, which has been occasioned by my late instructions to the draftsmen about proposing an amendment to clause 2. SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, clause 2, lines 6 and 7, leave out the clause, insert the following clause;
Commencement
``2. This Act commences on the day after the day on which a House of the Parliament approves regulations made under this Act in the same form as they are approved by the other House, provided that:
(a) not more than 90 days have elapsed; and
(b) the places of Senators have not become vacant under section 13 of the Constitution; and
(c) a dissolution or expiration of the House of Representatives has not occurred, between the approval of one House and the approval of the other House.''.

This is a procedural device in relation to the commencement date of the Therapeutic Goods Act. It will provide that the Act will not come into effect until the date on which both Houses of Parliament have approved the regulations to be made under the Act. We have had considerable debate during the course of today on the whole thrust of the Therapeutic Goods Bill. In some respects, the primary criticism has been that the Bill cannot be effectively judged in the absence of the regulations which will be necessary to give effect to all of the provisions in relation to the licence, manufacture, sale, export, import and certification of prescribed therapeutic goods.

When we dealt with questions such as the vocational register of general practitioners, honourable senators will recall, the Senate took some steps basically to ensure that a Bill which the Senate had otherwise agreed to should not come into effect until such a time as the Parliament had been able to examine the regulations and, by substantive motion, both Houses of Parliament had either approved or, as in the case of section 10 of the vocational register legislation, until the Senate, by resolution, had approved the regulations. We then saw the regulations. It was only after the Senate passed a positive motion endorsing those regulations that that section of the Act, which had previously been passed, was able to come into effect.

This is a device to ensure that the regulations which are required to be made and which give effect to the substance of this legislation shall be made publicly available and that the whole thrust, the whole regime, which is dependent upon those regulations shall not come into effect until such time as both Houses of Parliament, according to the formula set out in this amendment, have approved the regulations. So this is not a matter of catch-as-catch-can, when regulations become available, having a mechanism for disallowance. In fact, it is a requirement that, if the Act is to be passed, the Governor-General is to assent to it, and it does not come into effect until the regulations have been produced, presented to the Parliament and approved by the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have done that with immigration.

—Senator Jenkins will recall that this morning, during the debate on the legislation, I raised with Senator Ray the fact that a device had been eventually decided upon, in terms of a parliamentary committee looking at immigration regulations, and that this was a first step in getting to a situation in which the Parliament is not constantly asked to pass important pieces of legislation which depend upon having regulations, which regulations have to be taken sight unseen. That is a principle which we are determined to put forward for the Parliament to consider. Honourable senators all round this chamber, including Senator Dunn in her contribution and Senator Coulter in his contribution, made the point about the necessity for the Parliament to have some capacity to see regulations and about the disallowability of regulations in whole and in part. This is a device which now asks those honourable senators who have made so much of this matter to give their adherence to the principle which they have stated is close to their hearts. As a test of integrity, we invite them to now stand by that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that there would be any interference in the operative dates of the legislation, that is, the appropriate operative dates in March and the appropriate operative dates in June or July when the fees matter, which is dealt with separately, comes into effect because quite simply, if the Government is anxious to have these matters dealt with, it will produce the regulations. TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 14, subclause (3), reads:

The Secretary has the power to allow that export. This concerned the Australian Democrats for reasons which I outlined during the second reading debate. —Senator Puplick is quite right. The sense of what I was explaining remains the same, but I confused the order of the words. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 14 (3) has been proposed for amendment in two different versions by the Australian Democrats. The first, a circulated amendment, proposed to remove entirely the role of the Secretary in giving any sort of consent and would have provided a blanket prohibition that `a person must not export therapeutic goods'. There was then some discussion. The Government's position was `Except with the consent of the Secretary, a person must not export therapeutic goods'. There is now a sort of halfway measure: `Except in exceptional circumstances and with the consent in writing of the Secretary, a person must not export therapeutic goods'.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret to say that in some respects the Opposition would have found it easier to live with the first Democrats' formulation because we would have known that there was a distinct prohibition one way or the other or with the Government's unqualified, `except with the consent in writing of the Secretary', leaving it effectively to the discretion of the Secretary without requiring the Secretary to establish what are or are not exceptional circumstances. I take it that it is the Secretary who must be satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances. That is why I was anxious to get the exact wording understood. It is not a matter of `Where the Secretary is satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances'; it is `Except in exceptional circumstances and with the consent of the Secretary'. Who is to determine the exceptional circumstances? It is not as though the Secretary determines that there are exceptional circumstances. This is not a vague concoction of words about something which is warm and fuzzy; it is a piece of legislation subject to the interpretation of the courts. There is an `and' in this clause. So we have a clause that says, `Except in exceptional circumstances and with the consent of the Secretary'. To me, the two things are in fact capable of being judged by different people. Who is to judge whether there are exceptional circumstances?

Hypothesising for a moment, I wish to take action to prohibit the export of a particular therapeutic good. The Secretary has consented in writing, but I challenge that through some Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act or court procedure and say, `I challenge that there were at the time or there are at the time exceptional circumstances, and I ask you, the court, to make a judgment about this because I wish to take some action or some action ought to be taken to prohibit the export of the therapeutic good in question'. I do not contest that there is a consent in writing from the Secretary; I contest that there are exceptional circumstances. Had the amendment said, `Where the Secretary is satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances' or, `The Secretary shall not consent in writing unless he or she is satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances', which would simply have been a matter of the Secretary signing some document to say that he was of the opinion that there were exceptional circumstances and that his discretion, therefore, had been exercised accordingly, then I would have been somewhat more mollified. But the fact is that we now have two tests on foot-the presence of exceptional circumstances and the consent in writing of the Secretary-one test being a matter of fact and the other test being a matter of opinion, whereas previously there was only a question of fact to be determined, which was that a person must not export therapeutic goods from Australia, et cetera, with which I would have been satisfied. Because of those difficulties that I see with the way in which this is constructed, the Opposition will not support the amendment.
