It was made quite clear that those circumstances would indeed be very exceptional. In introducing this amendment, I gave one such circumstance where we may have a vaccine in this country which, indeed, may never be used in this country because the disease may not be here. The particular batch might be the only batch we have. The batch might be below standard and, therefore, not conform. Nonetheless, it may be the only therapeutic agent available, and I certainly would not seek to prevent the export of such an agent.

SPEECH.PARA: Going to the matter raised by Senator Puplick that two tests are required, that is done very deliberately, of course, because it is a check on the Secretary by way of a potential court appeal that the Secretary has not willy-nilly, wilfully, wantonly or in any other respect given permission for the export of such non-conforming goods. So while Senator Puplick is correct in saying that consent in writing is an objective test which can be seen by the courts, nonetheless, the Secretary, in giving that consent, takes into account that other clause `in exceptional circumstances' or `except in exceptional circumstances' and will be guided by the fact that he could be challenged before the courts in relation to the export of a non-conforming therapeutic good. It is precisely for those reasons that the amendment was not written the other way around, in which case the whole matter would simply be dependent on the Secretary, and it is appropriate that we cling to the principle that goods which do not conform to Australian standards should not be exported but, if they are to be exported at all, should be exported only under those very exceptional circumstances which would be rare and unusual. The wording is, therefore, quite appropriate to meet those unusual circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am trying to grasp this particular amendment proposed by Senator Coulter, I agree with both honourable senators that two tests seem to be involved. Indeed, Senator Coulter has quite deliberately tried to remove the judgment of whether there are exceptional circumstances from the Secretary and made it a separate test within the clause which really places an obligation upon a person. So I do not think it is quite true to say that it is the Secretary that must take into account whether there are exceptional circumstances; it is a person who must take that into account in order to escape the penalty. I guess that it would be part of the prosecution of the offence that the prosecution would have to show that there were no exceptional circumstances or, I suppose, at least, that the matter was lying probably within the knowledge of the accused person. It might well be up to the accused person to show that there were exceptional circumstances, but quite clearly all the Secretary has to do is sign a document. Additionally, there have to be exceptional circumstances, and it is only if there are exceptional circumstances that the export is lawful.

SPEECH.PARA: So in that situation I can understand that there are two tests. I wanted to clarify that, indeed, the person who might be subject to the penalty will bear the responsibility of at least making it a live issue, bearing in mind the evidential burden of proof, that there were exceptional circumstances; and then it would be up to the prosecution to show that there were no exceptional circumstances. But, as I say, I am caught a little bit on the hop here. However, I do believe that there are two different elements and the responsibility for ensuring that both are fulfilled fall on, firstly, the Secretary and, secondly, a person who wishes to export.

With that sort of attempted understanding, I believe I understand what Senator Coulter is trying to achieve, and that is that this export of therapeutic goods which do not conform with the required standard, the applicable standard, is extremely rare and should occur only in the most extraordinary circumstances. I understand what he has sought to achieve, and I think that the Government can accept that particular amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. The Minister for Justice is quite right in saying that he has been caught on the hop. We have all been caught on the hop by not having had the opportunity to take all this through, but that happens in the committee stage, and I do not object to that, in exactly the same way that I had to produce my own amendment expeditiously. I believe that what the Minister has said is correct. There will be on the person a reverse onus of proof which, if that matter had been examined by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, undoubtedly would have caused that Committee to report to the Senate about a reverse onus of proof. Matters would have been consequently addressed. The Minister is also correct in saying that we understand what Senator Coulter is attempting to do. We just think that the exact words of the device may lead to more problems than is immediately apparent on the face of it.
—The question is that amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Coulter to clause 14 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Committee, but other preoccupations have prevented my entering this debate thus far. However, in respect of this clause I have just noticed something that takes my attention. I also apologise to the Minister for not giving him notice of this question, which has just occurred to me. I refer to the provisions of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations which relate to abortifacients. Do the provisions of the legislation currently before us in any way affect or impinge upon the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations?

SPEECH.PARA: For example, under those regulations, the abortion drug RU486 is a prohibited import into Australia unless it receives the approval of the Secretary and, under the Secretary's signature, the Secretary has indicated that this would be a matter for reference to the Minister and that it would require the Minister's consideration prior to the Secretary's giving his approval or otherwise. As this is a matter of great controversy and a matter about which I have received certain assurances, I would like to know whether this legislation in any way affects the current provisions of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the current provisions relating to the import or export of abortion drugs, or abortifacients.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not confident that I am in a position to deal with the very complex question that Senator Harradine has raised. I need, perhaps, to get some written advice from the officials as to the way this Bill relates to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. I wonder whether during the next 10 minutes or so I could get some further advice on the matter and try to come back to Senator Harradine while we deal with other matters.
—Is it the wish of the Committee that consideration of clause 14 be postponed?

—It seems to me that Senator Harradine has asked a somewhat more general question in relation to this legislation. I do not think it bears particularly on clause 14, although subclause 14 (1) does talk about imports. Senator Harradine's is a more general question about the areas of intersection between the two pieces of legislation. I think we should deal with this amendment and move on and, as Senator Tate has indicated, come back and get his reply at any stage during the debate.

—Nevertheless, the Chair intends to proceed to clauses 15 to 32. Senator Tate has indicated that he will come back with an answer. When that answer is available we will deal with the amendment and clause 14.

—An amendment was before the chamber. No vote has been taken to defer that amendment. It seems extraordinary that we should be put in this situation. The amendment was being debated. A different matter was raised-quite properly-by Senator Harradine. But it has nothing to do with this amendment. I think this amendment should be put. The clause can be held over in the normal way until we come back to it.
—The Chair is in the hands of the Committee on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the answer to Senator Harradine's problem may not lie in reference back to clause 7, namely, that the Secretary may declare that a particular good or a particular class of good is not a therapeutic good for the purposes of the Therapeutic Goods Act. In other words, if the Secretary were to declare that a particular good or a particular device was not a good or device for the purposes of this Act, that would solve Senator Harradine's problem. However, I am not in the business of attempting to solve Senator Harradine's problem. That is the Minister's responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: For the sake of expediency I urge upon the Committee that we vote on and dispose of Senator Coulter's amendment in relation to clause 14 (3). It will carry, and then perhaps clause 14 as a whole could be put to one side while the Minister deals with this matter so that we can at least get Senator Coulter's amendment out of the way because it is unaffected by the question Senator Harradine has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Harradine I indicate to the Committee that that has indicated to me that the same course would be appropriate. I call Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that Senator Coulter's proposal had been disposed of.
—No.

—I was under that impression. I would be happy to see it disposed of and for the Committee, having regard to how the Minister may respond to the general question that I raised, to give me time to consider that position.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, postponed.
Clauses 15 to 32-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 33 (Publication of list of goods on Register).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 23, clause 33, lines 4 to 6, leave out the clause and insert the following clause:
``33. The Secretary must publish a list of the therapeutic goods included in the Register not less than once every twelve months.''.
This is an extremely straightforward amendment. The Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 as printed says:
The Secretary may, from time to time and in such a manner as the Secretary determines, publish a list of the therapeutic goods included in the Register.
The Australian Democrats are merely seeking that there should be a regular, at least once a year, publication of that register, so the clause would read:
The Secretary must publish a list of the therapeutic goods included in the Register not less than once every twelve months.
In view of the importance of this register as a repository of information in relation to registered goods, we feel that the amendment is entirely defensible and commend it to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports Senator Coulter's amendment on this occasion. We agree that the idea of having a register published at least every 12 months is correct. I have perhaps lost some touch with the draftsman's art as to why `must' appears to have replaced `shall' in all of these amendments. I suppose there is some appropriate reason buried within the bosom of the Clerk or the draftsmen or somebody about that. Nevertheless, the amendment has the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply wish to indicate that the Government finds a lot of merit in this amendment moved by Senator Coulter and will support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 34 to 49-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 50 and 51-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 32, paragraph 50 (4) (d), line 23, leave out ``one month'', insert ``one week''.
(2) Page 33, after subparagraph 51, after subparagraph 51 (5) (a) (ii), insert the following subparagraph:
``(iia) tell the authorised person the day (not more than one week after the magistrate completes and signs the warrant) on which the warrant ceases to have effect; and''.

In relation to these clauses, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum. The amendments alter clauses 50 and 51 of the Bill, which relate to warrants designed for the seizing of evidence. The amendments give effect to Government policy in relation to search and seizure warrants, which is that the period of validity of such warrants should be no longer than one week. I believe that they also follow a Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggestion, so indeed one has a meeting of the minds of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the Government in relation to these amendments. I commend them to the Committee.
Amendments agreed to.
Clauses, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 52 to 58-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 59 (Fees).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) page 36, after subclause 59 (2), add the following subclause:
``(3) No licence fees or inspection fees are to apply to non-profit public hospital supply units.''.

The situation that this amendment deals with is one which may well apply in a number of States. Certainly, I am aware of it applying in Tasmania, where the bulk dispensing of a number of prescriptions is carried out in a central dispensary, so that dispensary is in fact manufacturing larger than just one-off quantities of prescribed materials. These prescriptions are in the nature of extemporaneous prescriptions which are used by a number of patients and therefore it is more convenient for the dispensary to manufacture them in bulk. It is a cost saving measure by the hospitals which clearly should not be subject to a licence fee or inspection fee.

It is possible that in a number of other circumstances hospitals or groups of public hospitals may manufacture such things as dressings and the like and therefore would be manufacturing therapeutic goods. Again this would be a cost saving measure, something that could easily be carried out within the individual hospital, but for various reasons it has been found more convenient to do it in bulk. Again these activities, while they involve manufacturing therapeutic goods in the strict sense of the word, should not be subject to licence fees or inspection fees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two points arise in relation to the words `non-profit public hospital supply units'. Why should this be confined to public hospital supply units? The questions are whether this is a non-profit supply unit, whether it is a public hospital which is supposed to be non-profit, what is the situation of private hospitals, whether they are profitable or not profitable, and why should there be any degree of discrimination against supply units which supply therapeutic goods to both public and private hospitals?

SPEECH.PARA: I would have no difficulty at all if the amendment were `no licence fees or inspection fees are to apply to hospital supply units' but the qualification which is now introduced-non-profit public-causes me considerable concern. Some people are in private hospitals because they have paid the necessary insurance premiums, because they are taken there in an emergency or, most importantly, because they choose to be there. The question of whether a unit which supplies therapeutic goods should find itself subject to the payment of a licence fee or an inspection fee if it supplies private hospitals but exempt from payment of that fee if it supplies non-profit public hospitals is a discrimination that the Opposition is not prepared to countenance. Therefore, we will not be in a position to support Senator Coulter's amendment-not because we object to the removal of the licence fee or the inspection fee for those particular units but because of the discrimination which is introduced as to why those units should be exempt only if they are supplying non-profit public hospitals. To that extent we are not prepared to accept that form of discrimination.

Senator Coulter may not have intended to discriminate in that fashion but the Senate is entitled to know whether both Senator Coulter and, more to the point, Senator Tate are now saying that supply units which relate to the provision of goods and services to private hospitals are to be discriminated against. In particular, I want to hear what Senator Tate has to say. Senator Coulter may have a position on this. People in the private hospital sector are entitled to know whether Senator Tate and his Government are deliberately exempting some suppliers from fees and charges and deliberately imposing them on others. People in the private hospital sector are entitled to know what the Hawke Government's view is about the discrimination between public and private hospital suppliers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed clause 59 (3) of the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 was attempting to give an advantage to-if you like, to discriminate in favour of-non-profit hospital supply units. Certainly I would be quite happy to take out the word `public'. I believe that the discrimination between public and private is not intended, was not important and was not really the thought that lay behind the drafting of this clause. The clause was intended to help hospital supply units which acted in a public or charitable context rather than in a profit-making context. I would certainly be happy if Senator Coulter were to delete the word `public' so that proposed subclause 59 (3) were to read:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) No licence fees or inspection fees are to apply to non-profit hospital supply units''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy with that. I will be interested to know whether Senator Puplick knows of any hospitals that fall into the category which he has outlined. I am certainly not aware of any but that is not to say they do not exist. The intention of the amendment is to cover the manufacturing of things which, in a one-off situation, say, in a pharmacy or single hospital, would not come under this legislation but, because of the arrangements to cut costs-the amalgamation of, say, a number of prescriptions into a bulk supply-become a manufacturing operation. If that is the intention I see no reason why that operation should then be caught up within this legislation. I am very happy to delete the word `public' if that meets Senator Puplick's objection so that it reads `apply to non-profit hospital supply units'.
—Is leave granted to remove the word `public' from the amendment? There being no objection, the amendment is altered accordingly.

—We are now halfway there. The question now is why should the amendment apply only to non-profit hospitals. I would be grateful if the Minister for Justice could advise why a supply unit which supplies therapeutic goods to a hospital which makes a profit will be subject to licence fees whereas a supply unit which supplies therapeutic goods to a hospital which does not run at a profit, or runs at a loss, is exempt from the fee.

—To delete that further qualifier would simply create such an enormous loophole right in the midst of the legislation that it would be impossible to stick with the rest of it at all. We must draw a line somewhere. Clearly a profit oriented hospital could begin by dispensing on a small scale and legitimately for its own use in the way that I have indicated with bulk manufacture. Clearly if it became profitable it would move on and could operate in a much bigger way. To remove those words, it seems to me, would put such a hole in the legislation that it would be quite impossible to continue with the rest of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —So in other words, a unit operating as part of a hospital which makes a profit, which is big enough to supply goods to a non-profit hospital, pays the fee. Although the beneficiary could otherwise be the non-profit hospital, the fact that the supply unit is within a hospital which is a profit-making organisation means that it becomes subject to the licence fee, the cost of which presumably it passes on to its other customers.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect, Mr Chairman, I think this is part of the difficulty of taking a lot of these things on the run. The Minister is obviously acquiescent in the Democrat amendment. It has been negotiated between the Democrats and the Minister or the Minister's advisers, or the Minister in the other place or his advisers. We are to have a situation in which a hospital which runs efficiently and perhaps makes a profit-heavens above, one would hope that that is not yet a cardinal sin-is to be subject to these penalties of licence fee or inspection fee whereas the non-profit or loss-making hospital is encouraged to remain in that status in order to avoid payment of the fee.

I understand where the balance of numbers lies in this matter. However, I think this is an unnecessary discrimination. It seems to me that there should be no reason why, if we are to have this exception, it should not simply be that no licence fee or inspection fee is to apply to hospital supply units. It seems to me that that is what we ought to be seeking to achieve. We ought to be seeking to achieve support for the hospital system. Whether they are public, private, profit-making or non-profit-making is not relevant to the question that the licence or inspection fee should not apply to hospital supply units.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw Senator Puplick's attention to an amendment which we intend to move to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill in which we have attempted to pick up the matter which he raised. Although the amendment was not drafted with this object in mind, clearly it would cover this circumstance. The amendment seeks to insert the following subclause:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the regulations shall provide that annual charges in respect of the registration or listing of therapeutic goods are not payable by persons whose turnover of those goods is of low volume and low value.

TALK.START.PARA: —Persons? Since when is a public hospital a person?

—Perhaps Senator Tate can correct me here, but I would have thought that `persons' covers both natural and other persons. In those circumstances, there is the option for a hospital producing a low volume for its own internal use to attract a very low charge or no charge at all. If that organisation were to move on from that, clearly it could not use the provisions as a loophole and continue under the guise of being a hospital-providing unit, to be free of licence fees or inspection fees. I ask Senator Puplick to look at the other amendment because it seems to me that it could cover the very circumstance that seems to be worrying him.
—Does the Minister wish to respond?
—Not at this stage, Mr Chairman.
—Do I take it that the Minister does not have a response on whether profit-making or non-profit-making hospitals are to be the object of this clause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not think that I needed to supplement the answer given by Senator Coulter, whose amendment this is and to which, I must admit, I have agreed on behalf of the Government, with the further amendment, which he has agreed to, to delete the word `public'. It is not a question of a penalty being imposed on a profit-making hospital or a hospital unit designed to make a profit. It is a question of a proper licence or inspection fee being imposed but being waived in a case where a hospital supply unit is not set up or designed to achieve a surplus of revenue over its operating costs. That, I guess, is the understandable basis for Senator Coulter's proposal; that those organisations which are not set up in a way which is designed to achieve a surplus should be able to have the benefit of a waiver whereas those which are designed to achieve a profit can take into account their own fee structure-in other words, the fees they charge those who use their services-and the licence or inspection fees in trying to achieve a surplus of a particular magnitude.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.33 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) two questions as this relates to amended clause 59 as agreed to by the Government. Does the waiver of licence or inspection fees apply to non-profit hospitals which have supply units or to non-profit hospital supply units?
—I am advised that in discussions with Senator Coulter the terminology was adopted in order to refer to those non-profit hospitals which have supply units within their operations.
—I am grateful for the Minister's advice that the licence or inspection fee would have related to the hospital. I now ask him: What is a hospital supply unit?
—It embraces a manufacturing unit within a hospital which supplies therapeutic goods to other hospitals within the area.
—So, the supply unit is not simply to supply the single hospital to which it relates but both manufactures and supplies to other than its own parent institution?
—I understand that that is correct.

—I wonder whether I might intrude. This could apply to either situation. It could apply to a hospital in which part of the process of manufacturing was not on a single patient basis but was supplying to that hospital, or it could apply to several hospitals having come together for the purposes of manufacturing. I do not see why the Minister should say that it should apply only to the situation where one hospital supplies to another or a unit supplies to several hospitals. I see nothing in the definition of `manufacturing' which would exclude the situation in which one hospital was simply supplying for its own purposes.

—I am advised that the description I gave was more the norm than an exclusive category of those which might fall within the definition in this particular subclause. So Senator Coulter is correct. But the description I gave was of that situation which would normally be the case. If I misled the Committee to any extent in not making that clear, I regret that.

—This is getting absolutely Gilbertian. Earlier in the day Senator Coulter spoke about a paradox and I was reminded about a song regarding a most ingenious paradox in The Pirates of Penzance. I am now reminded of the song in The Mikado which goes along the lines, `You are right and I am right and all is right', et cetera. The fact is that Senator Coulter clearly intended one thing and the Minister clearly intended what he now describes as the `norm' to be something else, and undoubtedly for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act the courts will find themselves absolutely bemused at reading the debate in order to try to ascertain precisely what the Parliament might or might not have meant with regard to all of this. Since explanatory memoranda are always written in a particular fashion, I ask Senator Tate to tell us what financial impact the Government expects as a result of this licence waiver arrangement and how many hospital supply units he thinks there are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to correct the implication of what Senator Puplick has said. This wording was not intended for particular purposes in relation to the explanation I just gave. It was intended for certain purposes and the words clearly would apply to a certain range of things. I outlined in my second reading speech the situation in Tasmania where a number of hospitals had come together and established a central supply for the purposes of pharmaceutical manufacturing. Clearly that situation obtains over a reasonable number of public hospitals in Australia, both with respect to pharmaceuticals and, I would suspect, with respect to sterile supplies of a number of other therapeutic goods.

SPEECH.PARA: In drawing up the words, quite clearly one has to be careful that one does not make the terms too wide or, indeed, exclude those very things that one wants to include. The explanation that I gave earlier was simply intended to indicate that, quite apart from the intention, the words, as far as I can see, would apply to the single hospital. Whether there are single hospitals in that situation, or how many hospitals there are, I am not aware. But I would have thought that the numbers were not all that large and I would have thought that the question of fees would be largely irrelevant because this is a new piece of legislation which imposes fees for something which formerly did not attract fees. The fact that those particular operations in public hospitals continue to attract no fees does not have any implications in terms of the Budget at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to answer Senator Puplick's question as regards to the number of hospital supply units. I am advised that the licence fee would be in the region of $3,500 and the inspection fee would be in the region of $3,000 per year. That gives Senator Puplick some idea of the amounts of money that would be involved. I do not know how many times one would need to multiply those amounts to get the exact financial impact, but it is quite clear that it would not be a huge amount of money within the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 60 to 62-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 63 (Regulations).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 40, after subclause 63 (3), insert the following new subclause:
``(3a) The regulations must provide for the waiving of fees or charges in cases where turnover of goods is less than 1000 units a year.''.

When the original raft of amendments was circulated by Senator Coulter, the Opposition parties had a look at them as best we were able within the resources and confines of time available to us. There were originally five amendments proposed by Senator Coulter, the fifth of which was in exactly the terms which I have just read out-to insert a new subclause (3a) into clause 63, reading:
The regulations must provide for the waiving of fees or charges in cases where turnover of goods is less than 1000 units a year.

The chamber may recall that during the second reading debate Senator Coulter made particular reference to the impact which a system of fees and charges would have in relation to smaller operations and producers of goods of a particularly specialised nature where the number of goods produced might not be large. I do not want to anticipate the brief comments which will be made in relation to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill to which Senator Coulter will be moving a proposed amendment dealing with the turnover of goods of low volume and low value. I will come to that in due course, because it really should read low volume or low value.

The essence of this argument is that the Opposition, when looking at the proposed amendments of the Australian Democrats, found them attractive. I had some consultation with my colleague Mr Shack from Western Australia who, as you will know, Mr Temporary Chairman, is the shadow Minister for health. We were attracted to this Democrat amendment which was then amendment No. 5. It disappeared as part of the raft and package in the negotiations which took place between the Democrats and the Government at an earlier stage today. We believe that the regulations should provide for the waiving of fees and charges in cases where turnover of goods is less than 1,000 units a year, because of the high-tech, low volumes, particularly for start-up companies which I am concerned with, and I know Senator Coulter is concerned with as they featured during his remarks in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clause was withdrawn not for any sinister motive or double dealing but simply to shift it into the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill, and we will be dealing with that amendment in a moment. I wish to deal with the words in this amendment which are different from those in the other amendment. I will pick this up as Senator Puplick has already moved this amendment. There was a problem with the figure of 1,000 units or less in that, first of all, the figure is arbitrary and, secondly, the value of those units may, indeed, be quite high. One might have quite a small production run but a very high value and, clearly, in that situation a fee could be chargeable.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation which that amendment sought to address, and which is now addressed in the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill, is the one in which the profit flowing from the sale of those goods would be low because the volume of the goods would be low and the value of the goods would be low, hence, the words which have been carried over into this other amendment. I am advised that the more appropriate place for this amendment is in the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill and that is the reason it has been shifted. I seek the assurance of the Minister that that is the appropriate place to achieve this end. I think, from what Senator Puplick has said, that we are all agreed that it is desirable that those companies which produce a range of items of low volume, or those start-up companies which have not yet become very profitable, should be provided with a system under the regulations whereby the charges can be waived or kept to a very low level.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is more attracted to Senator Coulter's formulation of what various senators around the Committee have in mind. If one looks to a production figure of less than 1,000 units, quite clearly one could have, for example, 900 pacemakers being produced in a particular manufacturing facility worth $3,000 or $3,500 each. Obviously that would be quite a substantial business. It is probably for that reason that Senator Coulter decided to abandon the figure of up to 1,000 units and to go for a more flexible description which allows us to give the relief which everyone considers would be useful and desirable but which does not allow, by some sort of artificial simple counting, for those organsations or manufacturing units which can well afford to pay not to pay. There is no reason why they should not be subject to the normal requirements of payment under the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is precisely for the reason that Senator Tate has just indicated that the Opposition is attracted to this idea of 1,000 units. The example of pacemakers is perhaps the most useful that Senator Tate could have given in terms of bolstering the case which the Opposition wishes to put forward. The likelihood of Australia's being competitive in international markets in goods which are of low value is much smaller than the competitive advantage that we will have in goods that are of a similar value to units such as pacemakers. It is unlikely that we will have an export advantage in goods which are not only of low value but also of low volume.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of low value when we are in the marketplace competing against manufacturers who have advantages of proximity to international markets, who do not have the transport, communications and shipping difficulties that this country still faces but who have the advantages of comparative labour costs, the very area in which we are likely to have advantage is for goods which have some value such as the range of pacemakers, the production of Nucleus Ltd and various others, which we ought specifically to be seeking to encourage. It was for that reason that we were attracted to the proposition to move away from the test of low value-whatever that means. What does low value mean? What is low? How low is low before the Government decides that a product will be tax exempt? How long is a piece of string? How low is low: as low as the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about children living in poverty? Is that how low the value has to get before it becomes a test?

Senator Walsh has to determine these things ultimately, I guess. The Department of Finance eventually will determine what is low value in Senator Walsh's terms. Goodness me, the idea of asking somebody who would make one of the central figures of A Christmas Carol appear as a munificent benefactor of the human race to determine what is to be low value in terms of these regulations is a nonsense. It was for that purpose that we were attracted to Senator Coulter's original proposition of an objective test. One thousand units is 1,000 units. Even Senator Walsh can count. Even Senator Tate who does not pretend to be an economic literate can count to a thousand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Slowly.

—Indeed, slowly-and undoubtedly in Latin. The capacity to have an objective evaluation of 1,000 units, rather than low value, low volume, was what attracted us to Senator Coulter's amendment. While pursuing these almost theological questions, Senator Tate undoubtedly takes comfort in the fact that Senator Coulter has been struck by the bolt of lightning on the road to Damascus and has decided to abandon his commitment. Nevertheless, we are going to persist with putting forward the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations must provide for the waiving of fees or charges in cases where turnover of goods is less than 1,000 units. . . .
We earnestly entreat the Australian Democrats to vote for their own amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I just cannot let Senator Puplick get away with that. I suggest that he perhaps go away and try his long division in Latin figures. He might come back in three weeks' time and be better informed of the difficulty that the Romans had with their mathematics.
—I think they managed quite well as builders.

—Yes, and they had Pythagoras and so on to get their buildings square, too. But the reasons that this amendment is not being proceeded with in this Bill is quite simply that the purpose for which the amendment was originally put forward-it never got to the stage of being moved by us-is being taken up in another Bill in a more appropriate place, where we are proceeding with the purpose of that amendment. We are doing it in a more appropriate way and in a more appropriate Bill.

—All I can say in relation to the historical comment-and my pride as a historian is wounded on this occasion-is that, if that is the best of the argument, Senator Coulter reminds me of Disraeli's wife. Disraeli said that his wife was altogether an admirable woman. Her only trouble was that she could not remember which came first-the Greeks or the Romans.

—I do not want to prolong the argument because I think we might be nearing the end. But it is important to note that we are talking about a regulation making power in Senator Coulter's amendment to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill. In that case, it will not be Senator Walsh who will be making the determination as to the exact quantum of those terms. It will be the Parliament itself, when it has the regulations before it. I think it is an important matter.
—It must be the silly season, but really it was a Pythagorean theorum which the Romans used to square their buildings.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite honourable senators to festina lente.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the amendment (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very properly raised with me that, as a result of the amendment which the Committee has made to clause 2-namely, in relation to a commencement date of the operations of the Therapeutic Goods Bill-there may have been the need for some consequential amendment to be made. As a result of the passage of clause 2, the Act would not come into effect until regulations had been approved, but regulations may or may not have been able to be made under an act because the Act had not, in fact, come into effect. Potentially we had a logical difficulty there about making regulations under an Act which itself had to wait before it came into effect for certain things to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: However, through the courtesy of the Clerk, my attention has been drawn to section 4 of part 2 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 which is headed `Exercise of certain powers between passing and commencing of Act'. Having looked at that, it appears to me that the potential difficulties, which were originally brought to our attention about the operations of the regulation making process as a result of the insertion of clause 2 in the Bill, do not need to be addressed. I had, again by courtesy of the Clerk, an amendment drawn which would have provided:

`For the purposes of section 2, regulations may be made before the commencement of this Act as if this Act were in force, but do not come into effect on a day earlier than the day on which the Act commences.

I believe that that is not necessary. Therefore, I will not be pursuing that amendment because I believe that the provisions of section 4 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 adequately provide for that situation. I believe, therefore, that further amendment to clause 63 is not necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick has raised a very interesting and difficult point. Obviously, there is a logical difficulty-the chicken and the egg question. I am persuaded by the honourable senator-and he is relying on the Clerk, who apparently has made an examination of this matter over the last several hours-that the Acts Interpretation Act covers the situation and permits the regulations to be made. That would allow the Act to come into force if those regulations are approved. I am a little anxious. I do not know whether we should ask Senator Puplick to surrender his piece of paper. I might adopt his amendment and, out of an abundance of caution, insert it in the statute anyway. If it is surplus to requirements, it cannot do any harm. Perhaps the Clerk could indicate whether that is right.
—I will answer for the Clerk. The answer is no.
—As I said earlier, this is a novel procedure and I have been proved correct; it is novel to take the regulations up in the way that the Opposition has proposed. So just to protect ourselves, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 41, after subclause 63 (4), insert the following subclause:

``(5) For the purposes of section 2, regulations may be made before the commencement of this Act as if this Act were in force, but do not come into effect on a day earlier than the day on which this Act commences.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the basis that belt and braces, I presume, cannot do any harm, having earlier this evening established the principle that amendments drawn by one person ought at least be pursued by that same person even if the argument has been overtaken, the Opposition does not have any objection to the Minister's abundance of caution in the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Remainder of Bill, other than postponed clause 14-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the remainder of the Bill, repeal and transition provisions, particularly to deal with some remarks that were made by Mr Tickner in the other place in the second reading debate when, very simply, he alleged that I, whom he described as a prominent member of the front bench, was on the public record as being flatly and diametrically opposed to the views that had been expressed by the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Tangney, Mr Shack. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In common with me, those two members, namely Senator Bishop and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), were members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry into therapeutic goods, which amassed six volumes of evidence and which formed a damning indictment on the control by successive Australian Governments--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, we are dealing with the remainder of the Bill. Which particular clause are you referring to?
—I am referring to the remainder of the Bill, which deals with the repeal of the former Therapeutic Goods Act 1966 and makes way for the new legislation.
—Are you referring to clause 64 and clause 65?
—I think that is all that is left.
—There are other clauses.
—Yes. I am referring to clauses 64 and 65.
—Senator Bishop, you may make your remarks relevant to clauses 64 and 65.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Very simply, the Opposition's view and my view is that the principle of establishing a unified national system of control over the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic products is supported by both the Liberal and national parties and the industry. That is not to say, however, that the Bill as it has come forward, with regulations being a substantial part of the enactment, is in any way satisfactory to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, Mr Tickner went to great lengths while addressing the laudable nature of the Bill which is replacing the 1966 Act to say that the Public Accounts Committee was the foundation of the replacement Bill. Quite frankly, that is a patent misrepresentation, in that the Public Accounts Committee strives at all times to arrive at a report to which all members of the Committee can put their names. Mr Tickner and I, in the course of the debate on the report, were at opposite ends of the spectrum; it is a wonder the debate was not heard in another State. For him to allege that somehow I would support his view of the interpretation of the Act as underpinning the worthwhileness of the replacement legislation, the Bill we are presently debating, is totally and utterly misleading.

The recommendations were couched in such language as to accommodate the vastly differing points of view within the Public Accounts Committee, which, as I said, strives to bring in a unanimous report. Mr Tickner's views and mine were as diverse then as they are now. Again, I place on record my singular exception to the number of times in which he invokes my name and that of Mr Ruddock-though Mr Ruddock can speak for himself. I find his comments both offensive and angering. We simply came together with a view that there should be a unified national system of control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, Senator Bishop is almost making a personal explanation. I do not want to interrupt the flow of the honourable senator, but it may be that the type of contribution she is making could be made on the third reading, although I do not want to invite her to do that. I cannot let it go without making some protest, although I will not ask the Chair to rule on it. It seems to me that Senator Bishop is drawing a very long bow in trying to relate her remarks to the clauses before the Committee.
—I understand that Senator Bishop is talking to clauses 64 and 65, which refer to the former Act and the repeal of it. I ask her to confine her remarks to that subject.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. In the previous Therapeutic Goods Act, there was a clear power for the Commonwealth to enforce legislation concerning pharmaceutical goods and there was clearly no distinct power for the Commonwealth to deal with devices. Indeed, the manner in which the replacement Bill is drafted is such that there is reliance on the corporation's power. I suspect that, whereas the 1966 Act relied on the powers as described here, the law of the Commonwealth relating to the provision of pharmaceutical and repatriation benefits for pharmaceutical evaluation and all the things that flow from that, the bringing in of regulations in the way that the Bill contemplates is really waiting for a ruling from the High Court to see whether or not the Commonwealth has the power to deal with devices. For that reason, devices are not dealt with in this Bill as they were in the 1966 Bill: they relied on the Customs power to deal with imported goods. It is important to remember, in saying that the Public Accounts Committee recommended that there be fresh legislation and that the old Act be repealed, that that is in no way to say that the people who subscribed their names to that report were giving some blessing to the Bill presently before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Several clauses in the Public Accounts Committee report required consultation with the States and that there be no cross-subsidisation for any of the categories likely to occur in the regulations. Use was to be made of comparable overseas valuations, and there was nothing to suggest that the manner in which the Commonwealth had operated in creating five categories of devices under the old Act was in fact unsatisfactory. Other speakers in this debate have pointed out that the charges which are going to be imposed via the regulations and by the subsequent Bill will indeed impede our export industries. Those have been adequately dealt with. The important thing is that Mr Tickner tried to say that the Public Accounts Committee report underpinned every aspect of the Bill before us and I chose to make my remarks concerning the repeal of the old Bill. In doing so I am drawing the Committee's attention to the question of whether the Commonwealth will ultimately have power to enact the legislation which it wishes to so do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to Senator Bishop, and I will endeavour to get Mr Tickner never to refer to her as a prominent member of the front bench again. I will certainly bring Senator Bishop's remarks to his attention and see whether any repentance on his part is required or elicited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice for his quaint indulgence. He should not trouble himself on my behalf. I can probably manage well on my own.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill, other than postponed clause 14, agreed to.
Postponed clause 14, as amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause was deferred in order to allow Senator Harradine to pursue some matters with officials. I understand that those consultations took place over the dinner hour in part and that he finds that there is now no need to pursue the particular matters that were of concern to him before the dinner break. In that situation I would now ask the Committee to support clause 14 as it has been amended.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have one amendment only, the substance of which has been adequately canvassed already by Senator Puplick in the debate which followed the amendment we moved to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. The amendment seeks merely to keep to zero level those charges which might be levelled against persons whose turnover of therapeutic goods is of low volume and low value. A moment ago Senator Puplick raised the point that it should be `or' rather than `and'. I think it probably has been adequately covered, but I reiterate that the intention here is to keep to zero level charges for those organisations whose turnover of goods is of a low volume and the goods they produce are of low value.

SPEECH.PARA: I have accepted the argument that was put to me by the Government officers in relation to some goods which might be manufactured in very small volume, but each of those goods might be of very high value. Pacemakers, for instance, surely have to meet the highest standards. Factory inspection and quality assurance in relation to goods in those areas is absolutely vital. I believe that the word `and' linking those two conditions is appropriate. I move:
Page 2, after subclause 5 (2), had at the end of the clause, the following subclause.

`(3) the regulations shall provide that annual charges in respect of the registration or listing of therapeutic goods are not payable by persons whose turnover of those goods is of low volume and low value.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the Minister's clarification on a couple of matters in relation to this amendment. The first is the question of whether the term `persons' is understood by the Minister to mean, legally, a corporation or company or manufacturing operation. Can he give me an assurance that that is the meaning of the word `persons'? I also ask him to address his mind to the question of turnover-`whose turnover of those goods is low volume and low value'. Does that mean production, does it mean sales, or does it mean a particular type of sale? For example, if I produce 10,000 units but sell only five, what is the basis of the decision as to whether that is low volume? Is it the number that I sell or the number that I produce?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, what is the definition of the term `turnover'? Thirdly, does the Minister give an undertaking that in the regulations the term `low' will not be used, but rather that there will be a quantifiable figure, that is, x number of units, or x value in dollars terms? Or does the Minister rely simply upon the fact that somehow this will be left to the discretion of some regulatory, departmental secretary or Commissioner of Taxation?

By way of illustration of the confusion that can arise in these matters, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that on a number of occasions Senator Coulter said that the intention of this amendment was to keep the charges low. In fact, the purpose of the amendment is to ensure that there are no charges at all. The amendment says `are not payable'. If by `low' we mean zero in the sense that Senator Coulter has used that terminology this evening, I think great comfort will be given to those who have persuaded Senator Coulter to move away from the objective test of 1,000 units to some vague formulation of low volume and low value.

Finally, does the Minister accept as a matter of principle that there may well be an operation where the volume produced may be low but the value may be significant? In other words, we might have an operation that produces, let us say, for the sake of argument, a computerised axial tomography (CAT) scanner-something with which you are intimately familiar, Mr Temporary Chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —So am I. I have been in one.

—I am delighted to know that it obviously worked-at least I presume that it did. If the person referred to produces only one or two of these items per year, the value of the items is considerably higher than might be anticipated, and certainly would not come within the term `low value'. Is the Government happy with the prospect that a company which may produce only a limited number of items but of considerable value should not obtain the benefit of the zero charges because the items must have both low value and low volume?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `person' when it appears in Commonwealth legislation is governed by the Acts Interpretation Act. I do not have that statute in front of me but, as I recall it, a person includes a body politic, a body corporate or an individual. That is the span of the meaning of the word `person' when it appears in legislation unless there is some indication to the contrary, which there is not in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of turnover, I think anyone running a business would understand that term to mean and refer to the sale of items concerned rather than their production or manufacture. The term is very commonly used in commerce to indicate that-although I do not know what the derivation is-the product is turned into something of different value, namely, the price that one obtains for that particular good or item. That is only a guess but, nevertheless, the word `turnover' is a term of commerce rather than manufacture and, I think, refers to trading or sale of the items concerned.

As far as the word `low' is concerned, it is quite clear that we are discussing an enabling provision which indicates that regulations must be made. It is the nature of regulations that more precision be given to those terms. As I understand it, that will be attempted. Of course, as we all know, those regulations will be brought before the Senate-indeed, to the other place also-for its consideration, when the attempt to give more precision can be examined. No doubt it will be the subject of lobbying by interested persons.

As to the combination of low volume and high value, I think it is the clear meaning of the subclause that that combination might occur. The `and' is deliberate. As Senator Coulter was saying, it is cumulative rather than disjunctive. It is not an `or'; it is an `and'. In that situation it could well be that only a small number of high value items turned over. However, depending on the way in which the regulations are drawn, the annual charges would not be waived; in other words, they would be payable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make only one point in reply to the Minister. Clause 3 of the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 is incorporated, and is to be read as one, with this Act.
Therefore, one looks to the Therapeutic Goods Bill for questions of guidance about what these things mean. Clause 6 of the Therapeutic Goods Bill states:
(1) This Act applies to:
(a) things done by . . . corporations; and
(b) things done by . . . natural persons or corporations in so far as those things are done . . .

The clause then specifies a number of matters. This formula in clause 6 of the Therapeutic Goods Bill derives from the interest which the Commonwealth has in extending its regulatory powers by reference to the corporations legislation. The question which I have raised in relation to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill concerns the definition of the term `persons'. It seems to me that if the proposed Therapeutic Goods Act, which is to be read as one with the proposed Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Act, goes out of its way to make separate and special reference to the difference between corporations, natural persons or corporations, and other entities, in order to obtain the benefit which it is believed should be obtained by passage of this amendment to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill, the proper construction would have been to use the same terminology-namely, corporations or natural persons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that that is necessary because clause 6 of the Therapeutic Goods Bill attempts to construct a constitutional link between the activities which are governed by the Bill-`things done by or in relation to'. In other words, the Bill in its various clauses deals with certain activities which do not normally fall within the purview of the constitutional power of the Parliament. To relate them to the constitutional power of the Parliament they have to be in relation to corporations-of course, that invokes the corporations power-or in relation to natural persons or corporations in so far as those things are done in the course of, or in preparation for, trade or commerce between Australia and a place outside Australia, among the States, between a State and a Territory or between two Territories; or under a law of the Commonwealth relating to the provision of pharmaceutical or repatriation benefits; or in relation to the Commonwealth or in relation to an authority of the Commonwealth. Quite clearly, paragraphs 6 (1) (a) and (b) attempt to link the actions that are sought to be governed by the Statute with those heads of power.

SPEECH.PARA: It is different when one turns to Senator Coulter's amendment because he is taking advantage, quite properly, of the Acts Interpretation Act. I am certain that where `persons' is used there unadorned, the Acts Interpretation Act would allow one to read that as covering bodies politic, bodies corporate and individuals. I do not think that there is any contradiction between the two, and there is no need for Senator Coulter to redraw the subclause which he has offered for the Committee's consideration.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bills reported with an amendment; report adopted.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 reported with amendments; and Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989 reported with an amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the Bills be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it clear that because the Senate has agreed to the Opposition amendment to clause 2 of the Therapeutic Goods Bill, we will not be dividing on the third reading of this Bill. If the Senate had not agreed to our amendment regarding the question of the commencement arrangements for this Bill, we would have opposed the Bill on the third reading. I have sought to make it clear throughout the debate that we did not object to the principle of the Bill, and that we did not object to the attempt to establish the national regulation of the control of therapeutic goods, but that we objected to methodology and, in particular, to the open-ended commitment to regulations which, in our view, were not subject to a proper degree of parliamentary scrutiny. If that situation had persisted, we would have resisted the Bill on its third reading. The passage of the Opposition amendment, which provides that the Act shall only come into effect once both Houses of the Parliament have, by resolution, approved the regulations which can now be made under this Act, satisfies our most basic concerns about the legislation, and therefore we do not oppose the third reading of the two therapeutic goods Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one item which bears very heavily on the Therapeutic Goods Bill, which is a matter that I raised in my speech at the second reading stage but which could not be handled by way of any amendment. I ask the Senate's permission to seek an assurance from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in relation to the role of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) in relation to the review of a number of items which will come under this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I pointed out in my speech during the second reading debate that the NHMRC committees are composed very largely of volunteers who meet regularly. Sometimes items are submitted for review and cannot be dealt with for at least six months-sometimes as long as a year. That process is unsatisfactory. Moreover, the NHMRC is not a statutory body. Therefore, the processes by which it will deal with matters which come before it under this legislation will not automatically be open to review so that those placing material before the committees can be assured that the matters have been properly considered and the judgments fairly drawn. I seek the assurance of the Minister that the role of the NHMRC under this legislation-and, indeed, more broadly-will be reviewed with a view to making the NHMRC more of a full time statutory body whose processes are open to full and open scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am a little reluctant to get involved in a committee stage response during a third reading debate. Nevertheless, I will satisfy Senator Coulter, who has been helpful at times in the passage of this package of legislation, by saying that the National Health and Medical Research Council has been devised so that its personnel are not full time. I suppose that is because the sort of expertise which it draws on is thought to be usefully gathered from those institutions of medical and scientific research and practice where people have practical experience of matters which they then bring to the deliberations of the National Health and Medical Research Council.

SPEECH.PARA: As for Senator Coulter's more general question concerning who keeps an eye on the decision making process of the National Health and Medical Research Council to ensure that it is open and able to be properly assessed-I know Senator Harradine has a very real interest in this-the Administrative Review Council is conducting a review of that decision making process. I certainly invite Senator Coulter to make a submission to the Administrative Review Council, drawing on his concerns and, perhaps, misgivings about this particular instance. It may well be that his contribution to the review being undertaken by the Administrative Review Council will be helpful in the formation of its conclusions and recommendations. The Administrative Review Council is looking at the overall question to which Senator Coulter adverted, and I believe it is best in those hands. The Government and, as I understand it, Senator Coulter and other senators will be interested to see the results of that review.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989STUDENT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) BILL 1989OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1989ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) BILL 1989UNIVERSITY OF CANBERRA BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The seven Bills the Senate is debating are the States Grant (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2), the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Bill, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill and the University of Canberra Bill. The Opposition supports all seven of them. One Bill will be adjourned until next week, but I expect the other six will be passed later this evening or in the morning. The Liberal and National parties have announced their education policies. We have made public our sound and constructive approach to schools, technical and further education (TAFE) and higher education. It is on the basis of those policies and our Economic Action Plan that we have confidence in saying that the Bills before the Senate tonight are fully consistent with those announced policies and so have our support. Three of the Bills are in the usual form for this time of year, providing annual funding to schools, TAFE and higher education, together with supplementation to account for inflation in respect of grants that have already been made. The three funding Bills provide $5.6 billion in assistance to education. Another Bill strengthens anti-fraud measures in student assistance schemes, with an estimated saving of $5m. The Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1989 proposes to increase overseas student charges between 8 per cent to 10 per cent in the format which has been used for many years. The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill 1989 draws together $112m a year for the next three years to provide supplementation assistance for Aboriginal education programs. The final Bill in the package, the University of Canberra Bill 1989, establishes the University of Canberra. It is an important and innovative measure, one which I have called for over at least the last year and which the Opposition welcomes. As an amendment to the second reading motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for the turmoil caused to Australia's higher education system by the Government's use of financial blackmail, centralised control, bureaucratic administration and other heavy-handed tactics to implement its ill-conceived education policies''.

I move that amendment to the motion before the Senate to make it abundantly clear that the Opposition, while supporting these seven Bills, does not support the way in which the Government and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) have let down and failed Australia in the administration of policies concerning schools, technical and further education and higher education. The only remedy to this situation, which I will come to later, will be in March or May next year when the people of Australia will have an opportunity to vote in a new Liberal-National Party government.

I will deal with each of the seven Bills in turn. The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 provides $2,212m for schools in the 1990 calendar year. It also provides supplementation with respect to the current year to bring grants to a total of $2,055m. The Bill also provides for a rural hostels program. It is easy for the Opposition to be cynical about this measure. Of course, we support it because we have urged greater educational assistance for children in country areas. The Government announced a $600m rural education program about six months ago. It turned out that all of the hundreds of millions of dollars, bar $2m only, was money that had already been determined for various programs. This was just the 8 per cent element that relates to the population in rural areas. The Government decided to launch a rural education initiative which was merely 8 per cent of everything that it provides for the whole country on the ground that 8 per cent of Australians live in country areas. The only new element was $2m-$1m this year and $1m next year-for a rural hostels program. I give the Government full praise for that puny, but welcome, initiative. This is the legislation that provides a framework for that $2m to be spent.

The legislation before us also extends eligibility for the English as a second language (ESL) program to students in the first year of primary school who may have arrived in Australia 18 months preceding that enrolment. It is also a welcome initiative. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which was provided in answer to my question asked in the Estimates hearings setting out ESL funding over recent years.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table shows that there has not been a return to the 1986 peak level of funding for English as a second language programs. The Opposition has been very critical of the Government for its huge cuts in English as a second language programs in 1987. Whilst there was some scrabbling together of additional moneys to meet the public outcry and the outcry of the Opposition, even today, and even in projection for 1990, ESL programs will be underfunded compared to any of the years in the first half of the 1980s. All of these measures are supported by the Opposition; they are sensible.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity to note that the Opposition months ago published its own schools policy. Only the brief time available for this debate restricts me in emphasising the particular strengths of the Opposition's policy with regard to schools. When we come into government next year, our implementing this policy will at least maintain, but generally increase, resources to individual schools, will abolish the barriers erected by the Labor Ministers Ryan and Dawkins to hinder the establishment of new schools, and will promote excellence, equity and choice for all Australian children and their families.

I turn now to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. The funding has already been passed for the 1989-91 triennium, and the $2,856m provided in this Bill is for the 1992 calendar year, in accord with the rolling triennium funding arrangements. This includes $34m for the additional 4,000 enrolments in the intakes to be increased in 1992; an additional $56m for capital works to bring 1992 funds up to the same real value as capital funding for 1991; and $13m cost supplementation for the years 1990 and 1991.

The Bill also provides that the Australian Research Council programs now incorporated into this Bill on a rolling triennium basis will have an additional $34m in 1990, $53m in 1991, and $62m in 1992. These additional research grants were announced in the science and research statement of the Government in May of this year. The Government's decisions in this area are not controversial. The Opposition supports all of them, as we have made the very firm commitment that in higher education funding all that is in this Bill and the present Act, with regard to the present triennium and the year 1992, in addition, will be maintained at least by the Opposition when it is in government.

Incidentally, I note that in this legislation some 72 higher education institutions are listed to receive financial support. After two years of Mr Dawkins pressuring institutions to amalgamate, it is ironical to note that there are quite so many higher education institutions in this country. If one had been listening only to Minister Dawkins, one might have thought that there would be only 35 institutions. Thankfully, the rhetoric of this Government to amalgamate for the sake of it, despite the want of any educational or financial advantage, has not swayed the councils of our higher education institutions. I believe that up to this point there have been amalgamations only where there is educational merit for them and where there are genuine long-term financial savings. Certainly, the Opposition will not persist with the pressure for amalgamation.

There are two significant observations about higher education over the last seven years of the Hawke Labor Government that I would like to make. The first is that funding from the Commonwealth per student in higher education has decreased in real terms every single year of the Hawke Labor Government. In every one of the last seven years there has been a decrease in the funding per student. TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I thank the Senate. These tables show the extent of unmet demand for each State. They bear out my summary that 10 per cent of applicants all round Australia are turned away from our 72 higher education institutions because of the policies of this Government. They will not be turned away by bureaucratic fiat under a Liberal-National Party government as all institutions will be given the right to abolish the ceilings on enrolments and to enrol whatever numbers of students, on whatever grounds, they see fit. The only answer to the inadequacies that I have mentioned is a change of government from the last seven years and the refreshing approaches of the higher education policies announced by the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to two particular new mechanisms which will refresh higher education in this country. Firstly, institutions will be given genuine autonomy by us. This will mean an end to the last seven years of centralising, standardising and uniformity from Canberra. Let me refer to the 15 year period from 1972 to 1987. In recent times I have often described them as `the Karmel years'. I have the very highest respect for Professor Peter Karmel who has contributed more to education in this country than any other. The years from 1972 to 1987 were very much led by his decisions and reforms. A certain number of goals were set and achieved by both the Labor and Liberal governments. That period of consolidation has been achieved. On the basis of the 15 Karmel years, we can now put aside the two years of Dawkins-the overcentralising and interference with the higher education institutions of Australia-and move on in a refreshing way to a genuine autonomy in these institutions. Councils will be councils again and will not just deal with bicycle sheds; vice-chancellors will be vice-chancellors again. In this context I am really referring to the 1950s and 1960s, when councils were councils and vice-chancellors were vice-chancellors. With this increased autonomy and, indeed, a genuine sense of constructive competition between institutions around Australia, I believe that there will be positive incentives for those institutions to manage their own program delivery with efficiency and effectiveness.

The second new mechanism that will be implemented by our policy will remove the Canberra imposed ceiling on student enrolments. Censorship of enrolments will go. We guarantee the number of student places provided by current legislation, including the extra 4,000 places for 1992 provided for in this Bill. But in addition to those guaranteed funded places in higher education, institutions will be free to enrol any additional numbers on whatever basis they see fit. Unmet demand will be genuinely tested for the first time in 20 years by our flexible approach.

Finally, with regard to higher education funding, I wish to refer to the higher education contribution scheme (HECS) which many people know as the graduate tax. HECS was introduced for the first year of operation this year by the Hawke Labor Government following the report of the Committee on Higher Education Funding, the Wran report, and the decision of Mr Dawkins. Under a Liberal-National Party government, the HECS will be abolished. After coming into government in March or May next year we can expect the new approach-that is a post-HECS approach-to take effect from 1 January 1991. We are abolishing the HECS for two reasons. We want to ensure that the student payment goes directly and fully to the education institution where the student is enrolled. We will stop student money going to the government trust fund. We want to get government right out of the relationship altogether. The Australian Taxation Office will no longer be involved when we abolish the HECS. The second reason is that we want to lower the financial burden on all students by decreasing the student contribution from the $1,800 tax under Labor to a $1,200 tuition fee under the Opposition. Since the $1,200 amount was announced two months ago in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan and tax statement of October, some students have asked questions to clarify the positive advantages for students in our positive and reformed approach. I will explain some aspects for the first time. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables that set out the explanation I am about to give.
