TALK.START.PARA: —The first table concerns Labor's higher education contribution scheme. The second table shows the Liberal-National Party tuition fee alternative to the HECS. The first table shows that the $1,800 amount, which is the tax liability accrued for all higher education students, bar very few, rises with inflation year by year to $1,882 next year, to $1,969 in 1991, to $2,060 in 1992 and to $2,155 in 1993. The tax liability, for example, at the end of the 1993 year will be three times the final amount of $2,155 for a three-year undergraduate course. The actual liability grows as the years go by in the same way as the new liability of any year of study grows. So a student under Labor at the end of a three-year course undertaken in 1991, 1992 and 1993, will have a tax liability of $6,465 at Christmas time 1993. The table also shows that with the 15 per cent discount for the up-front payment, the amounts in successive years will be $1,530 this year rising to $1,832 in 1993. If a student paid up front in each of the three years 1991, 1992 and 1993, the total amount paid would be $5,257. That is the cost of a three-year degree under Labor. The student contributes approximately $5,250-$6,500.

SPEECH.PARA: In comparison, let us turn to the Liberal-National Party tuition fee alternative. Students will fall into three groups. The first group is one-quarter of all students who will be totally exempt from all tuition fees; so 85,000 higher education students in Australia will pay zero for their higher education enrolment. That is a $6,000-odd advantage for them. The second group is another one-quarter of all students and they will pay $1,200 a year, which is $3,600 total. Under HECS they would have had to pay $5,257, so this quarter of all students will have an advantage of $1,657. The third group, that one-half of all students who will be neither exempt nor able to pay up front, will presumably take on loans which would be government-guaranteed loans so that no student would ever be denied enrolment in higher education for the want of the money to pay. Here we have to have a calculation for the interest that may be accrued during the years of study on the basis of $600 being paid each semester for the three years-six payments of $600 each. Any bank or finance company will have an interest ready reckoner that will show a student what the interest accruing in that sequence of instalment payments will be.

The conclusion is that that half of the students of Australia who undertake the three-year course in 1991, 1992 and 1993 will have a tuition fee liability of less than $4,550 compared with $6,465 under HECS. Under the Opposition scheme, the advantage to the student is $1,915. I note that that figure is worked out on an interest rate of 15 per cent, so if that rate falls below 15 per cent by the time the scheme begins students will have an even better advantage. In a rule of thumb way, when Christmas 1993 arrives, under the coalition approach students will be at least $2,000 better off than under the higher education contribution scheme of the Labor Government.

The table makes it abundantly clear that under HECS there is this year a total of fewer than 19,000 exemptions; that is, fewer than 19,000 of all of our higher education students do not pay for their tuition. There are only two groups of exemptions-the 4,000 for the professional development of teachers and the 14,299 set out in the table for all others who are all postgraduate students. In great contrast to this 19,000, the Opposition will have exemptions for 85,000 who will pay zero for tuition. This greatly increased number of exemptions will be ample to provide for these sorts of groups of people. All current categories of exemptions will be able to continue. Many thousands more post-graduate students will be able to become exempt. All honours year and other fourth year graduate diploma students will be able to become exempt. All fourth, fifth and sixth year students undertaking courses of longer than three years again will be able to be exempt. Finally, and especially, many thousands of students in financial need will be able to be exempt. All the categories that I have mentioned will be able to be exempt together, because the 85,000 will cater for such numbers. The final decisions will be determined by the education institutions themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I now come to the third of the Bills before us-the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Bill 1989 which provides TAFE funding for the 1990 calendar year. According to decisions already announced in the TAFE 1990 Commonwealth programs and priorities statement, $329m is appropriated and the Opposition fully supports the Bill. Time in this debate precludes my debating now the current issues concerning TAFE, but I draw attention to the T.A.F.E. Policy of the Opposition, a sound and constructive policy which the Opposition has published and which is widely distributed. This is the policy which will be implemented on our return to government next year.

The fourth Bill before us is the Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, which relates to the Austudy scheme and postgraduate awards. The objective of the Bill is the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments. This Bill extends existing Austudy provisions to the non-legislated schemes-that is, assistance for isolated children, Abstudy and Aboriginal overseas study awards. It is a sensible extension of the anti-fraud measures that are already in place for Austudy and the Opposition fully supports the scheme. The Bill also enables the charging of interest on debts after a three-month grace period which will essentially act as a deterrent for the accrual of debts. (Extension of time granted) I thank the Senate. We have seven Bills before us and I was conscious from the beginning that I might take 40 to 45 minutes in presenting the Opposition's case on them. The Bill before us also renumbers the clauses, given the very many amendments that have been passed by the Parliament over the last 16 years. The impact of this measure is some $5m, estimated to be recovered over the next two years. Only $100,000 is expected to be raised in terms of any interest payments. So it is small and reinforces the view that this measure is essentially a deterrent.

Essentially, my point on this Bill is that this measure should have been taken 10 years ago. It should have been taken in any of the years of the Hawke Government and, in fact, in some years of the preceding Government. These are the sorts of reforms which have been the outcome of program budgeting and the requirement, not least from the Senate Estimates committee system, that the departments of government apply to themselves a program evaluation. I can only commend the Estimates committee system and the Department for eventually achieving such a degree of program evaluation as to put in place the kinds of measures that we see in the Bill that is before us. The Senate should take a bow and the Department, to some extent, should take a bow as well-but 10 years too late. The Opposition, in government, will completely review Austudy. We will follow up the quite scandalous reports from the Auditor-General and others in regard to the level of fraud that has taken place in the student assistance programs.

The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill 1989 provides $236m over the next three years. That is about $112m a year. It is to promote educational equality in access, in participation and in outcomes. It sounds like affirmative action, and technically there would be some controversy about that in this chamber, but certainly there is no-one I know of in the Senate who would not want to see an improvement in educational outcomes, access and participation, whether by students or by staff in educational institutions. So the Opposition supports the objectives of this Bill and very genuinely supports the outcomes that we all hope will flow from it. There are some dangers in the Bill. It gives inordinate power to the Minister to determine to whom he gives contracts-whether they are States, educational institutions or even persons involved in education. I am sure that we will seek to monitor what the incoming government's Minister will do with regard to this money. In many respects this Bill reappropriates money that has already been voted by other legislation. Certainly that is the case for the first half-year of operation. It sets out for the remaining 2 1/2 years moneys that will be in succeeding Budgets.

Let me say to those within the Government who are propagandising from time to time that there is nothing in the Opposition's policy which would take away a dollar from any of these programs. The cuts in Aboriginal affairs, along with the cuts in many departments, that have been announced by the Opposition all affect bureaucracy and not programs. This Bill not only will be supported in this chamber tonight but also will be supported in operation by the Opposition in government.

The next Bill before us is the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1989. It raises overseas student charges by 8 to 10 per cent. I do not have time to reflect upon the Bill, except to say that the Minister gave a firm undertaking 12 months ago to provide in legislation for the ability to pay the overseas student charge in two instalments. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Minister's letter to me of 7 December-only last Thursday-with regard to this undertaking.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Employment, Education and Training
Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, 2600
7 December 1989
Senator Baden Teague
Senator for South Australia
6 Waterloo Street
GLENELG SA 5045
Dear Senator Teague

I refer to the letter I wrote to you on 13 December 1988 about payment of the overseas student charge (OSC) by instalments. I undertook that payment by instalments would be introduced in 1990, when additional resources and new administrative and computer systems were expected to be available to deal with the considerable extra administrative burden that instalment payments will impose on my Department.

My Department has already arranged administratively for payment to be made in instalments by students whose payments were found to be in arrears because the OSC liability had only recently come to my Department's notice. Most of these students are temporary residents or their dependants. These students have been permitted to pay the arrears by instalments, but have been required to pay the OSC for a course taken in 1989 in one payment.

Unfortunately, it appears that only OSC liabilities in arrears can be paid by instalments under administrative arrangements. The Attorney-General's Department advises that, because of the particular wording of the relevant provisions in the OSC legislation, current OSC liabilities cannot be discharged by instalments. The legislation must therefore be amended if payment by instalments is to be permitted.

By the time that advice was received, it was too late to have the appropriate legislative amendments drafted and passed by both Houses of Parliament in the 1989 Budget sittings. I therefore propose to have a Bill prepared for introduction to the Parliament in the Autumn sittings.
The Bill will amend the OSC legislation to permit the OSC for a full academic year to be paid in 2 instalments, one instalment to be payable for each semester in the academic year.
Yours sincerely
J S Dawkins

SPEECH.PARA: The final Bill before us, the seventh Bill, is the University of Canberra Bill 1989. Following the White Paper on higher education of July 1988 it was clear that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) was intent to effect many amalgamations in institutions around Australia. One was here in Canberra. In December last year he introduced a Bill to amalgamate the Australian National University (ANU) with the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE) and the Canberra Institute of the Arts, the three higher educational institutions in this city. In December this was opposed, not least by myself, by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, so the legislation did not see any progress.

Shortly thereafter the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly was formed, and one of its first acts was to set up an inquiry into higher education in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Amongst other things, the inquiry reached three conclusions. Firstly, it agreed with the Opposition and the Democrats that there should be no amalgamation of institutions. Secondly, it agreed with the proposal that a number of us had been making-that the Canberra College of Advanced Education should become the University of Canberra. Thirdly, it recommended that the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly itself should enact the legislation to set up that university. Clearly Mr Dawkins has been defeated in his earlier proposal and has agreed to the first two of these three conclusions, and so we have the Bill that is before us now. The amalgamation is over in Canberra and the Canberra College will become the University of Canberra.

This has the full support of the Opposition. Indeed, we have called for it for many months now. The ANU will remain uniquely undisturbed as the national university in Australia and the University of Canberra will be equivalent to universities in the States which are set up by State legislation. From next month the University of Canberra will have a particular responsibility to serve the people of the city of Canberra and the surrounding region, including parts of New South Wales. The Opposition not only supports the Bill but will, on coming to government, enable a transition whereby the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly will be enabled to pass legislation of its own making that will responsibly maintain continuity with the Bill before us, but such that the legislation will be Australian Capital Territory legislation on a similar basis to other higher education institution legislation in the States.

In the few minutes that remain to me let me make a few observations about this Bill. Firstly, the sponsorship by Monash University is welcome. I am reassured that there will be genuine and constructive input, and not a censorious or authoritarian approach, from the representatives of Monash in the upgrading of aspects of the new University of Canberra. However, I am not convinced that the partnership between Monash and the University of Canberra should run merely for three years. Rather, it is sensible to envisage a period of seven years. I say this chiefly to deny that three years should be the general standard around Australia for sponsorships of this kind. Currently sponsorships are operating or being explored in the Northern Territory, Queensland and Victoria. To me seven years would seem to be a much more likely standard when moving into the doctor of philosophy programs and establishing research infrastructure. I am conscious that the University of Canberra has already moved a considerable way down this path and is in a relatively strong position. So some period between three and seven years may be appropriate in this case. I am a great supporter of the achievements of the Canberra College of Advanced Education. I was one of those who first called for it to become the University of Canberra. I am totally confident that with the sponsorship of Monash it will soon make a transition to being one of the great universities in this country.

My second observation is that the Opposition, on its initial reading of the first draft of the legislation, urged amendments. I am happy to say that the Minister agreed to our suggestions. One was to increase from two to three the number of Council members nominated by the ACT Minister in circumstances that are now outlined in the Bill as passed by the House of Representatives. A second was to clarify the qualification requirements of members of the Council. I would call those the Senator Peter Baume amendments because they were inspired by his reflections on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Council qualifications and were seen by us to be as much demanded of any such University of Canberra Council members as of ATSIC Council members. The Minister agreed to the amendments and they are in the Bill as presented to the Senate. What I was most concerned about in the former of the two amendments was to maintain the principle that a clear majority of Council members were neither in the employ of the university nor students of the university; therefore, outside members could more objectively be in the majority on the Council.

The urgency of the legislation is keenly felt by the Opposition. We will not move any subsequent amendments in order to ensure that there is no possible barrier to this legislation being passed over the next 24 hours and the University of Canberra beginning from 1 January 1990. Accordingly, I am not taking up the luxury of any further amendments, such as our strong endorsement of the principle of voluntary student unionism which was an amendment moved in the House of Representatives by my colleagues. Every Opposition member supports that principle. If conditions were otherwise we would move an amendment in the Senate. The reason for my not doing so at the committee stage is only to ensure that the university begins on 1 January next year.

I conclude by referring again to my second reading amendment which I moved on behalf of the Opposition. Whilst the Opposition supports all seven Bills before us, it does not commend the Minister, Mr Dawkins, and the Hawke Labor Government because of their mismanagement of education not only in higher education but also in schools and TAFE institutions. The only remedy, next March or May, will be the election of a Liberal-National party government to implement the policies which will be for the good of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -In the last three-quarters of an hour Senator Baden Teague has oscillated between being the ghost of Christmas futures and doing a reasonably good imitation of Chamberlain waving a piece of paper: `I have here a piece of paper'. He would probably be better characterised as a latter day revisionist historian at the end of his speech in terms of rewriting the most immediate past in the most glowing terms which actually made the Opposition look as if it had an education policy.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in a difficult situation with only half an hour in which to consider the legislation. I hope that the Opposition will give me the reciprocal right, as we donated to the Opposition, of additional time in which to debate the entire number of Bills before us. I do not intend to deal with the issues which I will pick up at the committee stage. But I will comment on each of the Bills and look at some of their specific aspects relating to education in the 1990s. I would like to hone in on one point in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2); that is, adult literacy. At this stage I do not want to make too many comments about the structure of the allocations from the Commonwealth Government. It is an unfortunate fact of life that we in Australia spend a great deal of our time criticising the people who are doing the work in our schools. Garth Boomer, when speaking about our literacy standards, made the following statement in 1987, which I totally endorse:
Credit must go to our teachers who kept on educating with precious little community praise and often in the face of uninformed, unfair and mischievous attacks from sections of the media.

I add to that: quite a number of politicians. We have had-and this has gone on for a number of years-the most uninformed attack on teachers and their ability to deal with a whole range of matters in our schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a party of teachers, aren't you?

—We have an interjection from an Opposition senator. I remember on one occasion my Leader being asked whether we were upset by the very large number of ex-teachers in the Parliament. Her comment bears repeating. She said, `We're not worried about the number of ex-teachers in the Parliament; what we are worried about is the large number of ex-learners'.

SPEECH.PARA: Literacy was highlighted in the last couple of weeks by a number of international experts visiting Australia for a conference on literacy. Having looked at the very large number of education systems existing throughout the world, they made a judgment that Australian teachers were the best qualified and the most adept at taking up new initiatives and putting them into practice in a practical way in the classroom structure. That was indeed praise for the people who are doing the work. We have had this extraordinary welter of uninformed criticism of the people at the workface.

Australia has been doing remarkably well in this area. Our literacy rate is very high, particularly our adult literacy rate. A large number of people in our community are assisting in teaching those adults who do not have the capacity to operate in a functionally literate way within our community. They are doing it not in a paid capacity but by their thousands in an unpaid capacity. They are assisting those people back into the work force and back into productive life. Many people engage in those types of educational activities. There are many in the classroom to whom hardly any attention is paid when the door closes. There are many outside the classroom who help on a one-to-one basis in the promotion of literacy within our community, who never receive any thanks and who, at the end of the day, only ever receive carping criticism of the most uninformed kind from a whole series of self-appointed critics who have never in fact darkened the classroom door or who, when they were probably last there, managed to fail their English exams in any event.

The second Bill that we have before us is the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. I want to point to a very real problem that I do not think has been alluded to by many people in the debates that have gone around concerning the higher education contribution scheme. One would not have gathered from Senator Teague's contribution that the Opposition actually voted for that scheme, and that that is in fact why it is in place. Also one would not have gathered that the Australian Labor Party, coming into office with a pledge never to introduce such a scheme, managed to do precisely the opposite and put in place a tax on students, which it had pledged not to do.

In terms of what will actually happen to that tax, I would like honourable senators to consider for a moment the actual ongoing context with regard to it. I take an example. This year, students earning less than $22,000 were not required to make any repayments towards their debt. Those earning between $22,000 and $25,000 paid 1 per cent towards repayment on their debt. Those earning between $25,000 and $35,000 paid 2 per cent and those earning $35,000 paid 3 per cent. As an example, let us take an economics graduate with an income of $23,000 who would, in his or her first year of employment, be required to make a payment of $230 towards the total tax liability which, for a three-year course, is likely to be about $5,500.

Of course, as honourable senators know, having passed the legislation, those outstanding debts will be adjusted by an index calculated to match real terms. In dollar value, a total debt which is eventually repaid will be larger than the initial debt. That is a circumstance that I think many Australians are very familiar with from taking out a home loan, whereby their repayments are less than the interest that is in fact added to their debt each month.

Those students in the upper income brackets, who presumably endear themselves to the Australian Labor Party, will end up paying off their higher education contribution scheme debt very rapidly indeed. Those who are even more wealthy and who can afford the up-front fees will in fact get a discount. As an example, let us take those people on a lower income who are not able to afford those types of exercises. Firstly, in the example of the economics student, his or her first year's repayment of $230 will not, in fact, match the real increase in debt. For example, if we used a 7.5 per cent inflator, we would end up with $412.50 as the amount that the person would have to repay for that particular year. I think that honourable senators will realise, having spoken to so many--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I refer you to standing order No. 406, which states, `No Senator shall read his speech'. It seems to me that Senator Macklin is not flowing in his normal fashion but is in fact somewhat restricted to the written word.
—There is no point of order.

—I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for coming to my rescue. I have raised a point that has been raised by a large number of organisations. I refer to the example that has been raised by those organisations supporting nurses in this country. Of course, nurse education is now in higher education institutions. In looking at the type of repayments for nurses, one will also find a similar situation, whereby the debt that they incur will in fact increase more each year than the amount they will be repaying. So, they will be in a recurring increasing debt context. That may seem fine to Senator Walsh-I did not pick up his interjections-but I am quite sure that to those people who have to pay that debt, and pay it continually, it is not fine. In fact, it will be in the type of context that former Senator Ryan, when she was the Minister in charge of education, pointed to as quite clearly disadvantaging those people on low incomes who would normally be expected to be supporters of the Australian Labor Party, when they remembered their origins.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I want to raise is exemptions for postgraduate students. This is an extremely difficult situation because the Government issued only 19,000 exemptions for all postgraduate students last year. We know that many institutions have made a variety of arrangements which make the situation very difficult, and I will give some examples. Many institutions have claimed exemptions for staff who are undertaking postgraduate studies. I am not decrying that and saying they should not do it, but it leaves out a large number of people. Typical students who hardly ever complete their postgraduate studies at the end of an academic year-they tend to do so throughout an academic year-also take away a large percentage of the useful, available exemptions.

Many institutions have made a policy decision not to provide any exemptions for those people undertaking masters degrees by course-work. Many parttime students have found that this is the only means by which they are able to undertake masters degrees. There are so many anomalies creeping into this area of exemptions that I hope the Government has at least some intention of addressing these problems, and addressing them in a real and concrete way by allowing those people undertaking postgraduate studies in this country to be exempt from that charge. It makes eminent sense.

I refer the Government-if it needs any argument with regard to this matter-to the last years of the Fraser Government when the conservatives attempted to introduce fees for second and higher degrees. The Australian Labor Party, in opposition at that time, argued violently against this on the grounds that it is an absurd proposition that, having paid out $14,000 to $15,000 for a graduate-in today's terms it is well over $30,000-the Government was then quite happy to say, `We are going to cut those people out; we are not going to support them going on to second and higher degrees'. At that time the Labor Party saw the absurdity of the situation but, unfortunately, at this time sees that it might be a useful device to ingratiate itself with the rich and thick in this society.

I wish to turn now to the third of the seven Bills before us, that is, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Australian Democrats have very strongly supported the provision of assistance to students. I listened with a degree of admiration to Senator Teague, who was able to turn a policy which will gut student assistance into a paeon of praise and suggest that somehow or other that policy would help students. What Senator Teague does not seem to be aware of is that within the last 18 months, as far as the operation of the student assistance scheme is concerned, there is no fat left. There are not any rorts going on. What is happening in terms of the squeeze being put on student assistance is that people who should be assisted are being forced out, and are not getting the assistance they are due. This Australian Labor Party Government cut out $60m in one hit alone from the student assistance scheme, yet the Opposition says it will be able to clean out another $30m. For Senator Teague's information, there is not $30m available. He intends to take $30m from those people who do not have it and force them out of higher education. Under the Opposition policies we are well on the way to what I have just mentioned-a policy for the rich and the thick.

In this country we need a reasonable student assistance scheme. We need everybody who has the ability and the capacity to undertake higher education to be provided with that opportunity. The reason for that is very simple and it should appeal to Senator Walsh. Every economic study that has been undertaken, both in Australia and especially in the United States of America, has come to one inescapable, fundamental conclusion: a dollar invested in higher education is easily the best investment that can be made in any area within an industrialised, advanced, technological society. There is now no debate about that fact. A dollar put into higher education is a better investment than a dollar put into mining, digging up or putting down yet another railway line, chopping down yet another rainforest or undertaking any other type of activity that is said to be development.

One would have thought that we might have learnt merely by looking at the example of those countries that have invested in the intelligence, imagination and creativity of their own people. In Australia we have this rather quaint notion that we will be able to achieve Senator Button's utopia of a technologically advanced society by, somehow or other, not investing in our own people. A way of achieving that is to import everybody with skills and not bother with our own citizens. That is the only way to overcome the problem. If we are to have our own citizens employed in this utopia set out by Senator Button in his various plans for development, we will actually have to pay. There is no other way. We will have to put money into higher education and we will have to put money towards funding those people who have the capacity.

Strange as it may seem to the Government and to the Opposition, there is not yet any study that I know of which suggests that intelligence is distributed in exactly the same manner as income. In fact, my understanding is that they are not even casually related. Intelligence, in fact, is quite independent of parental income. It is a pity that we manage to impose upon the data a very strong correlation between the two. How do we manage that? We do so by saying that we will provide funds for the benefit of those with income and wealth and that we will penalise those with intelligence but without income and wealth. We can do that but we will not be developing in any reasonable, rational and economic way if we continue down that track. As Senator Haines has said on a number of occasions recently in speeches to various groups, by putting that amount of money into higher education, we will not even be meeting the level of investment that goes into those countries which we seek to emulate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ever had a look at West Germany?

—Senator Walsh invites me to have a look at West Germany. The fascinating thing about Senator Walsh is that the only figures on education he ever looks at are those which are paid out by the centralised body. He has never looked at the States in Germany. He has never looked at the input from private industry in Germany or Japan. Those countries spend a larger proportion of gross domestic product on education than we do. Senator Walsh cannot controvert that because he knows it to be true.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extraordinary circumstance. The Government floats around figures with regard to the Budget but, of course, it never floats around figures with regard to the way the country dedicates itself to its educational task. Australia has not done that. Australian private industry expects every dollar to come from the public sector. It never believes that the private sector has to put its hand into its pocket. It believes that it has a god-given right to pick up a graduate for nothing. It says to the taxpayer, `Go out there and educate this person through to the end of a law degree and then I, the private sector, will take that person and use that person to create a profit for my firm without any responsibility and without contributing a dollar on my part'. In fact, this Government at one stage actually toyed with the idea of putting a levy on the private sector for educational purposes. It only toyed with it; it did not do it. That is the type of government we have, a so-called Labor government that will not bite the bullet on those types of necessary reforms so that the private sector will pay its fair share. In West Germany, which Senator Walsh invites me to discuss, and in Japan, which he does not invite me to discuss, we know that the private sector pays its fair share. That is the difference. Those countries see education as being necessary. In this country, very few do. Unfortunately, the circumstances are such that we are unable to meet the expectations and the necessary elements with regard to our citizens' educational future.

I wish to make only one comment on Senator Teague's contribution to the discussion of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Bill, that is, he obviously has not seen what has gone on in the last few weeks in New South Wales with regard to technical and further education (TAFE) institutions. The New South Wales Liberal Government has, in fact, cut the TAFE exemption quotas from 140,000 to 70,000. I found it extraordinary that the Minister could wave around a piece of paper purporting to be a policy with regard to TAFE, knowing that the only Liberal State Government in this country has just cut in half the exemption quotas for TAFE. That, to my mind, really took the cake this evening. I do not feel that I need to say any more about that circumstance. The circumstances are such that the Liberal Party of Australia, with regard to its policy, has condemned itself by its own words.

Unfortunately, the Australian Labor Party's policy in this area has also been appalling. In fact, it has not provided and, in this Bill, still is intent on not providing a range of educational opportunities that should be available to those people who wish to undertake TAFE studies. Again, I find this odd, given the Labor Party's professed interest in the type of people who might go to TAFE colleges. We know that a very large number of those people, for want, for example, of places in TAFE colleges, have had to go to private business colleges. In the committee stage, I want to raise some items with regard to that.

Over 12 months ago we had a debate here on precisely this item. It was interesting that the Australian Labor Party was trying to cut out support to those business colleges. When I pointed out that the vast majority of people in private business colleges are women, that the overwhelming majority are from state schools, and that the overwhelming majority have not completed any years of formal education-if they had, of course, they would have been supported 100 per cent by the state-Dawkins, to his credit, finally backed off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator must address the Minister by his proper name.

—The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) finally backed off. I think it is interesting that the Labor Party again has not seen that the types of people its educational policies are affecting are those who might normally be said to be its supporters. Having so much lost touch with its own base, it is quite happy to devastate the educational opportunities of those young women from state schools and working class backgrounds who are completely unable to find a place in TAFE for secretarial studies and who have to pay sums that they cannot afford to get some chance for a job within the economy of this so-called lucky country.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to turn now to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. Here again, we have been battling both the Government and the Opposition on this matter. I think it is extraordinary that the merchandising mentality that has overtaken the Australian Labor Party with regard to education has probably overwhelmed all its humanitarian and other basic philosophical approaches to education and the usefulness of education as an element in our approach to other countries. Treating education, as the Government is now doing, as a purely exportable product is to ignore the human side of our very effective and efficient educational system. The export of Australian education should be used not only to enhance the quality of life in education in overseas countries but also to enhance our reputation in those countries as a friend and as a neighbour. However, as I mentioned when we had a discussion in this chamber a few days ago on the foreign affairs document on regional security, this Government, as a matter of friendship, sent a warship around the countries of South East Asia at enormous expense, and yet refused to provide educational scholarships for their poorer citizens. Those are the types of decisions and priorities this Government has. In that document it pats itself on the back about the waltzings of our warships in and out of various ports of South East Asia and sees in some way a weapon of war as our token of friendship and support. It may come as a rude shock to the Government to find that other countries, and particularly their people, do not in any way see that as a token of friendship; in fact, they see very clearly that Australia has decided that the friendship with those countries is expendable when it comes to assisting with a fundamental element that they are looking for, that is, providing top quality educational opportunities. It seems that the short term rewards for extra funds for the institutions have replaced the many, varied and often intangible long term rewards which have always been associated in this country with overseas students. I think it is a pity that this Government has decided to ditch all of those things on the pyre of its so-called economic rationality.

Phillip Jones in the Current Affairs Bulletin back in July this year argued-I must say that I fully agree-that not only is the Australian education system relaxed about monitoring the progress of individual visiting students, but also there is a reluctance to monitor the progress and effect of our educational relationships with the Asian and Pacific countries involved. Australia still seems in need of a policy. At present it seems to be a case of `take the money and run'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Support Agency was established over a year ago, its prime purpose being to collect child maintenance, to enforce maintenance orders and to ensure that payment is made to custodial parents. The purpose was to see that maintenance was made available for the support of children, as it should be, from each parent. It was expected that there would be some teething problems, as with any new organisation, and that it would take some time to settle down. Many complaints were received early on when the Agency was established about the slowness in processing payments. For some time delays of six to eight weeks were common and many were longer. What is disturbing-and this is the reason I am raising this matter tonight-is that there has been no sign of improvement in this time. In many respects, I suggest, the situation is even worse. There is a steady stream of complaints about the tardiness and inefficiency of the Child Support Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that when payees attempt to find out from the Agency what is happening, why they are not being paid, they just cannot get anywhere. Phone calls are not returned and it is virtually impossible to talk to the same officer twice or to speak to the same officer one spoke to the last time one rang. I have seen a constituent recently whose ex-husband is paying maintenance to the Agency for his children's benefit, but the maintenance is not being passed on to his former wife. I will refer to that in more detail later.

I want to give some other examples. A constituent of mine last year who had to wait until January to receive moneys which had been paid to her in November had to go without that income at Christmas. One can imagine the impact that that had upon her and her children. After all, we are talking about people who are dependent on this money to run their households. The same constituent's maintenance order included a provision that the maintenance was to be adjusted each year in line with the consumer price index (CPI). When it was not indexed she inquired at the Agency about the increase that was due. It told her that she would have to calculate it herself. She had to ring the Australian Bureau of Statistics to get the CPI figures. The Child Support Agency either could not or would not calculate the figure for her. That was in October last year.

Only last week I had a call from a constituent who indicated that absolutely nothing has improved. Her CPI increase, which was due to take effect in the November payment of this year, has not arrived. The Child Support Agency, notwithstanding the fact that it is part of the Australian Taxation Office, has done nothing to calculate the new figure. Her ex-husband, who is paying his maintenance to the Agency, continues to receive rude and threatening letters from it alleging that he has failed to pay when in fact he has. Her ex-husband makes the payments personally at the Tax Office and has frequently had to demand a receipt for the money he has paid in. Originally he was told that the Agency did not give receipts, but he has finally managed to be able to get them, which is just as well now that he is being accused of not having paid the maintenance. If he had not insisted upon the receipts we can imagine how it would treat him now.

Another constituent I have seen recently formerly received her maintenance through the Collector of Maintenance but subsequently agreed or arranged to have her payments transferred to the Child Support Agency. She thought, from the publicity about what the Agency would do, that this was a reasonable course to take and the right thing to do. The father of her children mistakenly continued to send a number of cheques to the Collector of Maintenance and, fortunately, the Collector forwarded them to the Agency. The client is now battling to recover the moneys rightfully intended for the support of the child of the former marriage. In addition, the Agency is in the process of commencing automatic withholdings from the father's salary. This woman has been told that if she is lucky she will get the November payment in January. Mr President, I am keeping these stories short, but I hope that you can comprehend from what I am telling you the difficulties that many people are experiencing. How this woman is expected to manage without that income over the Christmas and school holiday period one can only imagine.

Another constituent who contacted me a short time ago said that the Agency had totally failed in its attempts to obtain maintenance from her ex-husband. The Agency officer she spoke to said that a summons had been served on 12 April but that there was a 28-day statutory period for her ex-husband to reply to this. That period expired in May and in August of this year she was still regularly ringing the Agency and found out, as it happened, that nothing more had been done. My office contacted the Agency and was met with a range of explanations over a period, ranging from `The court has changed its forms' and `The details of the summons have not been entered into the CSA's computer' to `The person handling the matter has not learnt the job yet, and anyway it is none of this lady's business once a summons has been served because the debt is then due to the Commonwealth'.

Just a few weeks ago the lady again rang my office to say that no further progress had been made even though she knew of and had advised the Agency of her ex-husband's whereabouts and his employment details. She was being forced to sell her home because she could no longer cope with the mortgage repayments when the money was not coming through to her. I am aware of many other cases, but I leave it at that for some of the anecdotes.

A mother of two whose ex-husband pays his maintenance to the Agency while receiving it through the Collector of Maintenance received it regularly, but while it was being paid through the Collector the ex-husband paid more than was due under the order and that surplus money was transferred to the Agency. Her ex-husband continues to meet his maintenance liability and has asked the Agency to pay the credit to his former wife for the children because he wants them to have the money; he expects them to have the money; but the Agency will not part with it. It will not say what has happened to the credit. The Agency has also claimed that this woman is receiving what it calls `out of agency' payments. She has not received such payments, she tells me, and the Agency has not been able to prove that she has. The money intended for the children and paid by the former husband is somewhere and it is not going to the woman for the benefit of the children. They certainly do not have it.

My office has made numerous inquiries on behalf of clients and the assistance received does not hearten me. Calls are not returned. Frequently I am told that the computers are down and that officers are `not on the floor', whatever that really means. Many officers are unwilling to identify themselves and so it becomes very difficult indeed to achieve continuity. I remind you, Mr President, that there is not an office in Canberra that people can contact. They have to go through the Sydney office which makes it very impersonal indeed. The Agency was set up in the middle of last year. I think all of us recognised that there would be a few difficulties in getting it going, but it should be functioning well by now.

It could be said that all I have done is give a string of anecdotes, but I have been selective in those that I have referred to, and there are many more. The fact is that although the Agency might be working in improving life in some respects, many people whose arrangements were satisfactory previously are now suffering by not receiving the money that their children need. Either there are an inadequate number of people for the work that the Agency has to undertake or those people have been inadequately trained. It is not acceptable that people should have to wait six weeks for money which has been paid by a father for the support of his children.

I also raise this because I do not get the same sorts of complaints and the same problems being raised with respect to other Commonwealth agencies in Canberra. In this case, there are no means of appeal, whereas there are forms of appeal with respect to other agencies. I find other agencies here helpful, but people who have difficulties getting through to the Child Support Agency have nowhere else to go. I neglected to show this letter to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is at the table, but I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the letter written to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) by the last woman I referred to setting out the story which really explains it quite well.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Hon Brian Howe MP
Minister for Social Security
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Sir
I seek your assistance in having a serious problem rectified.

Following my divorce from .............. a maintenance order was made by the Family Court for my children ............ and ............ (ref: C.128 of 1984). The order was for $90 per week and it specified that collection of payment would be the responsibility of the office of the Collector of Maintenance in the Magistrates Court. ........ turned 18 in August 1987 but she was still a full time student and continued to pay $90 per week until June 1988. The Collector of Maintenance informed me by letter (copy attached) that, because I should not have been paid for ........ after she turned 18, they would recover the overpayment by not paying for .......... The decision was apparently made after consultation with my ex-husband, ......... This change occurred in July 1988 when I was still providing some support for ......... who had commenced an APS Traineeship. I received $60 per week for the period 14.6.88 to 12.7.88, then $30 per week as from 20.7.88 although ....... did not turn 18 until April 1989, when the order would have varied for her automatically. I did not pursue the matter because ........ commenced full-time employment after her year as a trainee, as a permanent officer in the Australian Taxation Office about July 1988, nearly 10 months before she turned 18. This, as I have already stated, was not an officially approved variation to the maintenance order as no application was made to the Court to have the order varied.

Payments (at $30 per week) ceased from the Collector of Maintenance on 15.11.88 when the Child Support Agency took over payment of maintenance. I was informed (by way of a copy of a letter sent to ......... that there was a credit of over $400 in his account (ref: J97 Office of the Collector of Maintenance), I have misplaced my copy of this letter.
..... commenced payments to the Child Support Agency by way of direct transfer from his salary as soon as he was requested to do so after collection was taken over in November 1988.

I have made numerous inquiries, both to the Hotline of Child Support (008 112442) and the office in Canberra, but I have been unable to gain satisfaction from either of these sources regarding the correct amount of payments and, in particular, what happened to the credit which was transferred from the Collector of Maintenance. I would have expected that any surplus remaining after his current commitment, would have been returned to .......... as he is apparently paying the amount requested by the Child Support Agency on a regular basis. However, you will see from information I will give later in this letter, that the money should be paid to me.

The first payment I received from the Child Support Agency was credited to my savings account with the Commonwealth Bank, the same account to which Family Allowance is paid for I have received the following payments:
I am concerned about the following matters and I seek your assistance to have them clarified.
Letters from the Department of Social Security (ref no. 201 232 919 L) have stated that I have received direct payments (out-of-agency payments) as follows:

I do not have a letter relating to the payment of $260.89 on 05/04/89, but this payment was presumably also calculated on the basis that I had received a `direct payment' of about $130 for March. I would like to know the total amount I have been presumed to have received in `direct payments', and I would be even more interested to know who made the payments and to what account. I have certainly not received them. ........... Was under the impression that I had. Perhaps this is an accounting practice which allows the Child Support Agency's books to `balance' or is it a way of overcoming the fact that the Court Order was illegally altered? No variation of the order was, to my knowledge, approved and I did not know that the clerical staff at the Office of the Collector of Maintenance were in a position to alter the amount of maintenance without the consent of the Court. It would appear that ........... was willing to continue to pay for .......... after her 18th birthday because he was aware that she was not yet in full-time employment and the money I received from him was being passed on to her.

I have discussed these matters at length by phone with officers of the Child Support Agency and I can only say that I have been thoroughly dissatisfied with the explanations. I also discussed the matter with .......... and he was equally frustrated. It was suggested that I could elect not to take advantage of the Child Support services and arrange payment of maintenance directly from .......... This would possibly overcome some of their problems, but I am reluctant to take such a step until I can at least receive some answers to my questions.
Helene turned 18 on 22 April 1989 so it would seem that time has allowed one problem to be overcome. However, it still does not provide an answer to the matters concerning.
1. The `direct payments' which were supposed to have been made to me;
2. The whereabouts of the credit balance transferred from the Office of the Collector of Maintenance in November;
3. The legality of the action taken by that office in June 1988.

Although I appreciate that some minor problems could have reasonably occurred when collection of maintenance moneys was taken over by another agency, I cannot accept that it has been impossible to have the problems sorted out after a period of over 9 months. As a result of the change-over I am worse off by $394.90 partly because money is now paid to me on a monthly basis after is collected from . At $30 per week, I would have received $1,560 for the financial year July 1988 to June 1989. In fact, I received $360 from the office of the Collector of Maintenance and $815.10 from the Child Support Agency-a total of $1,175.10 which is $384.90 short of the amount I should have received for ......... only.

The Office of the Collector of Maintenance made regular fortnightly payments direct to me. .......... would have been paying money to that office in the same way that he does now to the Child Support Agency. There were never any delays with payment and the only hiccup occurred in July 1987 when the amount was suddenly reduced from $90 to $30 per week.

You will appreciate that the financial demands of supporting children and providing a home for them have increased, partly as a result of the current economic situation. My mortgage repayments have increased dramatically over the past months and I am trying to continue to satisfy the children's needs under more difficult circumstances. There has been a recent increase in the amount which I receive by way of family allowance for .......... and .......... has endeavoured to provide financial assistance to .......... and .......... when he is able.

I have discussed the contents of this letter with ..... and he told me that he did not wish to have the credit balance from the Collector of Maintenance returned to him. He has discussed this with the Child Support Agency and he was under the impression that the money had been paid to me. It had been suggested to him that if he were prepared to sign a letter of authority, the money could be directed to me by way of a gift or out-of-agency payment.

When I last contacted ......., he said that he would like the money to be paid either to me or direct to ....... to offset any of her future needs if he should, for any reason, be unable to continue to provide the amount of support which he now gives.

I would expect that the sum of money involved should also have accrued some interest whilst being held by the Child Support Agency-at least equivalent to what it would have accrued had it been paid to me or ....... 9 months ago.
I would appreciate your assistance in having these matters resolved as soon as possible.
Yours sincerely
A copy of this letter has been sent to Senator Margaret Reid for her information.
