The fact is that she is not receiving this money. She wrote a further letter dated 6 November 1989 which, in the interests of keeping my remarks short tonight, I also seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows
6 November, 1989
Dear Sir

Further to my conversation with an officer of your Department on 2 November, 1989, (on 008 11 2442 at 3.45 p.m.), I am enclosing copies of correspondence which I forwarded to the Minister for Social Security on 29.8.89. I am also enclosing a copy of the reply I received. (Letter dated 26 Sept., 1989).

I was assured by the person to whom I spoke on 2 November that this matter could probably be sorted out quite quickly by persons in your office. I certainly hope that this is the case as you will notice that it took the office of the Minister for Social Security almost a month to acknowledge my letter and I have still not received a proper reply after a further six weeks.

The only change which has been made since I wrote to the Minister for Social Security is that the amount of maintenance which I had been receiving from the Child Support Agency, through the Department of Social Security has been halved as from 1.11.89. I was informed of this fact by letter from the Department of Social Security. (See enclosed copy of the letter dated 30 October, 1989). A few days after I received this letter, I received another identical letter. You will see that there was no reference made to an ``out-of-agency'' payment although such a reference had been made in some of the previous correspondence.

From information which I was given by your office when I phoned on 2 November, it would appear that this elusive ``out-of-agency'' payment has been responsible for the reduction. I can only repeat that at no time since the Child Support Agency took over the function of collection of maintenance have I ever received a payment for maintenance other than that which was credited to my account in the Commonwealth Bank by the Department of Social Security. Details of these payments are given on page 2 of my letter to the Minister for Social Security 29 August, 1989.

Whereas I appreciate that your office can only act upon information received, and you have told me that the last correspondence you have on record is dated 1.12.88, it is difficult for me to accept that it would take so long (twelve months) for my case to be sorted out. I first rang the Hotline number in late 1988, shortly after I received advice that the Taxation Department would be taking over the collection of maintenance. It would appear that there is no record of this call, or the advice given to me at that time. Nor does it appear that there is any record of any other conversations which I had with people answering the Hotline or those answering my calls to the office in Canberra. I have spoken on a number of occasions to a ......... in the Canberra office. My most recent call would have been some time before I decided to write to the Minister for Social Security.
I look forward to your early reply to my letter.
Yours sincerely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance, who represents the Treasurer who is responsible for this Agency, to take up the matter to see that the children whose parents need this money for their support actually get it and that this situation does not continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks this evening about the case of Mr Alex Watson, the Australian Olympic athlete who, I believe, has been shabbily treated by the sports authorities in this country and who, I believe, deserves a better go from both the sports authorities and sports Ministers in this country. Mr Watson is not only an outstanding Australian athlete but also a fine young man who has been denied natural justice and has not been represented adequately by those sporting bodies and organisations in Australia who have the primary obligation to do so and whose primary obligation, indeed, should be to safeguard the interests of Australian athletes rather than to serve any other cause, including the promotion of national Olympic bids or the individual ambitions of sports administrators for higher and better activities of higher and better positions.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Watson was born in 1957. He is a young athlete. He has an outstanding academic record including a degree from the University of Technology in Sydney. He spent part of his scholarship time at Trinity University in San Antonio, Texas. He has always been an outstanding sportsman excelling in rugby, cross-country running and basketball. He is perhaps best known as a participant in the sport of the modern pentathlon. Between 1982 and 1988 he has always been ranked in the world top 16 and, indeed, in 1986 in the world top 10. He has been placed frequently in the one-day champion of champions competition. In fact, in 1982 and 1986 he finished with a very high ranking in those competitions. He has been actively involved in sports promotional activities on a professional basis for a large number of years and has been an active campaigner against the use of drugs in sport.

The facts of the particular incidents which brought Mr Watson to a prominence which he would not have sought occurred on 19 September 1988 during the pentathlon competition in the Seoul Olympic Games and in particular on that day when the fencing competition occurred. As a result of random drug testing, Mr Watson was found to have a particular prescribed level of caffeine in his system. He has asserted from the very first day that during the events of the pentathlon competition his total consumption of caffeine derived from taking approximately 14 cups of coffee and a couple of cans of Coca-Cola on that particular day. I should add that there has never been any prohibition on the drinking of coffee or coca cola at the Olympic games and, indeed, those substances are provided to athletes. At no stage has Mr Watson ever qualified or resiled from that particular statement.

As a result of the random testing, it was found that he had a concentration of 14 milligrams of caffeine per litre in his system. It is perhaps to be noted that the official limit set by the International Olympic Committee for the Seoul Olympic Games was 12 milligrams. It is interesting that in Los Angeles four years earlier that limit had been 15 milligrams. So within the international Olympic community there has been a variation of the prescribed limits as far as caffeine is concerned. It is not in dispute, and I do not put it into dispute, that the concentration in his system was found to be greater than that actually prescribed in the rules set down for the conduct of the Olympic Games in that year.

Mr Watson's contention is that he reached that concentration only by drinking coffee and Coca-Cola and that the tests failed adequately to take this into account. The first question-in fact perhaps the only question-which arises in that respect is whether that story is believable. The scientific evidence is overwhelming that that is the case. I want to refer to some of that scientific information. Professor Ted Maslen, the head of the Crystallography Centre at the University of Western Australia and one of the world's most experienced and respected authorities on caffeine and on sports medicine, indicated in a letter addressed to the National Secretary of the Australian Modern Pentathlon Union in October 1988 his belief that Watson's story was credible. He said, for instance, in that letter:
I am therefore convinced that a flaw in the caffeine concentration test is the most reasonable explanation for what has happened.

He indicated his belief that the International Olympic Committee's failure to issue additional data on Watson's urine analysis strongly suggested that it did not have the information which was necessary to make the sort of judgments which it did. Indeed, in a further paper of Professor Maslen's dated 10 November 1988 he makes the point:
Because of this-
and here he is referring to the concentration of caffeine which occurs as a result of dehydration in athletes-

care is required in assessing caffeine intake from the unmetabolized residue in the urine of dehydrated athletes. In the absence of information on the state of the urine an analyst might well overestimate that intake by a factor of ten. Large errors could occur in particular cases.

In a letter which Professor Maslen was good enough to send to me he attached a letter dated 28 November 1988 which he had sent to the Drug Control and Teaching Centre at King's College London in which he draws attention to the fact that he has had experience for more than 30 years with distance running and other athletic endurance events. He says in that letter:
Anomalous urine is excreted from time to time by athletes dehydrated by endurance events other than running.
Again that simply goes to demonstrate the plausibility of Watson's story about that particular cause of the concentration of caffeine in his system which was found.

Professor Maslen is not alone. Dr Ken Donald, Queensland's Deputy Director-General of Health and Medical Services and the author of a book on drugs in sport called The Doping Game, was also the chairman of the drug testing committee for the Brisbane Commonwealth Games. He has made similar comments. For example, in the 25 November 1988 issue of the Observer Fortnightly it is reported:
Alex Watson may have been innocent of caffeine doping. He may have been caught by a rule which has no valid scientific basis.
That is the view of Dr Ken Donald . . .
The report goes on to quote Dr Donald as saying:

The level that has been set for caffeine has not been backed up by properly conducted scientific experimentation which has been published and which is freely available for the community and the courts to look at.
So there I have a second authority to draw on. Professor Vincent Marks of the Department of Biochemistry at the University of Surrey makes this point in a letter dated 27 April 1989:

I therefore question without very much more information the propriety of assuming that caffeine in the urine at a concentration of 14.2 micrograms per millilitre (i.e. 14.2 micrograms a litre) is indicative of deliberate caffeine overdosage with a view to cheating at sport.

That is a third authority that I could draw on. Fourthly, Professor Burkett, the Head of the Department of Pharmacology at Flinders University, who is a world authority on caffeine concentration through his nine years of research, believes that the Olympics tests are flawed in not accounting for individual variations in caffeine metabolism and has indicated that he believes it to be perfectly possible for an athlete in such conditions-and they are the conditions known about Watson's state of health and dehydration after the fencing event at the time at which testing took place-to reach such a concentration of the amount of caffeine which has actually been established in this case. I also draw attention to the comments of another distinguished scientist from the Flinders Medical Centre, Dr J. D. Miners, Senior Lecturer in Clinical Pharmacology. In a letter of 15 November 1988, he made precisely the same comment. At the end of a detailed paper, he writes:

I wish to reiterate my misgivings about the use of urinary caffeine concentration by Sports Authorities. Many factors influence the concentration of caffeine in urine and, in general, the urinary caffeine concentration is a very poor index of caffeine dose.

I could go on in some considerable detail with other comments from scientific authorities. But perhaps I should make a final point by referring to the interim report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Drugs in Sport. At page 117 the Committee says:

Evidence was received by the Committee arguing that the caffeine level recorded by Mr Alex Watson at the Seoul Games of 14.25 micrograms/ml could have been reached by the regular consumption of coffee during the day's competition.
The Senate Committee in no way qualifies or disputes that as a statement of the scientifically possible situation.

The question is not whether in fact that is exactly what occurred on that particular day; the question is whether in fact Watson's story is believable. It is credible on the basis, I believe, of the scientific evidence which one can adduce. Under those circumstances, it seems to me that the benefit of the doubt must go to Mr Watson in exactly the same way as the benefit of the doubt should always go to those who have an accusation made against them. In these matters the burden of proof does not lie on them to prove their innocence but upon the prosecuting or accusatory authorities to make out their case.

In the first instance, there is clear scientific evidence which says that Watson's story is believable. Secondly, there is the issue of Watson's own character. It is well established that over many years he has worked for the promotion of sport in Australia and for the campaign against the use and misuse of drugs in sport and, as such, his character ought to be weighed in the balance.

Thirdly, and perhaps of almost equal weight in this matter, is the support which he has received consistently from a Mr Willy Grut, who is the most senior official of the International Pentathlon Union and has been responsible basically for the international control and supervision of the sport. Mr Grut has consistently indicated his support for and belief in Alex Watson and his story and claims. He has never wavered in that commitment. I believe that somebody of that international eminence, who is dedicated and committed to his sport, should be taken very seriously. Mr Grut is the honorary secretary of the UIPMB, which is the primary body responsible for the international control of pentathlon events, and that factor should not be ignored.

Next there is the fact that the Australian Olympic Federation has become quite ambivalent on this matter. On 11 May 1989 the Federation put out a press statement dealing with the appeal that Watson had made to the AOF Executive Board. The Board, which was considering imposing a life ban on Mr Watson as a result of his suspension from the Games in Seoul, looked at the various matters and decided that it would not impose a life ban on him. In fact, it imposed a ban on him for, I think, only two years. It was apparent that the Committee had decided that there were certain factors which it should take into account, and indeed Mr Watson is eligible for selection for the 1992 Barcelona Games. The fact that a life ban is reduced to a ban of two years must raise in the minds of people the clear spectre of the Australian Olympic Federation not being prepared to back its original judgment in this matter, believing that other factors have come into play and that a two-year ban is the correct penalty to be imposed.

I believe that Alex Watson has not had natural justice in this matter. It is perhaps unusual to think about sportsmen and participants being entitled to the protection of the courts and of the legal systems to secure natural justice, so I have been through and looked at cases where sporting matters have come before the courts of law. I have looked at the case of Robert Gray and the Canadian Track and Field Association, heard in the Supreme Court of Ontario in 1986; the case of Jeffrey Michels and the United States Olympic Committee, heard in the Seventh Circuit of the United States Court of Appeals in 1984; the case of Sandra Gasser against various United Kingdom sporting authorities, heard in the High Court of Justice Chancery Division in 1988; and, perhaps most immediately on this question, the case of Paul Quirke and the Bord Luthchleas Heireann, which is the national body responsible for sport in the Republic of Ireland, heard in the High Court in Ireland before Mr Justice Barr in March 1988. His Honour in that case, reviewing the rights of persons to be heard, said, and I quote from the judgment:
The second factor which is crucial to this case is that it is fundamental to the concept of natural justice that no man shall be condemned unheard.

He went on to deal with a suspension imposed on an athlete by the Irish Board, which was a substantial penalty for an alleged failure to comply with the rules of that body, but held that the body had not given the person concerned the opportunity to speak adequately in his own defence and therefore ordered, by judicial authority, that the suspension be lifted.

Mr Watson has sought to have his case heard by an international sporting appeals body-namely, the International Court of Arbitration for Sport based in Switzerland. He made this application which was determined in September this year. The International Court of Arbitration for Sport simply declined to hear Mr Watson, without giving any reasons for its decision. I believe it is quite outrageous that a court which does not agree to hear a person, particularly when such an arbitral tribunal has been set up for the purpose of listening to these matters, makes a decision that it will not hear the person concerned and does so without giving any reasons why that should be the case.

It is surprising that, despite all of the vicissitudes which Mr Watson has had to endure, he nevertheless continues to have an unqualified dedication to the promotion of this sport in Australia. He is now the principal person in Australia responsible for organising the 1991 Ladies World Titles in the pentathlon competition and the 1990 Australian Cup series. Indeed, he is organising Australian Institute of Sport camps for elite athletes. I have copies of correspondence here from Watson to the Sports Development Officer of the Australian Sports Commission and correspondence between him and the Manager of the New South Wales Academy of Sport for which Mr Watson is responsible for booking facilities and for organising competitions which are to take place, and correspondence in which Mr Watson is in communication with the Australian Institute of Sport, which is happy to give him assistance with the organisation of the international competitions in 1990 and 1991 to which I have referred. There is no doubt that Australian sporting authorities, whether they be the Institute, people in New South Wales or people in the Sports Commission, are perfectly happy to deal with him and perfectly prepared to accept his bona fides.
This case has come to the attention of editorial writers. The Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 27 September 1988 describes this case as one which:
. . . goes to the heart of what the International Olympic Committee is supposed to be about.
The editorial then discusses the lack of support given by Australian sporting authorities to Mr Watson. In relation to accusations that have been made it states:
Because of this the first reaction of the Australian representatives on the IOC . . . has been disappointing.
Indeed, I echo those sentiments. The editorial concludes:
The fact that the accusations-
that is, the accusations that Mr Watson is not getting a fair hearing-

have the backing of Mr Willy Grut, the secretary-general of the international body that controls pentathlon sport, and an extremely credible official, gives added weight to the need for the IOC to be punctilious about clearing the matter up. This can be done by treating the accusations seriously and setting up an inquiry that can deal with them effectively. What must not happen is that the accusations be left untested, or that the weight and prestige of the IOC be used to intimidate people seeking to open the matter up. If the IOC behaves in this way, it will have failed its Olympic Games test.

It is also regrettable that the Federal Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has declined invitations made to him, including invitations made by me during Senate Estimates hearings, to take the matter up and to pursue it at his level. This contrasts very sharply with the fact that Mr Bob Rowland Smith, the Minister for Sport and Recreation in New South Wales, has done everything possible to assist Watson to have his case heard and properly determined in international tribunals and indeed within the confines of both the Australian Olympic Federation and the International Olympic Committee. One is entitled to ask whether the desire of Australian sporting officials to avoid controversy, to seek promotion of their own cause in the international sporting movement or, indeed, to advance the cause of the Olympic Games bid for Melbourne or anywhere else is getting in the way of exercising their clear responsibility to act on behalf of an Australian athlete, who the evidence suggests has a credible case that he has been badly dealt with and shabbily treated.

Indeed, by the time this matter is resolved, Watson may well have served out his suspension and therefore will not be under any enduring suspension or problems. That reminded Senator Collins somewhat of the case of Lindy Chamberlain. It was reported in the Canberra Times on 1 December 1988 that:

After hearing evidence at a Senate inquiry from Alex Watson, the Australian pentathlete who failed a drug test in Seoul, Senator Bob Collins (NT, ALP) said the inquiry was `almost a rerun' of the Morling inquiry into the Chamberlain case, where `pools of blood turned into caramel milkshakes' because of apparent difficulties with scientific evidence.

It seems to me that the point that is being made there is an interesting one. The point is simply that, regardless of the fact that by September next Mr Watson will have served out his ban, he nevertheless remains a person whose character has been stained and whose reputation has been left qualified. I believe it is his right to have his name entirely cleared. It is his right to go forward in his sporting career, which presumably does not have many years to run, and to go forward in his professional career and in his career in the promotion of sport and campaigning against the use of drugs in sport. He is entitled, as a matter of simple, natural justice, to go forward with his name cleared.

The book of Proverbs, as you would well know, Mr President, in verse one, chapter 22, says, `a good name is rather to be chosen than great riches'. It seems to me that the protection of Alex Watson's name is important, not only for him personally, but for people who believe in the integrity of Australian sport and who believe in the provision of natural justice for people who stand wrongly accused. At the end of the day it may well be that there will be dispute about the precise meaning of any scientific test of this sort. But that can only be properly said and determined if one really believes that every opportunity has been provided for this young man to have his name cleared and that he has had the support to which he is entitled from Australian sporting officials, authorities and Ministers.

I do not believe that he has had that support. I believe he is deserving of that support. He certainly has it as far as I am concerned and I hope that, regardless of when this matter is finally determined, whether it is this side or the other of the end of Mr Watson's two-year ban, he will emerge with his name unsullied and his reputation intact. I think he deserves great credit for having been prepared to pursue this matter to the length and at the personal, emotional and financial cost that he has. I wish him the very best in his endeavours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not at all familiar with the matters raised in Senator Reid's comments regarding the Child Support Agency. Lots of new arrangements of that type have teething problems, but I am sure they will be taken into account by the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

SPEECH.PARA: As for Senator Puplick's comments, I am only in the vaguest sense aware of the question that he raised, but prima facie I think he presented a case that certainly deserves further examination. It is not clear to me whether any Minister in the Federal Government has any effective control over the matter or, indeed, to which Minister, if any, it should be referred. Obviously Senator Richardson is one such Minister, but I do not know whether he has effective control or not. There is an obvious overlap of interest-maybe to Senator Tate as well. I will see that they are both made aware of the matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.09 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 13 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What territorial waters does Australia claim around Norfolk Island and: (a) what fishing zones exist in relation to these waters; (b) what and how many commercial fishing vessels are licensed to fish them; (c) what type of licences do these vessels have; (d) what restrictions are placed on their fishing activities; (e) what nationality are these vessels; and (f) are any particular restrictions placed on how close these vessels can fish to Norfolk Island itself.

(2) Does any Government agency monitor the activities of fishing vessels in waters adjacent to Norfolk Island; if so; (a) what agencies; (b) how many infringements of (i) Australian territorial waters by unlicensed fishing vessels; (ii) fishing licenses by both Australian and foreign vessels have been detected in each of the last three years; and (c) what penalties have been imposed as a result of these infringements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Australia claims territorial waters generally 200 nautical miles in radius around Norfolk Island. In the south-west this zone makes contact with the New Zealand fishing zone and in the north with the French fishing zone generated by New Caledonia.
The entire area, from the Norfolk Island coastline to the 200 nautical mile boundary is included in the Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ).
(b) Any vessel for which a Commonwealth Fishing Boat licence is current is permitted to operate in these waters. There are currently approximately 6000 of these.
In the year ending October 1989 some 290 Japanese longline vessels were permitted to operate in the AFZ, including the area to within 12 nautical miles of the Norfolk Island coastline.
(c) Australian vessels must hold a Commonwealth Fishing Boat Licence.
Japanese vessels hold Foreign Fishing Boat Licences issued under an agreement between the Governments of Australia and Japan.
(d) There are currently no specific restrictions relating to these waters, on the operations of holders of Commonwealth Fishing Boat Licences.
Japanese vessels are restricted to the capture of tuna and billfish by longlining and must maintain a specified distance from the Norfolk Island coastline.
(e) Only Australian and Japanese vessels are permitted to operate in these waters.
(f) Australian vessels are currently permitted to fish up to the Norfolk Island coastline. Japanese vessels have recently been excluded from an area of 35 nautical miles radius around Norfolk Island.

(2) (a) The Australian Fisheries Service (AFS) is responsible for monitoring the activities of fishing vessels in the waters adjacent to Norfolk Island. Both the RAAF and the RAN carry out periodic surveillance of the area and enforcement activities as required on behalf of AFS. Coastwatch is responsible for co-ordinating these activities.
(b) No infringements of Australian territorial waters by unlicensed vessels or infringements of licence conditions by either Australian or foreign vessels have been detected in the past three years.
An unlicensed Taiwanese longliner, the `Jin Ruenn', was apprehended by the RAN on 23 June 1983.
(c) The penalty imposed on the `Jin Ruenn' was forfeiture of vessel, catch and gear.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 13 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the recent disposal of approximately 10 000 tonnes of phosphate stockpile from Christmas Island by the Liquidator of the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island:
(a) what companies were invited to tender;
(b) what companies have been invited to tender for previous sales of stockpile; and
(c) was ICI, Malaysia, asked to tender?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) None. The Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island (Winding up) Ordinance 1987 enables the Liquidator to appoint an agent to do any business that the Liquidator is unable to do, or that it is unreasonable to expect the Liquidator to do, in person. The Liquidator appointed Wesfarmers Limited in February 1988 as his agent to dispose of phosphate stockpiles and phosphate dust.
The most recent sale in September 1989 of 7508 tonnes from the phosphate stockpile was a continuation of the existing arrangement with Wesfarmers.
(b) See (a) above.
(c) See (a) above.
